column10: Large orange numbers cause the happy chemicals.

A turn-based modern dungeon crawler that will make you shriek in horror, in all the best ways. Warning: this game is not for the faint of heart. Darkest Dungeon is difficult, and deaths are permanent. The frustration of losing a party member after sinking much time and effort into refining them as one of your own is at the forefront of what makes DD stand apart. You feel the loss more deeply because of the unforgiving mechanics, and are often burdened alongside your party's stress as if you are in the dungeon with them. The core gameplay and progression is very well done. The voice acting and art style is phenomenal. Only caveat is that some of the abilities feel underpowered or that they do not have a good use, and the game can be more frustrating than fun at times.

Oh yes absolutely fantastic campaign management game. The combat is so fun and gripping there is so much style and love put into the enemies and characters. An absolute must try be wary its easy to lose significant amount of time when you first start playing.

Awesome game, 10/10 from me.

The level of polish is incredible. The setting, the soundtrack, voice acting, flavor and immersiveness are all spot on. The story is interesting, and progressively narrated by the musical voice of Wayne June. Some of the quotes I unironically say from time to time (nerd alert).

"Monstrous Size has no intrinsic merit, unless unordinate exsanguination be considered a virtue!"

The gameplay is not for everyone. Personally, I'm a big fan of turn based RPG, and Darkest Dungeon interprets the genre flawlessly. It can be hard at the start and the steep learning curve can discourage most players, but if you do decide to "steel yourself in the face of chaos" you'll feel rewarded as ever.

You WILL get screwed by RNG, heroes WILL die. But that's part of the game, and I love it for it.

"Would you recommend this game to other players? Yes/No" This is a genuinely great game. But I do not recommend it to anybody.

It's addictive without feeling rewarding. It's kinda not respectful of your time. I don't mean the fact that characters have permadeath. I love roguelikes. My issue is that 18 hours into the game, I have a set of level 4 characters, which is not even enough to enter the late game.

While I love the game's combat system, I didn't really feel like in those 18 hours the game pushed me to explore its huge selection of classes; I stuck to the 4 starter classes almost exclusively, and was almost always disappointed when experimenting with others. I also didn't find that the classes are super flexible, or that they have interesting synergies. Everything just kinda works like you expect it to. There are no cool hidden combos to discover. Once you've learned the combat system, it becomes a chore. And the fact that you can't skip animations makes this an even bigger problem.

The way Curios punish you for feeding them the wrong item made me look up the correct items on the wiki. I didn't like that... It made me feel guilty for cheating, while the alternative felt like unnecessary self-punishment and time wasting in trial and error, that could also result in a character death. It also made the game too easy and repetitive. I think the curios are a poorly designed discovery mechanic.

I enjoyed my 18 hours with this game, especially the early hours where I was losing characters, managing stress felt... stressful, and I had this sense that I'm overcoming an oppressively dark world through trials and tribulations. But I can't justify spending any more time on it, and in the end I'm retiring it dissatisfied, which sours my memories of the experience.

Ruin has come to our family. You remember our venerable house, opulent and imperial, gazing proudly from its stoic perch above the moor? I lived all my years in that ancient, rumor shadowed manor, fattened by decadence and luxury - and yet I began to tire of conventional extravagance. Singular, unsettling tales suggested the mansion itself was a gateway to some fabulous and unnameable power. With relic and ritual I bent every effort towards the excavation and recovery of those long buried secrets, exhausting what remained of our family fortune on swarthy workmen and sturdy shovels.

At last in the salt soaked crags beneath the lowest foundations we unearthed that damnable portal of antediluvian evil. Our every step unsettled the ancient earth but we were in a realm of death and madness. In the end I alone fled laughing and wailing through those blackened arcades of antiquity until consciousness failed me.

You remember our venerable house, opulent and imperial. It is a festering abomination! I beg you. Return home; claim your birthright, and deliver our family from the ravenous, clutching shadows of the Darkest Dungeon.

I don't really know if I should recommend this game or not. I'm 250+ hours in, but these are hours that come with some serious gripes with the game. I would like to recommend it, but it has serious issues and I've never finished it. It's a grindfest with serious mechanical issues. Feel free to read through and get the game at your own peril.

PROS: Some of the best mechanics when it comes to nail-biting turn based combat where death is but a few bad rolls away. Interesting heroes and hero abilities and being able to come up with your own groups is a real treat. Fantastic out of combat abilities and choices. A great sanity mechanic. Amazing art. Quality progression mechanics for both base building and heroes.

CONS: Tedious parts in the game such as having to slowly backtrack several rooms in dungeons. Why can't we fast travel to previously visited rooms? Progression while really fun can take a LONG time and can feel a bit grindy at times - you are effectively soft locked from end game content until you grind enough upgrades, equipment, etc until you can actually take on the challenge. This grind isn't bad intrinsically, but it can be a bit much of the same thing over and over with not real way to speed it up. Grinds often extenuate bad QoL and gameplay mechanics, which DD has more that it's fair share of. 

Which heroes are good in which regions? What hero has quirks that help them in a region? Or against certain enemies? I Don't know, and the benefits you get from paying attention to these "soft-hidden" mechanics are so slight that they are hardly worth keeping track of. I have a roster of 20+ heroes, how am I supposed to remember one of them gets a boon for visiting the catacombs? Why should I care when simply selecting strong heroes with good group synergy is 90% of what will carry me through a dungeon run. The positive quirks I feel need an overhaul to make them more visible at a glance, and more impactful.

Lastly I'll talk about my biggest gripe, and yes it deserves its own paragraph (several in fact). The healing in this game is completely and utterly janked and ruins both the experience and the immersion. For context: in DD your adventure can involve several battles with downtime in-between to explore. Healing can occur within a battle, and it is very effective. Healing can also occur outside of battles, but it is either a campfire (which is extremely limited use and healing HP comes at the opportunity cost of getting buffs) or it's healing items, that cost money & offer extremely low health regen & take up valuable inventory space & is capped at a total amount. Due to this, you'll want to run a group with a healer who is able to heal during the battle. Running a group without a healer is strongly discouraged, as any health lost is extremely costly/difficult to get back without one. And you cannot guarantee you'll be able to avoid damage, the game is just too swingy.

So you're forced to run a healer. How many are there to choose from in the game? Well... two? I guess. (Perhaps 3 now, but I'm going off of when I played it mostp) One is effective, the other is less effective. All other healing is either terrible beyond usefulness or self heals which is a lovely complement in a group, but doesn't really help when a party member who can't self heal takes hits... So suddenly to play optimally, my party comps pretty much always include a Vestal. This leads to extremely boring team coms and monotonous game play. Why in the sweet **** is the healing balanced this way when everything else is so much better balanced. It's horrendous game design effectively punishing the player for trying to enjoy other fantastic elements of this game. Want to make a cool party comp of four party members? PSYCH! You get 3 options and you better take the Vestal or you're going to have a bad time. A simple fix would be to allow for much better out of combat healing - if it came at a cost that's fine, you're running a higher DPS comp anywho, it should have a downside. As it stands however, and comp without a healer just isn't viable.

But we've not even got to the best bit. Since healing out of combat is so restrictive and expensive, you're highly incentivised to heal within combat. So a battle is best played out where you kill all the enemies except one, then you keep them alive but in a weakened state by stunning and debuffing them, whilst you use your healer to patch up your heros back to full.... It completely disrupts the flow and immersion of the game, turning it into a frustrating experience beyond comprehension. It is by far my least liked aspect of this game. It takes an already grindy game and makes it even more tedious. And did I mention it ruins the immersion? Because it really does. Do I want to have fun, or do I want to min max and play out the worlds most S****y mechanic in order to stand a chance in the next combat. Woe is me.

I don't understand how a game studio can be so close to hitting the mark can publish several DLCs for their product and yet never resolve some of these glaring issues... Some of the updates have seen ever so slight improvements to my gripes here, as I'm sure any astute fan & reader will point out, but it's a drop in the bucket to what's required.

I'm not sure if I've ever experienced such disappointment in a game that had such promising potential, only to see it squandered.

Recently took this game up again after letting it sit for seven years. Up against the 86 week time limit and with 8 heroes already dead, I wiped on the final boss of the very last dungeon and 86 weeks of game-playtime - many days of real time - went down the drain. It took me seven years to recover my morale enough to try again.

You start the game with two heroes, always the same two guys, Reynauld the kleptomaniac crusader and Dismas the cheating highwayman. In other games of this sort your heroes are always straight-backed courageous fellows who are in it to the end, but in this game your adventurers have "quirks" which are sometimes good, and sometimes bad (like being a kleptomaniac, or a known cheat). As they adventure through the dungeon they get stressed out and sometimes they'll crack and develop afflictions which cause them to behave strangely (and poorly) in combat. (Occasionally the stress will make them true heroes. But not very often.)

If they survive, they can perform stress relief activities like grabbing a drink, gambling at the bar, praying to their gods, other things of that nature, and recover enough to maybe go back and try again. New heroes will come to your Hamlet on the stage coach, ready to fight and die for you, and you will build parties of four and send them out every week to explore the dungeons, get gold and trinkets, level up, and upgrade their equipment at the Hamlet (which you also upgrade to get better heroes, better equipment, better skills, and better stress relief activities). Ultimately your final goal is to go into the Darkest Dungeon, four times, to stop the unspeakable horrors that dwell there from taking over your world.

Death of a hero is almost always permanent, and on Stygian difficulty if you lose 12 heroes the game is over, or if you take more than the 86 weeks the game gives you the game is over. (You can play on lower difficulties which have no time or death limits, if you want. That turns the game more into a rogue-lite than a rogue-like. That might be your cup of tea.)

On my latest playthrough, I triumphed against the final boss with 2 weeks to spare. It felt good. Really good. On the old road, I found redemption.

Excellent game, stressful, but it is great fun to work your way through the combat puzzles, so to speak, and slowly get better and better at finding hero and skill combinations that let you tear through the inhabitants of the various dungeons. The dungeons ramp up in difficulty as your heroes level up, and they will refuse to go back to dungeons that are too easy for them, so you have to get better. The champion difficulty dungeons, for level 5-6 heroes, are very, very tough, especially the bosses. I tend to lose my heroes at the beginning, when they are level 0 nobodies, and at the end, when the highest level bosses expose the weaknesses in my old strategies. Strongly recommend, if you like dungeon crawlers.

There was a time when I would not only endorse this game but perhaps give it a rare 10/10. This was up to 2017 and the Butcher's Circus. Nowadays this is far from the case.

The original game with its two difficulties (normal and hard) and several old and newly added areas is very well balanced, challenging and rewarding for planning and experience.

Since then the balance values have been tweaked making stress a more abundant problem, the PvP circus annoys the player every step of the week to play it in a giant glowing icon even though the servers are down and thus several achievements impossible.

Combine that with two new mechanics, the blood curse and the farmstead. Both of these are optional and should be challenged mid to lategame. Ingame both tell the player to do it on "Resolve 1-2". This is wrong. The Farmstead endless run will overwhelm early groups and will set stress and money back alot. Doing it on hardmode is akin to suicide as it saps precious resources for early build up.

The blood curse dungeon is a similar trap, spawning new ways to slow you down and to kill your people all over the map once it has been triggered. It should be avoided on hardmode runs if possible.

This game is not as well balanced as it was up to 2020, the game is not rewarding as it was up to 2020 and the game annoys you like nothing else with a feature that is DEAD. A dead feature that makes this game a nightmare for completionists. It is 100% incompleteable.

If you are a completionist, do not buy this game. If you dislike mobile game "info" terror... avoid it too. Although some mods remove that nuisance.

Nowadays this game is "okay", play it and maybe complete the singleplayer content. I personally will NOT recommend it anymore. This dungeon has been corrupted.

As frustrating as the game can be, it is still hands-down one of the best roguelikes I have ever had the pleasure of playing. The atmosphere, the stress system, and more all just balance well in this game. Highly recommend - just don't get too overconfident while diving into the darkness.

The most annoying, aggravating, and anxiety-inducing game you'll love to play.
The greatest thing about Darkest Dungeon - and the thing that many players hate and fear - is that it is a FAIR GAME. As in, actually fair. Balanced. It is NOT "fair" in the sense that one measly hero can develop god-like power and squash everything in his/her way. Darkest Dungeon is fair in the sense that your heroes and the enemy are almost a 1:1 ratio in power. Every blow you land on the enemy is dished out right back at you. Boss fights are actually tough, and unique, not just a formality. Instead of winning 99% of the time and b*tching about the ONE TIME YOU FAIL, like in most RPGs, you will have to make a decision whether or not to cut your losses and "fail" more than you will feel comfortable with. The game rewards wise choices and stacking the odds in your favor as much as you can - most of the time. Sometimes it just doesn't matter, because the % chance just didn't go your way.
And considering that's how things have gone for the MILLIONS AND BILLIONS of monsters who have died to feed our egos over the years, that's more than fair.

Darkest Dungeon is a masterpiece that flawlessly combines dark and atmospheric storytelling with challenging gameplay. The game's unique art style, reminiscent of a gothic novel, immediately draws you into its grim and haunting world. Assemble your team of heroes and embark on a journey through treacherous dungeons filled with horrors, testing your strategic skills and resilience at every turn.

What makes Darkest Dungeon truly exceptional is its modding community. The game's modding support opens up a realm of possibilities, allowing players to tailor their experience. From new character classes to additional storylines, mods enhance the already rich gameplay, providing endless variations and keeping the adventure fresh.

The stress mechanic adds an extra layer of complexity, forcing players to not only manage their party's health but also their mental well-being. The constant risk and reward dynamic creates an immersive experience, where every decision matters and the consequences are palpable.

Darkest Dungeon is more than just a game; it's a dark and gripping journey that challenges your tactical prowess and resilience. With the added joy of mods, it becomes a playground for creativity and personalization. If you're a fan of deep strategy, atmospheric storytelling, and enjoy the flexibility of modding, Darkest Dungeon is an absolute must-play.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

"The struggle is not in the dungeon, but rather inside the mind."

Its corridors echo with the whispers of madness, and every step forward feels like a descent into the abyss. Heroes are but flickering candles against the overwhelming shadows, their struggles a futile dance with the inevitable. In this merciless realm, hope is a fragile illusion, easily shattered by the horrors lurking in every corner. It's a journey into the darkest recesses of the human psyche, where victory comes at a price too steep for some to bear.

Turn-based games without much in the way of movement systems are one of the hardest genres to pull off in my opinion. For a slow-paced genre that relies on strategy to be fun, it can be hard to avoid situations where it's best to just use whatever move has the biggest numbers over and over. I feel this issue is best highlighted in pokemon, where casual players can get by pretty easily just by using a big move repeatedly and one-shotting everything. Darkest Dungeon completely circumvents all of the genre's usual flaws and forces you to think. It took me like 4 party-wipes to grasp that this game was something special, something that required a deep understanding of different synergies, combos, and mechanics, but once I started to put the pieces together, it became a blast. As of the writing of this review, my learning curve is only beginning to tread upward, but I can already say that DD has one of the best, if not the single best, turn-based RPG combat systems that I've ever seen. It doesn't need a grid map like fire emblem to introduce positioning elements. Even with its deceptively simple positioning system and the way it follows pokemon's formula of only allowing each character to know four moves at any given time, the synergies between different characters and the way their abilities compliment each other is truly a sight to behold. If you enjoy turn-based strategy, this game is a necessity. Plus, it's got workshop support, and it's one of those games with really cool devs who look at the awesome in-depth mods made by their community and make them into official content, or even publish them on the steam store as entirely new games in their own right like they did with Black Reliquary. As far as DLC goes, crimson court is basically more of the Darkest Dungeon you know and love. It has new mechanics, enemies, and some really cool bosses (I've only fought the crocodile so far, but the battle was very difficult in a very fun way, and beating it felt extremely rewarding), but it doesn't reinvent the wheel. The best part, however, is probably the Flagellant, a new class that damages and applies bleed to itself in exchange for healing other party members, doing big attacks, and otherwise helping the rest of the team. The Flagellant also has a few big moves that he can perform only at low HP, synergizing with his self-damage mechanic and making the class feel way more involved. The mission structure is much the same as ever. Color of madness and butcher's circus are a bit further removed from the base game, offering new game modes. Color of madness adds a new area, the farmstead, that acts like a sort of gauntlet mode. There's no torch, no food or camping, no corridors to traverse or objects to interact with. It's just back-to-back battles. Personally, I really enjoy the mode. It gives you constant action and simplifies the game a bit, tearing away some of the fluff and extra mechanics to give way to the game's phenomenal combat system. It also rewards you with unique trinkets to bring into normal missions, tying it nicely back into the main game's progression. Butcher's Circus, unlike the previous two DLCs, doesn't really contribute to the main game. It's a mode that's mostly independent of your estate's progression (you only need to unlock everything in this mode once, even if you complete your estate save file) which lets you partake in multiplayer battles. It doesn't really add to the base game in any way, but I don't care, because this mode fucking slaps. I absolutely love butcher's circus. It's a bit sandboxy, since you can customize your trinkets and heroes in any way you choose without risking the loss of those trinkets or heroes, which makes it a great proving ground to test a cool build. It's also just a ton of fun to put your strategies head to head against real people. The final paid DLC, the shieldbreaker class, doesn't add as much as the other two, but in my experience the shieldbreaker is busted as hell so I'd say it's worth it anyway. She's a dancer who plays a bit like the jester and has some nice hard-hitting attacks plus a little bit of bleed and blight. The other DLC hero, musketeer, is kinda mid, but she's also free so it doesn't matter.

Shallow in gameplay, the game masks this by putting in the 'difficult gameplay' situation (and some theatrics). The game is simple, 'out-stat your opponent' regaeding one key implementation- resistance percentages. But without a compelling dungeon crawl to get there. Most enemies have 10 to 20% resistance to a few damage types, then 30% resistance to just about all damage types, then 45%, 65%. It is just a plain increase with progress. And you counter that by increasing your own damage% above 100%. Like 150% against a resistance of 65% (this only means is you'll deal 85% of the weapon damage. This is as deep as you will find in game systems). Or chance% and resistance% for hit/dodge and status inflict/resist. The game is lacking substance. It is bland, with only visuals as the real feature along with subpar horror theatrics, while plastering 'horror' around which would usually just be a setting to lay out the event of horror. Here, the presence of 'twisted creatures with horrifying shreiks' is supposedly enough. From my point of view they might as well well normal creatures like lions doing what they do, surviving, along with a hint of perverted necromancers and witches doing their thing just because.

The fights are seemingly deep till you are hit with this revelation and just start playing properly. Then you see that 99% battles are a breeze because there is just one thing you need to consider, and other times there is just no way you will win except for example the enemies miss 5 times in a row and you crit 5 times in a row. The retreat and stress mechanic is just a time sink, and resultant of combat mechanics will be caused not by your fault, while on stygian it is a near guaranteed loss of the entire game (caused not by your fault). It is hard to mess up when you only have to keep track of one thing, which will give you a premonition of which fights are going to play out how without even a serious glance. The whole loop became… boring.

Might and Magic Book One (1986) has most of this game's mechanics. And 20 times more possibility. Yet very hard, but only in the sense you do not understand the game enough yet, or decline to use the various solutions available readily at all points of time before the party member making such solution possible dies.

Storytime…

So, I had this mission where my Flagellant and Vestal both caught the Crimson Curse. And during battles, they were practically healing each other. Later on, I kinda ship them, gf and bf, forbidden love between a nun and a madman kind of stuff. Ngl, the vestal gave “I can fix him” vibes, lol... I even started dressing them in matching red outfits and gave them cute nicknames.

Then, one day, when they went on a mission together, my flagellant got afflicted and craving for blood (which I ran out of). He went batshit crazy and stabbed the poor Vestal, leaving her bleeding out. I was pretty ticked off, so I didn’t give the Flagellant any food for the rest of the mission. Had to come back to it a couple of times before I got into it, but now I'm into it and it's a very good game. Very good atmosphere, story, and I find I get attached to my characters.

For example, Malvallet the Crusader. Joined us around week 10 and was a capable warrior from the beginning who was often the most useful member of the team. Eventually he died in a brutal wipeout of my A team at the hands of the Siren when I had no light and had ran out of torches (didn't realise it was a boss and yes I was dumb and had never fought a boss before). I moved on and took in another Crusader, Hauville, who eventually surpassed Malvallet and became my new best front liner. Then one fateful, day, Malvallet was miraculously brought back to life! To learn from the now veteran Hauville, alongside a newly acquired Crusader named Bose, who had a drinking problem. Malvallet and Bose would become good friends as they went on several missions together, drank together, and trained alongside one another, while Hauville was drafted for the more elite missions. Malvallet has been in several scrapes since then. Such as a desperate battle against the Brigand 12 Pounder, in which Osmond the Bounty Hunter, whom Malvallet had known before his own death, was knocked to the ground by a cannonball and then stabbed to death by a cutthroat. All three crusaders are still alive, and Malvallet is now a legendary crusader alongside Hauville, with Bose not far behind. However there is still a long way to go. If I was ever to write a story about Malvallet, it would be from the perspective of Caunter, an abomination who loves being whipped and has survived since even before Malvallet joined.

All this is to say that it's fun to grow attached to the characters, a bit like pokemon.

Almost! Almost a great game. 

This is a review for the base game, not either DLC expansion or the PVP mode.

Darkest Dungeon takes the atmosphere of spelunking in decrepit and damnable caverns for loot, riches and glory and boils it down to basic principles. The art, music and narration are all fantastic. While the mechanics relating to party comp, provisioning, and meter management are all fun, the AI is where this game gets tedious. Even when you load up overleveled heroes with your best equipment and employ use of abilities that are the counter pick to the horrors you face, the AI still hyper fixates in ways that you really aren't given tools to do anything about. 

Have low health? You will receive a DoT that will pick off that party member. Have high stress? literally any enemy that can inflict stress will solely target that character to induce a heart attack. Spreading your food out evenly after each battle? too bad, you proc'd a food check three steps later and lost twice the health you gained. 

At its core, its a solid game that scratches the itches I have for things like Ironman mode in XCOM, but the sheer inability to avoid half the detrimental mechanics makes it more annoying that regretful when you lose a character to RNG. 

If you like your Roguelike to be bit more in your control than up to chance, pass on this one.

I was drawn in by the intriguing atmosphere ( as a fan of Lovecraft) and wanting something that was going to be different to what I normally play, after 3 hours, I feel I've given this game a fair shake. Here's what I learned: 
- It's repetitive.
- Strategize and be cautious as much as you want, the game is simply cruel and punishes you indiscriminately for every decision you make - good or bad.
- For every step you take forward the game slaps you 10 backwards for no reason.
- Despite my best efforts, after 3 or 4 days I ran out of money, my 9 or so characters were so afflicted with debufs and stress that they basically were a gibbering mess, incapable of fighting, and I have no means to to heal/treat them. 
- RNG sh**s on you even if you somehow manager to get one of your debilitated characters to actually make a strike.
- I didn't even bother with character customisation, because what's the point, they will die within a few day.

This game obviously panders to the sadistic, self punishing types or to those who enjoy mind-numbing grind. I've been on the wikis and discussion boards, and I categorically reject anyone's claim that you have to strategies to win - I usually excel at strategy games that require careful planning (resource/stat management, proceed/retreat mechanics etc), but this is sadism. I played this on the normal mode, and its unplayable difficulty wise.

I know I'm in the minority, and I guess I probably just ought to "stay in my lane" and "not be a n00b"; It's not fun, it's enjoyable. If I want to spend what minuscule free time I have getting attempting to grind some sort of survival, whilst running out of money, dealing with stress, and unfair conditions, I might as well put in another shift at work. 

I don't understand this trend of creating nasty games that are sadistic in nature. Life is fucked up and stressful enough. There's a story I wanted to experience here, with some interesting lore. Is it relay too hard for the devs to make this game accessible for those who don't have infinite gaming hours to "grind and get good" and just enjoy the game in an easier "story mode"? 

I guess not.

TL;DR: If your into Dark Souls like repetitive sadism, do for it. Otherwise, move along.

It just isn't fun. It's extremely repetitive, like mind-blowingly repetitive. I like challenging and tactical games, but this isn't it. You see the same characters and scenery over and over throughout the whole game, and you're doing the same thing over and over. There's no real strategy, because there are so many random things that happen. For example, your characters can suddenly get some illness or have a heart attack and die out of nowhere or just continuously miss or pass on their turn until everyone is dead. They can also become a klepto and start stealing loot from you or heal for zero points, wasting your much needed heal and ending your turn for no apparent reason. Oh and death is permanent, so have fun working on building up characters so that they can die and leave you starting from scratch. Have fun never having any money either. Have fun never having upgrade supplies. You have to grind like crazy, using characters as throwaways just to get some small amount of supplies and money going. The whole game is just unnecessarily punishing and inconsistent. Maybe if I had time for that kind of crap I'd keep playing it anyway, but I don't see the point when there are much better games available. I recommend you pass on this one. Like I said, it just isn't fun.

Darkest Dungeon is a case study in bad game design.

The game has the best in class writing, great sound design, fantastic art direction, yet manages to fumble the full package with really, really bad gameplay.

Two of the greatest hurdles of good game design are avoiding RNG and grind, and Darkest Dungeon fails both hurdles spectacularly.

The core gameplay loop is not fundamentally broken. It’s actually quite fun at first. But it quickly devolves into an unfair grind-fest.

Randomness is maximized to the point that even on easy difficulty a single missed or hit attack can be the difference between winning or losing. If that sounds fun, it’s not.

One of the worst design features of the game is the fact that mercs refuse to fight in dungeons they perceive as being ‘too easy’. It feels so artificially imposed to just make the game even more unfairly hard than it already is.

A timer might make sense, or an 'arrogance' trait, but nope, every single mercenary refuses to make your life even remotely easier, simply arbitrarily deciding not to try lower level dungeons in a textbook example of ridiculously artificial difficulty.

The game, while very difficult even on the easiest difficulty, is still tolerable up to the ‘darkest dungeon’, or the hardest location in the game, where things get truly ridiculous, with even the basic enemies able to basically wipe your party. And better yet, if you try to run away, you will be guaranteed to lose one of your party members.

Worse yet, the final dungeon has to be beaten four separate times.

This is already silly enough, but what somehow makes things even worse is that any hero that goes in refuses to go back, meaning that character is rendered almost useless. This is such bad design that it breaks my brain. Again, maybe make it a trait or a timer--but no. The character will never go back in again, period, and no positive traits or items can in anyway prevent or reverse this.

What this means is that you have to grind a total of 16 characters to level 6 just to beat the game, which is an insane amount of grind. And if you ever get party-wiped once, that’s yet another 4 characters you’ll have to grind to level 6 just to be able to have another chance at beating the dungeon.

The game would not only be much fairer but much more effective if the darkest dungeon was a single, final, climactic fight. You can lose, but if you win, its over.

To get an idea of how unenjoyable DD’s gameplay is, 6.4% completed the game on easy mode. That is a crazy low number for a game of the quality that Darkest Dungeon is in so many regards.

Pretty damningly, Dark Souls 3, meanwhile, which is supposedly famous for its difficulty, has been beaten by at least a full 25% of all players. Of course, DS3 is difficult in a fair and rewarding way, while Darkest Dungeon is just punishing.

Meanwhile, 4.2% completed the game on normal. Finally, only a laughably, embarrassingly small 1.2% completed the game on Stygian, the hardest difficulty. For the record, 2.2% completed XCOM 2 on the hardest difficulty, legendary mode, which is famously very, very hard and very, very long for most to complete.

As another comparison, 2.8% of people defeated Cuphead on the hardest difficulty, which is also known for its very high difficulty.

For the record, the fact that DD was a huge grindfest has been reiterated for many years by many people. If you go to the negative reviews of this game, the reviews are extremely consistent--there is not a single criticism of anything but one thing, the gameplay, and more specifically, that the game has a good early game and decent to poor mid-game which leads to a godawful, insufferable grindfest and RNG hell of an end-game that basically no one, and I mean no one-- even most of the positive reviewers--seem to like.

When the criticisms of the game are this consistent across the board, it’s not a matter of subjective opinion, or not being good enough, you are doing something wrong with your game.

Whoever designed the aesthetic, did the writing, and so on, is a genius. But whoever made the gameplay is, without any exaggeration, an idiot, and an extremely egotistical idiot on top of it.

Darkest Dungeon is a disturbing depiction humans in a lovecraftian nightmare. As you descend into the dark tunnels your heroes will become stressed as they teter on the brink of madness. The game is deliberately tough and often unfair, and it saves every choice you make. It teaches you to make the best of a terrible situation, and that is where the true beauty of Darkest Dungeon lies.
A game designed to be unfair, but that is kept alive by a loving modding community.

I'm supposedly only 18 hrs in. That really just doesn't sound or feel right. In a way it feels like I've been playing forever. Perhaps that's because I've had it for a while and toyed with it here and there until recently really diving in. Or... Maybe it's because it's nearly accurate to real life as it sometimes slaps you in the face. It reminds you that things don't always go your way and life sucks sometimes no matter how much you plan, prepare and/or train. That, in itself, might not sound fun and this game is a challenge in many ways but there is a path through it that many find so much enjoyment. I am on that path. With that said, there was something else that initially drew me to this game and did not disappoint: 
Art Style and Presentation!
The visual and audio production of this game is amazing! The art style, the music, sound events, the narrator and the entire mood is done so very well. 

Major production value and long play/replay for the price, IMO. One just needs to be able to cope with their heroes dying. Don't get too attached to them and be prepared to let them go sometimes. [+] Each dungeon you select a new combination of classes, can change their builds and equip different trinkets, making each dungeon run feel fresh
[+] You can play the game really safe and you always have an opportunity to flee from fights and leave the dungeon if things are getting tough. Beautiful game that massively overstays its welcome. The combat is novel the first few hours, until you find the optimal abilities and hero choice and proceed to do the same thing for the next 40 hours of your campaign. This wouldn't be as much of a problem if experimenting with new abilities/heroes wasn't so discouraged, either through the roster limit, stress that locks you out of using a character for multiple weeks if it's too high, and permadeath. Much of this stems from the "hero management" genre as a whole, but nothing was stopping the devs from fixing these sort of problems, other than the idea that it makes winning the game more rewarding, and while that's not wrong, the reward does not outweigh the frustration and monotony necessary to get there.

Characters you have spent hours grinding to get to the max level will die. Despite all this Darkest Dungeon is an excellent game. The player is expected to make the most out of  a bad situation and persevere even when  disaster occurs. The atmosphere and art are encapsulating and the game play is suspenseful as every move really does determine if your party lives or dies.  The DLC's add even more content with new bosses, quirks, classes and, events that make the game even more enjoyable. Darkest Dungeon is Challenging game that will not hesitate to throw you through a ringer but it has some of the highest highs of any game I've ever played and that keeps me coming back again and again.

I really love Darkest Dungeon.

The grim aesthetic does a great job of staying safely oblique while implying horror that is deeper, more morbid, more cosmically unhinged. In this sense, the game is primarily an artistic experience. The sound design complements gameplay beautifully - the voice actor for the narrator has a presence in my internal dialogue.

Before I move onto gameplay, it is important to note that I am not a skilled gamer. I can spend hundreds of hours grinding, making the same dumb mistakes and never getting to enjoy later-game content in some of the more brutal titles.

This is a hard game.

I recall that I bought this game the year that it released and I have logged 200+ hours. I have not beat this game. Darkest Dungeon 2 is out. I will still play this game (in addition to Darkest Dungeon 2).

Like many roguelikes, a good DD run will have you invested in your favorite heroes - and one bad dungeon can have you wailing at your monitor over the loss of a cherished asset. It feels a bit like XCOM in this way. Training up a strong team, collecting powerful relics and careful planning will get you to the final room - but then the real fight begins!

When you consider the rich modding community and all the DLC you can layer onto an already intense strategic experience... it is very easy to recommend this title.

Once you've got a handle on this first entry, take a crack at its sequel!

[h1] One of my favourites of all time. A wonderfully painful experience. [/h1]

Contrary to the title of this review, if you're not into overwhelmingly and seemingly unfairly difficult games then this one may be a pass. As a diehard fan of the XCOM strategy genre (Red Hook took inspiration from XCOM according to the devs), I fit right into the "win against all odds" demographic but I understand this isn't for everyone. If you enjoy strategy games and (especially) have an interest in D&D then this game will be damn close to perfection.

If I could pick one thing to highlight (because otherwise this review would be very long) it would be the voice acting. It is by far the best and most iconic voice acting I have EVER heard in a video game. The game simply would not be what it is without Wayne June.

This game will test your ability to keep your cool. Go in with the right mindset. You WILL get beaten down. You WILL get screwed over by bad RNG. The highs are high but the lows are crushing. That is part of the experience. The campaign is long - but victory will come.

Good luck!

"Ruin has come to our family."

The Ancestor, driven mad by fervent curiosity, grew obsessed with uncovering the secrets slumbering beneath the family manor.

So too, was I. Obsessed, I played this game relentlessly until completion like it was my day job.

I found Darkest Dungeon to be an excellent turn-based party RPG that proved enthralling to the very end. It is a game that heavily rewards game knowledge and mastery to minimize the risk to the heroes that matter, and to know when to discard the heroes who do not.

--Well-built RNG and uneasiness--

There's already a top Steam review that perfectly addresses how the mechanics inform the feel of the game. I would suggest you go see it too, if you're looking to purchase this game; it's eloquently writen.

The underlying RNG tolerances of the game create a fundamental sense of uneasiness that keeps players on their toes. The incredible lows, like the panic that sets in when one of your heroes goes from full HP to Death's Door in a single stray crit, provide a sharp contrast with the highs, like when a hero unexpectedly turns virtuous and manages to rally the party to victory.

Once you've built a solid foundation of game knowledge, you can mitigate most of the RNG through thorough preparation. Knowing which heroes thrive in which areas, familiarizing yourself with the enemy movesets, and watching your carefully built strategies unfold is extremely satisfying, because all of this gets you 90% of the way to success. Even the most experienced players are kept on their toes, because in that remaining 10%, you are left with nothing but a lot of prayers to RNGesus. Even then, with enough preparation, close calls can almost always be averted with quick thinking (speed. up. your. healers). Every victory feels meticulously earned, and that is a glorious feeling.

--Excellent Horror Aesthetics--

One would be remiss to not compliment the sheer craftsmanship of the game's aesthetics. Every visual is delightfully horrifying; many attack animations reveal new depths of corruption lurking behind the already grotesque gallery of enemies.

The narration deserves special mention here, because narrators are often hit or miss in games due to their potential for repetition. A bad narrator quickly becomes exhausting to listen to. The Ancestor is an excellent narrator, and the voice actor delivers his lines perfectly. I am always impressed by how much sadistic pleasure he conjures up for his torment of the Miller; I can practically feel the Ancestor's spittle as he revels in his dark deed. Even knowing the Ancestor is an awful person in-lore, his triumphant declaration of "The flesh is knit!" on a critical heal feels like an earnest celebration. Many of the Ancestor's lines have quickly become endlessly quotable earworms.

--Good DLCs, but avoid on first playthrough--

For my first playthrough, I kind of blithely turned on all of the DLCs I had available, which was all of them. Crimson Court, Shieldbreaker, The Color of Madness, Musketeer, and Butcher's Circus. While I don't regret this decision, had I known more up front I would've saved these DLCs for a second, or even third playthrough. The major issue with the DLCs is that while they provide an absolutely wonderful amount of awesome content, they also bring a very noticeable amount of power creep that can throw off the balance of the game.

First off, The Flagellant (which comes with the Crimson Court) and Shieldbreaker classes are both incredibly versatile and powerful. The Flagellant absolutely dominates in three of the in-game regions, and the Shieldbreaker decimates the other two as well as the endless mode. Both classes come with unusual drawbacks that hint at their clearly overpowered nature. The Flagellant is limited in that you can only have one per team, as multiple would be too strong. The Shieldbreaker comes attached with a series of "nightmares" that serve as a kind of unpleasant surprise sidequest for her, making her a potential liability until you've won all of the nightmare battles.

The Crimson Court DLC also adds the "District" in-game system, which gives a significant number of permanent in-game buffs and changes the player economy entirely. This, too, is something that might've made the game ever so slightly easier.

Two DLCS (Crimson Court and Color of Madness) also add a large number of new trinkets that are often far stronger than base game trinkets.

Finally, The Color of Madness DLC adds a new consumable item called Shard Dust that can very quickly derail the difficulty of many bosses. I was able to two shot the final boss this way, and although it was very amusing to do so, I imagine that the original battle would've proven far more epic and fitting as the climax of the game.

Overall, I feel the DLCs provide a lot of opportunities for experienced players to experiment, theorycraft, and break the game, but that they aren't really suitable for a new player.

--One Downside: a little Grindy--

That's all there is to really say about it. Some parts of Darkest Dungeon can feel a bit grindy and tedious at times: you're constantly wanting for certain key resources in the early game, and you don't really stop needing them until the late game mark. I wouldn't have minded if some of the resources were easier to stack in inventory during longer quests. This is about the only thing in Darkest Dungeon that I feel was genuinely a little off.

--Conclusion--

It's quite late, so I'm going to wrap this review up a little unceremoniously as my writing quality has been steadily dropping for the past hour. If you're a fan of turn-based RPGs, I would very strongly recommend Darkest Dungeon. It is a finely calibrated and excellent crafted experience that offers a hearty but reasonable challenge.

One the best games I've ever played. Granted, It doesnt look like much on the surface, tbh, watching it played on you tube etc... but man...is it fun and alot more strategic then at first glance. 

The game is well polished and well done, with few if any bugs. AI is smart, although as with any game it can get repetitive over time. 

Voice acting is the best in any game ive played hands down. excellent voice actor! 

Classes are fun to play with and pushes you to come up with different party compositions. Every single class can be used at least 2 ways, most alot more. Some you wouldnt think using them in a certain manner until you need a back liner or gap filler and have none to choose from. It forces you to utilize the classes in a different way than optimal and helps you learn all their skills and capabilities. Very well done in that regard. 

Stays challenging until the end. I love all the various quirks and diseases one can get. Really makes you think and prioritize different combos of party members in the different locations. Helps the game feel 'real' constantly juggling the best and worst quirks and party members to tackle the task at hand. 

Random wandering mini bosses adds so much to the game and helps 'fill in the chinks' imo. Alot of neat little hidden things here and there that keep you on your toes.

Finances stay a constant need until the end, which i love. It really makes you think about which buildings to upgrade, which skills and abilities to unlock and which blueprints to go after. nicely done and give you a small break from dungeon delving.

By far the best way to play is with the Crimson Court dlc. it adds alot to the game and i wish the other locations had some of the same mechanics that it provides. especially the epic quests part. really nicely done. the music in CC is awesome as well.

The downside to me is a little repetitive, of course, the Color of Madness dlc is not fun at all IMO. i usually play with it off nowdays. just dont like the grind and no maps. not for me, although the bosses are quite the challenge.

All in all, perfect game. would recommend to anyone who likes dark fantasy, or strategic play

[h1]TL:DR In the end, there is only darkness[/h1]

Bring a change of pants.

It’s not often you come across something unique or different amongst Steam’s infinite collection of games. 

DD combines dungeon crawling and town management and adds a dash of Gothic and HP Lovecraft. If that was not enough, once simmering in your pot, the developers add turn-based combat and serve you the complete game with added stress management.

It has a unique art style which would not look out of place in a Dracula comic and the narrator must have enjoyed his work. That guy is called Wayne June and almost worth the price of admission on his own. It’s almost Rocky Horror Picture Show time. Or Transylvania. 

The developers, Red Hook Studios, do a decent job introducing the player to the game’s systems and mechanics. How to navigate dungeons. Win in combat. Build your ancestors estate so you can attract heroes to join your fight and sooth their woes after each journey into the depths.

However, don’t think Red Hook are kind folks. The game quickly gets diabolically harder and if there are any people playing on the higher difficulties, well. Those people must be eating iron nails for breakfast.

Now, I do like the dungeon exploration and combat. It is complex enough for an old-time gamer to appreciate with so many combinations and strategies you could start a new chapter of encyclopaedia Britannia. 

Every time you venture into the depths you should organise four heroes. Equipment, amulets and trinkets. Torches and food. In real life I expect these guys to scarper off as soon as you turn your back. However, in the game, I almost feel sorry for them. They might return but they won’t be unscathed. Some of them might even go mad. You really must grow your band of heroes as most won't survive two ventures in a row.

I particularly like the Plague Doctor and Jester Class. The former can throw poison bombs from the back line causing damage over several rounds. The Jester has a guitar and knows how to use it. We also have a Knight Crusader, and a Werewolf. There are many heroes, each with their own unique skills and unique equipment.

This leads me to explain some of the signature features of the game that makes it stand out from its competitors. Your torch will go out slowly and in the increasing darkness your heroes might be ambushed. Or worse. They might get stressed. 

Stress management is very important as your characters might stop following your orders. Hit out at their companions. Technically they might join the other side. If you make the wrong choices they might die of a heart attack.

There are a lot of factors here to consider and those players that like complicated, rogue-like, turn based combat, games with a deep satisfying narrator, you can’t do much better.

To counterbalance the Gods of Random and difficulties, Steam has several Workshop mods.

Yes, I like it. Yes, I am scared of it. Yes, it is quite difficult. 

Yes, I fully recommend it.

This game thoroughly ate me for 30 hours. The turn-based gameplay loop is extremely compelling and the voiceover takes it to another level. However, the gameplay doesn't support itself for the ~50 hours is takes to complete on normal difficulty. The environments, while procedurally generated, don't contain enough variety and the game eventually became a tedious levelling grind. I'd recommend playing on easy b/c this will make the campaign shorter, which it really needs to be.

The gameplay is very fun, successful missions feel very gratifying, the narrarator and atmosphere are incredible, among a bunch of other things. Though what brings it down for me is the rng factor. You will hear people say that everyone overexaggerates the rng of the game, and that you just need some knowledge and skill. I highly disagree, this game is 50/50 skill and luck. A hero can die on their first deaths door check, you can go the entire game without seeing a virtue, an enemy can repeatedly crit your group, a group of enemies can spontaneously target a single hero, your attacks can miss, your status effects can be resisted, you can get hunger checked over and over again, the game can spawn more blockades than you should usually prepare for, your attacks can miss, you can have a character keep accumulating stress and damage from traps because you didnt get any scouts, your party can shuffle at an enemy encounter with max torch, your attacks can miss, etc, etc, etc. EVERYTHING in the game has an rng factor, you can use trinkets to lower that factor a bit (if you find them), but it will always be there. Its clear the developers intended for deaths to be a big part of the game, and its hard for me to say if that was the right move? Losing somebody is frustrating no matter what, and it can and will lead to quit moments. For me, the game has become more stressful than fun, so whats the point of playing? 

If you can handle these rng factors, I very much recommend the game, but losing heroes is incredibly frustrating, and it will happen. Its extremely hard to play through this game without feeling like it was a massive waste of time.

This game is incredible. I wish there were more like it out there. Though to be frank, it's not for everyone. 

It's been out a while so I'm not going to say anything that hasn't already been said. If you're wondering if you should get it, the answer is yes as long as a couple of things are true for you. 

- You don't mind the very real possibility of having an entire save file (sometimes dozens of hours) borked because you lost some of your best people on a late game dungeon run. 

- You find the idea of your units actively working against you (stealing loot, harming each other, refusing your directions) a really fun and innovative concept. 

- You love turn based combat and long term resource management so much that you don't mind if a game is those two things and basically nothing else. 

If all of that is true for you, you'll love this game. If you're not sure, try it anyways. This game is worth your time, even if it will make you want to put your head through a wall sometimes. 

Side note - the soundtrack is probably one of the best soundtracks ever made.

UPDATE 1: A year later I still find a liking to the game. For those who have surpassed themselves even with New Game +, I suggest trying out the Pitch Black Dungeon mod in the Steam Workshop. The mod makes changes to heroes/monsters/events/items/curios/dungeons, for those seeking even a grater challenge. It's compatible with skins and even additional class mods. It was a breath of fresh air and I felt desperation like I did the first time I tried it. As a community item, it went beyond my expectations.

Update 2:
I have all 100% achivements of the game and I am still coming back to play it. Below is my oh-so-nice-summer-child review (back in winter 2016) when I first beat it. Makes me nostalgic. It is January 2024 now.

After my 100th hour, I have finally put an end to the Darkest Dungeon.

As the leper says, a tide rises and a tide falls - I made triumph and I faced defeat, with the latter being the most common. I have forsaken favourite heroes, lost valuable trinkets and relics at the cost of gold and progress. In the end, I found out that I was at a stalemate. "This isn't fair." I said that to myself multiple times, yet I continued to struggle. The feeling of accomplishment drove me. The feeling of success over such a huge crowd of people like me. I didn't give up, despite the stressful and desperate times. And now, I hold the spoils of victory. At what cost...?

Hats off to the developers. At first I saw the game as everyone else sees it - a game. I ignored the story - thought it was some universe where monsters just exist - came out of nowhere, being a trivial thing. On the contrary,  with the journals found and the bosses slain, I find out that the reason for these abominations' existance isn't a given. Someone is behind all of this, and the reason for all of these horrors. 

Of course, people are and will be complaining about the RNG or grinding of it but the game is meant to be like that. I haven't seen a game so punishing and unfair before. But here I am, unscathed, actually pretty broken after the final quests, but at least the game teaches you not to falter in front of difficult challenges and situations. You will lose, of course, multiple times at that. But the trick is to keep on trying. And take note from this game and apply it in life.(cliche but a reality)

A note: the devs are working on a comic series about the characters' backstory. So far my favourite one is about the Crusader. You can check them out at the Darkest Dungeon Wiki.

UPDATE: A year later I still find a liking to the game. For those who have surpassed themselves even with New Game +, I suggest trying out the Pitch Black Dungeon mod in the Steam Workshop. The mod makes changes to heroes/monsters/events/items/curios/dungeons, for those seeking even a grater challenge. It's compatible with skins and even additional class mods. It was a breath of fresh air and I felt desperation like I did the first time I tried it. As a community item, it went beyond my expectations.

Do NOT be dissuaded by all the talk making this game out to be some epitome of difficulty. It's not.

Darkest Dungeon's difficulty curve lies within learning the game and its RNG. Both of these are also what keeps the game fresh and exciting. It's not a mechanically hard game, and frankly could use a bit more depth in some of its parts. As it is, all it asks from you is to learn through playing it, and then think about your decisions in the future. In all honesty, this isn't that hard to do. Sure, RNG can always screw you over, but with the right mindset and preparation, you can play around it most of the time, so it's not like your knowledge and strategy are out the window thanks to a roll of the dice. 

Demanding? Sure. "Hardest game ever?" Not by a long shot.

Other aspects of the game include the artstyle, which alone is enough to pique interest. That's not to say that what lies underneath isn't up to par. The story and theme of the game are cryptic, told through stylized cutscenes and by an excellent narrator, whose voice makes you shiver to the bone. As I said, the gameplay could use a bit more depth to it, but it's tactical enough to keep you engaged and requires you to think about your next move. There's 15 hero classes, each of them having 7 abilities, 4 of which can be used at a time. They do a decent job of preventing the game from getting stale in its grindier parts and encourage experimentation, though I'd lie if I said that I never just wanted to be over with a dungeon already. Customization, from a purely aesthetical standpoint,  is what I consider the game's biggest missed opportunity, as it's almost non-existent. Other than selecting one of the 4 premade colour palettes for each hero class and changing their name, there's nothing you can do. Not even their armour changes in appearance as you upgrade it, which is a damn shame.

Going through my most played games on Steam, one thing is certain: I'm not the type of person that gets hung up on individual games for too long. I'll play a game, beat it, and despite having the time of my life, wont touch it for another year or two, until the time is right to replay it. It's been years since a game has gripped me so much that I just couldn't put it down, even resorting to multiple playthroughs if necessary. The last time that happened was when I played Mass Effect 2 for the first time, back in 2011. And although my infatuation with that game has long since waned, here I am in 2018, playing my heart out with Darkest Dungeon.

The standout feature of this game is undeniably its combat system. Boasting a rich array of classes, skills, and trinkets, there is tons of freedom to craft diverse party compositions, in a distinctive turn-based combat framework unique to Darkest Dungeon. Not to mention the atmospheric depth, complemented by the stellar voice acting for the narrator, it pulled me in so hard that I was utterly engrossed, almost to an excessive degree.

The difficulty of this game is hard... even unfair sometimes. As many have said before, RNG is a huge factor in this game that can absolutely make or break your runs. But If you keep playing you'll eventually learn all the mechanics and it begins to get a lot "easier" as you can use your knowledge to effectively remove the RNG or sway it heavily in your favour. People seem to overshadow that RNG can be beneficial to the player too!

However, a significant drawback is that [b] THIS GAME DOES NOT RESPECT YOUR TIME.[/b]
I heavily advise you to consider installing quality-of-life mods to streamline the experience and reclaim valuable hours. I simply did not have the patience to fight the same boss three times and to endure sluggish walking speeds and such long battle animations. I suggest exploring mods like "Even Faster Walking", "Dark Dunge" and "x2 Combat Speed" if you're interested in a non-vanilla experience.

This is a very difficult game.. both to master and to review. If you enjoy getting your ass handed to you every once in a while and feel like most games today coddle you too much, here you go.

One piece of advice towards enjoying this game I'd say is to leave behind the Vestal and Jester, at least for the most part. Those are crutch characters that somewhat subvert the game's systems. 

So how do you heal without a Vestal? Easy:
1) Learn to use the small heals many characters have, like Musketeer and Flagellant. Even Antiquarian can help.
2) Learn to use self heals, like Leper and Abomination.
3) Always be stunning. Create time to heal in battle by stunning and debuffing enemies. Every fight you should take 1-2 turns to recover.
4) Learn which enemies you can bully by debuffing and dragging the fight out so you can recover.
5) Make the most of your camping time. Bring plenty of food so you can have a feast. Select camping abilities carefully.
6) Food can help heal between battles, but use sparingly, mainly to keep people off of death's door (DD).
7) Speaking of DD, if you are in a tough fight and constantly low HP, just get off of DD, don't bother healing properly.
8) It's okay to be at low health sometimes. You are healed between missions, go ahead and finish on DD.

Managing stress:
1) Crusader and Houndmaster are great for stress healing during battle.
2) Mainly stress heal at camp. Stress is more important to heal than HP if you have to choose.
3) Build Crit items over raw damage. In 90% of cases Crit is better, partially due to the stress heal. It really adds up.
4) Build Dodge items over raw protection. In 90% of cases, Dodge is better, partially due to avoiding incoming stress.
5) Bring lots of torches, keep it on full light at all times. Don't light a new torch too early, or before camp.

Darkest Dungeon is no doubt a well-polished game: beautiful art, mesmerising voice-over, cohesive lore and world-building, aptly presented Lovecraftian setting, interesting turn-based combat with lots of strategic depth (see this article from Rock Paper Shotgun for more about its mechanic: https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/how-darkest-dungeon-found-new-horror-through-its-turn-based-combat). It has countless contents and replayability, and has Steam Workshop supports.

On the other hand, criticism of its difficulty and grindy nature is not unwarranted. However, if you are not afraid of stressful resource management or unforgiving combats with heavy RNG factors and permadeath, then Darkest Dungeon is definitely a treat for you.

[i]"A moment of valor shines brightest against a backdrop of despair."[/i]

As a disclaimer, I played this with and without mods over the years, so this isn't a pure opinion and I'll focus on what is consistent with the standard content.

The gameplay loop is set between managing the health and sanity of your teams and fighting a host of very angry cunts for every inch of progress, gold, items and literally anything you have space to take. The game is somewhat a rarity in that it doesn't give pardons for failure: heroes' deaths are (essentially) permanent, recovery is both slim and costly, and enemies are given no small amount of advantages that will overcome your own. Top that off with a brutal RNG that may see you fail no matter your strategy, and you've got a pretty intense cycle.

Don't be discouraged by DD1's many frustrating elements: experiencing loss and anger and despair are intrinsic elements of the game. You can never fully lose, save for on the highest difficulty, but winning will always cost you. And that's not to excuse any conniptions you may rightfully have about it; I myself resent how tediously dull it gets fighting the same enemies in the same backdrops with the same heroes. Alas, the power of mods does address this readily.

Not much storywise, as the core of the entire plot is directly shown in the opening cutscene. But every little lorebit you do scrounge about the game does give context to the 'Why' of it. Spoilers: [spoiler]the Ancestor is a fucking prick[/spoiler]


Anyway, it's a great game overall, even if you don't have the stomach to finish it-- I myself did it on the most forgiving difficulty, and it still took some 60 hours thereabout. I recommend it if you can get it on sale, or to anyone who's prone to cosmic horror and gambling people's lives like pennies.

This is one of my favorite games. 
The gameplay is awesome - there's enough complexity to make the tactical and sometimes strategical decisions interesting for a long time. 
The lovecraftian grim atmosphere is great. Every part of the game supports it. The great music, the art, the narration and voice acting, and the gameplay where it's often optimal to use and then dismiss heroes, leaving them insane, battered and broken. 

I have a few serious issues with the game though. On easy and normal difficulty, the game heavily incentivizes you to play in a boring, slow way. It's safer to take many easier missions with lower rewards, but also lower risk of losing your heroes. This way, the game becomes a grinding slog. After playing for a long time, I've completely solved this problem by switching to only playing on Stygian - the hardest difficulty. It introduces the time limit. You don't finish the game in a limited amount of missions - your save file is done, you've lost. The whole campaign. This forces you to actually play in a fun way, forces you to take interesting risks - now you can't optimize the fun out of the game. 

But this "fix" of mine only works once you've learned the game and are so good at it that you can actually finish it on Stygian. Which I don't really think is a good experience for a first playthrough. 

So, this game is just too grindy.

Another problem I have with this game is the recycled bosses. You fight each boss three times, and it just kinda feels too long. 

These issues don't ruin the game for me, and I still love it very much. Almost all aspects of it are super polished, and this is really rare

I actually stopped playing this for a while because I was irritated with how they handle mods. That's really my biggest complaint about the game. The mods need to be in a certain load order or they won't load/behave properly. Thankfully, the game has been out long enough that there's guides explaining how to set a good load order (which I used). So aside from that, it's an awesome game. I love the fact that you can select your party members before you go on a quest. I love the turn-based style of game (I play A LOT of turn-based games). I also love that there's an element of tactical gameplay (I also play A LOT of tactical games). Another BIG plus for me was the fact that it has mods. I think having mods makes the game 1000x better. There's nothing wrong with the pre-made, built-in classes and whatnot, but it just adds a whole new level to the game when I can add a new class or new element to the game that makes it even more awesome. The story/plot is thorough and immersive. There's no set way to play the game. Just sit down, get a couple (or more than a couple) different classes to play with and run through the dungeons, caves, ruins, etc. You'll have fun. Trust me.

This game is one of the 15 or so in my favourite games. It probably shouldn't be as I haven't played it a lot. I haven't played it more on purpose... When I first started playing the game seemed pretty tame. I was thinking, this whole psychological horror thing is kind of lame, it's just a game...

Until it wasn't... One particular stretch was incredibly frustrating. You'd think a frustrating game would be a bad game, but in this case it drove home the theme.

I want to pick this up again, but it really does mess with your mind. It's fun, rewarding, and frustrating all at the same time. It's in my favourites, but it's going to be awhile before I play again as I tend to play games to relieve stress, not cause it.

I love this game dearly. It is easily one of my favorite games of all time. I have it on my PS5 (of which I have 80+ hours in the game) and now I got it on steam as well. I love the Lovecraftian elements strewn throughout the art style, dialogue, and environments--all of which was obviously done with immense care by those at Red Hook. The creative direction of the game is like none other; I've never enjoyed staring at 2D characters as much as in this game! I enjoy just about every aspect of the game except on occasion when the RNG seems really opposed to me. But most of all, what keeps me always returning to the game, apart from the Lovecraftian elements, is how much fun the Highwayman is, and how amazing the character Leper is (lore wise, not necessarily gameplay wise).

I don't get how even with extremely high dodge stats (like 50-60 plus other trinkets), my heroes still get hit by enemies. Meanwhile the enemy with 5-6 dodge manages to not get hit multiple times. The enemies always popping crits despite my torch level being always "Radiant", meanwhile my heroes rarely crit even when they have the right trinkets and buffs.

I know the game was designed to be hard and unfair, but this is still a load of bullshit.

Its a very fun turn-based roguelite. I understand people's gripes with its high rng based design yet I feel like it is mostly fair. However unlike other turn-based games the punishment for misplays is not at all forgiving as losing characters can set you back hours of gameplay. However to mitigate this the game does give you many chances to abandon quests if you feel like you may lose a hero.

Fun game — addicting — old school D&D style game with a Lovecraft twist. Constantly kicks you in the nuts even on lower levels of difficulty, just keeping your head above water is a huge challenge — no such thing as a "Best Party" for example — and if you go in blind and just kind of experiment with things, you will find horrors that party wipe you even with relatively higher-tier heroes compared to a mission's difficulty level. For example, I had a 4th level bounty hunter, a 5th level paladin, a 4th level houndmaster, and a 3rd level occultist fully upgraded and kitted out on a "veteran" (3rd level average) mission. I put a torch in a weird alter and accidentally summoned an eldrich horror. Party wipe! Anyway that part sucks, but the game is challenging and I feel like I'll probably be able to beat it without throwing the laptop out of the window.

Aside from Final Fantasy Tactics (which was the first great strategy game I'd ever played), this is the greatest strategy game I've ever played. The experience can feel a bit monotonous in the sense that Darkest Dungeon is 99.9% strategy & 0.1% story, but the challenge of mastering each character & combining them into increasingly effective teams felt like healthy crack for my chess brain. (As a specific example: It took 300 hours of experimenting before I discovered my favorite team, a configuration of characters that Red Hook had already thought to call, "Persephone and Cerberus.") Darkest Dungeon is definitely not most people's idea of a good time, especially if they are impatient or easily flustered, but I've enjoyed the hell out of its headaches & I doubt I've ever played a game that felt more-loved or more carefully considered by its creators.

Darkest Dungeon is simply amazing.  Loosely interconnected story and lore, dangerous exploration, deadly combat, resource management, simple character design, it's as close to a classic D&D style RPG campaign for a video game as you'll get. Most video games, or games in general, there's always a sense that you can "win" or at least they're designed for the players to "win".  Not the Darkest Dungeon. It has an Old School Renaissance (OSR) philosophy in that there are definitely fights you can't win and some that even if you could win most of the time, today is not your day and you're not going to survive.

I discovered Darkest Dungeon after playing Shadowdark RPG and they're remarkably similar, despite being created independently by two groups of people who couldn't be more different.  It speaks to the need for a style of gaming that has been lost and forgotten but is sorely needed.  With both of these games there is very limited "gear slots" and often you'll have to leave loot behind, just drop it on the ground and run back to the safety of your Hamlet.

If you enjoy extreme, grinding challenges; if you can handle watching your favorite heroes die instantly (I was surprised when my favorite Hellion "Griffin" came back to life and she helped me win the game); and if you want to explore forsaken places where all hope is long gone, play Darkest Dungeon.

Now that I have completed this game, I can thoroughly describe my 161-hour-long game play. First of all, it is undeniably a stress-inducing game. I purchased it in 2019 and I believe that it wouldn't be too challenging. Oh, how naive I was.

In terms of game play, it aligns with what one would expect from any turn-based game. You attack the enemy, and they counterattack, basic stuff. What sets this game apart is the need to pay attention to the mechanics like DODGE, ACC, SPD, etc. While some criticize the RNG aspect, I disagree. Most defeats result from my own greed rather than unfair game mechanics. The fact that the game always remind you of that every time you open up the game.

The combat system isn't the only important aspect since there are numerous events unfold. Managing gold income, upgrading buildings, and overseeing your crew are also essential elements.

Beyond gameplay, the art style captivates me. The dark atmosphere and ominous feelings, coupled with the OST, create a fitting ambiance (unless you're using mods). And who could forget the narrator? I'd go so far as to say the narrator elevates the game at least tenfold. I've even memorized some of the iconic lines.

In conclusion, it's a challenging game. However, let that not be a deterrent from purchasing it. Give it a try, so I don't have to endure this experience alone.
