This is by far one of the greatest games I have ever played. This game has everything: fantastic turn-based combat, awesome characters, amazingly written story, and the atmosphere is unlike anything I have ever seen. The way the game progresses, team building, and exploration of the different dungeons hooks me into many hour long sessions every single time I even open the game. This game is so addictive to me and there are so many different kinds of runs that you can do that the game always feels fresh. Speaking of feeling fresh, there is no other game that I have felt as much of an emotional roller coaster while playing before. The way that your runs can suddenly take a dark twist at any time really makes everything pressure you into really trying to figure out what is the best possible move in any turn or at any time, even when making this move you are screaming at your screen. The more you play this game, the more lessons you learn, the more you learn about what is best and what enemies to focus down, and what trinkets to go fore. It is incredibly satisfying to do well in this game because of how much all odds feel to be against you at all times, as it is usually because you had chosen the best possible option for any scenario. Besides the gameplay, as I mentioned earlier, the atmosphere in this game is fantastic. Everything including the ambient noise, the music, and of course, the ancestor's narration, make this game's atmosphere just unlike any other game I have ever played. It truly put me at least, in the heroes' shoes. There are so many more things I could write about but you should really play it for yourself to find out what all I have talked about and what I want you to experience for yourself. Fantastic game.

Before I begin, this game is the best one I've ever played. So my review may be a bit biased by this. But because I like it, you may get to know why is it so great...
(pros and cons below)
If I should mention the technical side of things, I have nothing to complain about. The audio-visual side, along with the rouge-like medieval setting of the game, is so breathtaking to me that words cannot describe it. 
In terms of story and gameplay, the game is very RNG, recruiting and gradually upgrading heroes, along with new abilities and trinkets are very intuitive, but also quite grindy. Especially when they don't hit anything afterwards.  Of course, you'll love the heroes and their irreversible deaths will hit you pretty hard, as there's no respawn. 
If you're tired of just playing in dungeons, killing very difficult bosses and you've finished the game after a few dozen (or hundreds) of hours, there are DLCs wich do not cost much, all under 10$.

Pros:
+++absolutely beautiful graphics and audio
+++great heroes you'll fall in love with and hate at the same time
++you'll enjoy the fights and they'll be just as stressful after hundreds of hours
+challenge your friends in the "Butcher's Circus"
++You'll be jumping with excitement as you defeat the toughest bosses

Cons:
-all attacks and the entire game is based on chance and percentage chances that can be influenced, but at times the game feels completely random
- you will have played this game for hundreds of hours without finishing it :)

A classic and terrifically gruesome game!  Everything you do feels like it matters, which is purposely stressful, but totally thrilling.  It really makes you feel like you're there with your party in the Darkest Dungeon.

The game has a lot of grinding, and practically speaking, requires that you look at guides.  It doesn't do any of the heavy lifting that would make the game more understandable, and it becomes a weakness instead of a strength.

The mechanical theorycrafting, atmospheric soundtrack, and good storytelling still make it fun to get in there and get your hands dirty.  Even with the guides, there's a lot to analyze.  Great modding scene, too.

I have tried really hard to get into this game multiple times. but honestly now after this latest attempt I'm fed up. i love the style of the game and i love a good challenge it really drew me in with the brutality and the idea of stress and quirks but the pacing is so frustrating and unforgiving that i just find myself constantly restarting due to feeling like im doing something wrong and trashing my campaign. I have looked at guides and tips and tried different things but honestly this game is stupidly unbalanced to the point where overcoming it feels more like a chore than a challenge of skill and strategy.

in the very beginning you are already onslaught-ed by stress enemies with high dodge so you cant get out of the fight with out one or more characters getting at LEAST close to 100 stress, and this is at the second or third dungeon. I haven't even unlocked the blacksmith or guild yet in some cases let alone use them. after nearly every dungeon i have to send the whole party into recovery for multiple things. literally after the second dungeon one of my characters negative traits, which they got IN THAT DUNGEON already became re-enforced with the skull just so it could give me the tutorial. this was on radiant.

its not that I'm terribly upset with rng really. I do think that could use a little tweaking but this is more a matter of pacing difficulty and allowing the player to even begin enjoying the game before they feel they need to watch hours of guides and restart multiple times. its sad as i think if it were just a tad different I would love this game but honestly at this point I just ask myself why frustrate myself trying to play this when I could play something else.

Ok, so first of all this is a negative review but not by a lot.
This game is about a 4-6 on a scale of 1-10 for me, with it leaning towards the 4 after about 70 hours of playtime, but the first 40 hours or so were leaning more towards a 6.

Positive- Great voice acting from the main narrator, also about the only voice acting in the game.
Original concept with a fresh take on the turn based battle format by adding in a "stress" factor that can really steamroll your party if left unchecked. 
Originality is the main attribute for this game, it does not have wizards, warriors, rogues and elves.
It has Crusaders,Antiquarians,Bounty Hunters, Occultists, and many more.
While some of these might be similar to the classical tropes (Crusader=warrior) they all have fairly unique abilities and mechanics, mostly based on various buffs and de-buffs. 
So while the dot effects like Blight and Bleeding have been done before I think that the combination of them and how they are used is very original and if you want an original game in this genre this will definitely scratch that itch.

Negative- Where the game failed for me is in the RNG roguelike mechanics. 
So RNG is to be expected in a roguelike, the very game itself states that heroes will die and it is a game about adversity and recovering in the face of unfairness. 
I feel though that the game very much overdoes the adversity. After a few times of having my champion level party wiped out I have just decided that the grind is not going to be worth the reward, especially since even at max buffs and gear the party can still be completely wiped out due to a battle going wrong due to the RNG.
I definitely could finish the game and play it some more but I am just not willing to level up another group at this point.
Once you hit the red dungeons the tide turns well against you. While I could make easy runs with orange and green with my buffs, the red dungeons are basically just a roll of the dice at this point and it is not due to a skill or learning curve but only to the fact that there are so many things that can go wrong in a single battle.
So while it has its moments and has a unique system, the rng is just way too punishing once you hit red and above no matter how well you know the game.
So I am going to go against the grain on this and give it a no, not recommended. 
Too long of a grind and the roguelike element means basically starting over again and again with a few slight buffs like being able to draft lvl 2 heroes, but it does not make up for the tediousness of starting over again and again and again.

I am also basing this review on the base game, I have not used or purchased any of the Add-ons and never review a game based on add ons. If the game is not good in its base state then it is not good, nobody should be required to purchase an add on in order to make the game playable. I love roguelikes and cannot recall a single one where I pointed out bad rng as a factor, having random bad events can be expected and even game ending ones, but this game makes bad rng front and center intentionally so maybe this will be something certain people like, I am just not one of them.

This is my first review on Steam and the fact I chose this game in particular should already tell you a lot.

Short version: I adore this game

Long version: The visuals and gameplay are simply phenomenal. Red Hook has done a fantastic job to bring the turn-based RPG genre into relevancy with its own flavour. Now for the big points, the stress system. It may be one of the first games to introduce such a system (it's at least the first one for me) and it's very immersive (albeit a bit bullshit at times). It's a very simple game with simple mechanics but that makes the depth and experiments you can do so much more accessible and enjoyable, every stats feel like it matters and easy to understand.

I will warn newcomers to the game however, this game is not easy and will punish you if you are overconfident or unprepared. Get used to things not going your way, it's all about decisions in the action, the game is not going to hold your hand.

But once you get used to the loop, the mechanics and understand what's going, what to do, it is a great experience every time for me. And that's not even mentioning this game has Steam workshop compatibility which means the possibilities to spice and change your experience are endless. Absolutely recommend for anyone interested.

As for the DLC's, I would not recommend them right off the bat, get them if it's on sale but I would not recommend you to use them at all in your first hours.

Punishing but fair, this roguelike turn-based RPG has a visual style second to none. Risk your sanity, you won't be sorry you did.

(skip to the end, I accidentally scrapped a revised review but didn't feel like getting rid of the old one I wrote because it's still pretty relevant)

[strike] Neat game, but it isn't really a roguelike/roguelite.

It's pretty much an RPG really.

There's roguelike-ish elements in that you can take risks discovering stuff in the dungeons, you can build a party with a bunch of different classes (there's legit like 16 of them), different accessories for the classes, a currency you use to upgrade a "base" (meta progression in the estate itself), risk vs reward with the light/dark mechanic, etc.

But I don't really qualify it as a roguelike. There are no runs and every quest you go on WILL have an affect on your next one. Whether it be a character getting stressed out and needing to unwind back at the estate, having a party die in a dungeon and losing all them AND their equipment, getting a negative quirk, etc.

Honestly, I love this game's aesthetics and battle systems, but oh my god does management of the estate and the long-term consequences of runs suck. I honestly love the idea, but it makes bad RNG and experimentation so much more punishing.

The fun of roguelikes is being able to fail a run due to your mistakes, yet being able to come out of it stronger for the next run because you learned something new from your past mistakes. Here it feels like you have all the downsides of a loss in any other roguelike and MORE without any of the plus sides of it (okay fine, maybe you'll learn/discover a new thing or two in a run, but it may not be enough to leave you wanting more). 

This game is waaaaay too punishing. Some of you may like it, but believe me when I say, that if you don't have much time on your hands, this game will do nothing but make you want to tear your hair out.

Honestly, if you like something like X-com and want something like that, but the characters can go insane, the combat is turn-based and on a way smaller grid, and you personally don't care if a game repeatedly kicks you when you're down and occasionally spits on you while it's at it, I think you'll definitely enjoy this game.

Everyone else though, proceed with risk. They murdered some of my favorite characters in the blink of an eye and left one party member live to tell the tale. On one hand, it wasn't like it was a scripted event, it WAS partially my fault, as I could've just left the dungeon to escape with them (even if it would've given them more stress/I would've missed out on some rewards), but dang it they all died in like one turn...

NOTE: Traits and quirks are fun, as having a character's only way to relieve stress be time in a brothel, only to then develop "deviant tastes" banning them from said brothels is hilarious. If I end up losing that character I'm uninstalling this game and never playing it again (i removed the quirk limiting them to brothels but left their "deviant tastes" just because I find it funny), though, I'm sure the devs probably know that and are probably dying laughing at the fact that the game is as punishing as it is. I just wish managing party members wasn't so tedious, though, I've heard that they've changed the second game to be MORE like a roguelike, so I can't wait to check that out some day.

I hope some day I'll come back to this review and change it into a recommendation, but for now, as someone with not as much time as they used to have to just themselves and with games that I generally just find to be more fun, I'll just leave this as a "don't recommend" for anyone who has heard this game is great, but not enough of the people telling them that this game is actually pretty grindy and not that much like a roguelike.

Feel free to tell me to go die in the comments though. I'd love to learn how to have more fun with this game and hate it when I see others having fun with something but feel like I can't enjoy as much myself.[/strike]

Just like this game, steam made me wanna kill myself when I was editing this review (I changed a lot in my revisions, as seen by how this review is now positive despite all my grievances with the game) and then accidentally hit "cancel" instead of "save changes" because I was in a rush. I'm not going back and fixing shit, so y'all can just have fun figuring out the fun shit for yourselves. Just know that I recommend playing on radiant mode (your heroes level faster in this mode while being less punishing in regards to how many people you can have die and farming gold), and using mods to speed up animations, walk speed, and stuff in game after you've grown tired of watching the slow battle animations (for me this was like 10 hours in).

Darkest Dungeon é a relação abusiva dos jogos - é um relacionamento tóxico que você não consegue abandonar.

Embora dungeon crawlers baseados em turnos não sejam novidade, Darkest Dungeon consegue ser único nesse aspecto, por conta de sua brutalidade. Mesmo na dificuldade mais baixa, o jogo não deixa de ser brutal, punindo erros e despreparo (e mesmo com o preparo ideal, nada é garantido por conta do RNG). Logo, a experiência geral para iniciantes (e até para veteranos) é perder seu preferido grupo inteiro por conta de um mero descuído e abandonar a run.

Mas mesmo com essas frustrações (e muitas runs abandonadas), sempre me vi voltando ao jogo denovo e denovo.

Darkest Dungeon is unlike most of the games you will encounter if you're an avid gamer such as myself. The gothic setting of the game is really unique and makes you wanna play more and more. The band of soldiers you have are all unique in some way, and all of their skills can be utilized one way or another in combat. It is a really well made turn-based game with a good amount of dice rolls that either go in your or opponents favor, but I'd say that tactics are still the most important. Losing well developed heroes in combat hurts like a bitch, but it makes you sure that you don't repeat the same mistakes as before. The feeling of well placed hit and carefully thought out boss runs makes this for a satisfying experience once you manage to pull out a victory. Try to slowplay your dungeon runs as it's better to analize what you do before you do it. 
The game, such as it is, require a solid amount of knowledge, and what I do is that I keep myself informed through official Wiki page about anything you can possibly need; from curios, dungeons, tactics, bosses etc.I bought the Ancestral edition just to experience the game in its entirety, it really keeps you craving for more and more.

When it comes to turn-based games, Red Hook really captured the essence of a true dungeon crawler, making this game hard to dislike in any possible way.

[h1]Lovecraft would approve[/h1]
[b]The term 'Lovecraftian' gets bandied arouund a lot these days but this is one of the few that touches on the sheer essence of Lovecraftian Horror. This games will twist even the noblest mindset into a cold, calculating fiend.[/b]

The game is a Rogue-lit dungeon crawler with a rather basic set up. YOu recruit heroes, send them into dungeons on mission and hope they survive. The missions and layouts of the dungeons are more or less randomized as are their contents. Death is permanent. And that will be counted as a mercy.

The unique mechanic of this game is the Stress (not sanity) meter, the afflictions/virtues, and quirks. Mental health is just as important as physical health and as your heroes areexposed to the terrible eldrich horros and abominations that make mockery of flesh and form, they will slowly but surely go insane.  Once a hero takes a certain amount of stress damage they will become afflicted by varuiouus conditions. This can have varying effects from causing erratic statuses, actions, and in somecases causing them to attack other heroes.

After missions your heroes will develop quirks. Some beneficial that ad bonuses, but most will be negative that make heroes weaker. The more missions a hero goes on the more experience and levels they gains but also the more of these quirks they pick up.  Stress and  these quirks can be treated of course, for a hefty fee.

Tough choices will have to be made.

One of the best things is that the devs do regullarly return to add new content. Teh most recent being the Butcher CIrcus which adds PVP. 

[h1]The Good[/h1]
[list]
[*] Unique artstyle befiting a graphic novel, or motion comic.
[*] Challenging gameplay base less around mastery and more about making the best of horrible situations.
[*] Satisfyingly strategic Combat
[*] Atmospheric Dread, and despair reinforced by the mechanics.
[*] An active and talented Mod community along with a load of interesting workshop content to spice up your game.
[*] Devs still tweaking and adding stuuff.
[/list]

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
[list]
[*] Gameplay can feel repetitive after a while.
[*] Game can be ruthlessly unfair at times.
[/list]

[h1]The Horror...[/h1]
[list]
[*] The narration is Elder God-tier

[/list]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
The game is solid, well made and while not perfect will scratch that Lovecraft itch perfectly. Its a shining example of what happens when the Aesthetics, The Narrattive,  and Mechanics of a game all work to enhance and reinforce the over arching Themes. The world of the game feels more alive than many Open world slogs out there and I highly recommend this. Even if you're not a lovecraft fan, even if you're not a horro fan, this game will likely have something tto keep you coming back.

You will arrive along the old road. It winds with a troubling, serpent-like suggestion through the corrupted countryside. Leading only, I fear, to ever more tenebrous places. There is a sickness in the ancient pitted cobbles of the old road and on its writhing path you will face viciousness, violence, and perhaps other damnably transcendent terrors. So steel yourself and remember: there can be no bravery without madness. The old road will take you to hell, but in that gaping abyss we will find our redemption.

Additionally, it feels a bit grindy. All the dungeons have a pretty similar feel to them. And finally, the trinket management dance you have to do before each dungeon really grinded my gears.

I consider myself a calm and patient person. I have never opened the task manager and forcibly closed a game out of pure spite and annoyance until today.
There's a lot to like about this game: the graphics, the sound design, the satisfying gameplay loop. There's also a lot to dislike, most of which comes down to the RNG. I know this isn't a new complaint about DD by any means, but I really thought it wouldn't bother me, since I've played a lot of tactical turn-based games and roguelikes. Oh, past self, how naive you were.
The best incident to sum this whole thing up: on the easiest difficulty setting, in two not particularly challenging dungeons, I lost two grave robbers to bad RNG, back-to-back. Losing a unit in DD means losing hours of grinding and fine-tuning, not to mention the gold you've spent training that unit up. In the end it just feels like a waste of time. I understand that DD is meant to be challenging and stressful, but at a certain point it no longer seems worth the time and effort. 
I respect the game for what it is and I appreciate that my friends really love it, but I'm not going to recommend it to anyone. I'd rather spend my time on something based more on skill than random chance.

Darkest Dungeon is a hard as balls game that rewards your efforts with pain and misery.
I love hard challenges.

I see that this game is presently on sale for $4.99 through November 28th. I figured I would give an opportunistic 2 cents on this game for anyone considering purchasing it and say that this game has a punishing sort of learning curve but is one of the most enjoyable blind experiences I've had in the past 30 years and, thanks to a creative modding community, has a wealth of replay value.

The only games that come to mind for what it could be compared to are perhaps the Spire and Lobotomy Corporation, but Darkest Dungeon is still very much its own unique experience. I highly recommend this game, especially at the current price, for anyone who is looking for a memorable experience. I can think of no finer way of closing out a long day at work than by coming home and playing this game - it's like Ambien for the soul.

I bought it and it took me like 8 months to finally try it lol.

But when i did, it took me by surprise how visually stunning this game is. The lore, music and gameplay dont fall behind too, as someone already said in another comment, the first message that shows when u play is that u have to make the most of adverse situations, and i can assure u that those situations appear a lot. But honestly, thats something that makes this game a lot better, the feeling that your decisions really matter, when u have to choose if u want to take the chance of getting amazing loot with the risk of getting ur party wiped out.

I love the battle mechanics, the bosses look amazing and their battles encourage the player to learn their mechanics (stupid Wilbur lol) and think about the right party composition. Sometimes u get the enemies surprised and get a full wipe without getting any damage or sometimes u get ur party surprised and struggle to not get everyone dead or afflicted. The Stress mechanic sometimes is very hard to manage but it is possible, even in high difficulty dungeons, which btw are also amazing, every one of them with different types of enemies, which also have different types of mechanics and resistances that reward the player for building a good team for them.

Anyways, the game is amazing, and im glad that i buyed, bcs i have a lot of fun playing it and now i know very well that overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer.

After playing Darkest Dungeon for a few hours, I think it is  time for me to gather my thoughts into a “review”, like the sassy person that I am. Born from the minds of passionate people at Red Hook Studio and after going through a long development as well as an early access, which nobody has ever had gripes with in the past, Darkest Dungeon was finally released on January 2016. A 2D turn-based dark fantastic RPG which received lots of love and hate, renowned for its crushing difficulty, grim “lovecraftian” atmosphere, incredibly art style and otherwordly narrator. 

Your journey begins with two characters, a crusader and a highwayman who, after a carriage crash must make their way to the hamlet, home to tragedy and despair causrd by the Ancestor, which have inherited and must now try to salvage. From the get go the game will expose you to its combat system which, as the turn based etiquette suggests, consists of waiting for your turn to make a decision while your enemy patiently awaits that you make your mind. The same applies to you thereafter, and bis repetita. 

Although fairly simple to understand, Darkest Dungeon’s combat will take determination to conquer. Not because of the somewhat questionnable amount of damage which you can be dealt. Although you could think that. But because of all the random situations which you will have to struggle through. Welcome to the land of RNG where you will beg for mercy each time a character moves a toe into that stealthy spike trap you couldn’t disarm. 

The game mostly consists of themed dungeons where you explore long corridors filled, or not, with treasures traps and encounters, and rooms which can contain your quests’ goal as well as your downfall, or sometimes both. Your characters will have to be balanced in order to have the odds of survival. What I mean by that is that you will imperatively need to have a strategy in mind when putting together a team, unless your intention is to throw blood bags at your opponent and angrily stare them to death. Most of the time, your team can consist of a block of stone to serve as a target, one or two pesky dodgers which deal most of the damage, and a buffer or a healer, the latter being a better choice to be honest. Considering you have probably bought all the DLCs there are seventeen classes which you can choose from, if they happen to come by the hamlet. Each classes will have their own unique appearance and perks which gives them a very unique role. Their quality traits and afflictions which you can modify latter, as well as camping skills which are to be used inside the dungeon when your heroes need to rest, must be managed as to get the best out of everyone during every expedition. 

The combat itself, the basic punching and shooting executed by your meat sacks, centres around six stats which can vary depending on the class of your characters: Accuracy; Speed; Dodge; Damage; Protection and Critical Chance. I think most of these mechanics speak for themselves, damage does more damage, dodge dodges harder, and critical flips you over. What you must keep in mind is that all of these parameters are available for the enemy as well, meaning you can get a decent idea of how bad the situation can become when you will encounter a giant centaur crab which can tank 80% of the damage like a titanium sponge. 

The main mechanics you will have to take care of, aside from the obvious team composition and perk choice, are the inventory and stress mechanics. The inventory basically consists of your group's furniture’s which can help them survive in the dungeon, as well as the space available for treasures and trinkets. But the signature mechanic from Darkest Dungeon, which most people will certainly remember about, is the stress inflicted both on your character and yourself. Providing lots of insanity and loss of will to live when your best characters die from a heart attack. Simply put, each time a character gets hurt, interacts with a bad object, sees another member of the team getting hurt, or even simply walks down the corridor of life, will suffer from a certain amount of stress. Once the “stress” gauge is filled to one hundred, the character's resolve will be tested. And much like in real life, it hurts way more than you think. Your character gets a roll where they either suffer from an affliction or a blessing. But don’t count too much on the blessings being a thing as they tend to be extremely rare. Instead, pray for RNGesus to be kind enough not to put the worst afflictions on your characters when they get one, which means that they most of the time will get angry or depressed and are going to be less reliable as your adventure lingers. But don’t you think it ends here you silly brat, the metre hasn’t reached its maximum amount yet! When you get to an amount of two hundred your character will get a heart attack, which will drop their health to zero, leaving them very vulnerable. 

If you’ve made it past all the hurdles and succeeded in completing your quest, which will most of the time be exploration, fetch quest or kill the meany of the dungeon, congratulations, you made it back to the hamlet! Your characters will get some experience and crumble under newly acquired afflictions and/or positive traits. The hamlet itself serves as your headquarters, where you get to hire new heroes, treat the mental breakdown of your recently depressed employees and train them as well. All of these charming activities will of course come at a price, which you will have to comply with, until your exploration grants you enough trinkets to trade for lower inflation. Once you are finished dealing with that, do the dungeon bit a thousand times more in the various areas available and you can access the final dungeon. A realm best described as the pinnacle of “suck it” in enjoyment, with stupidly punishing outcomes if you come under-prepared, or an underwhelming experience if you’ve prepared a bit too much. 

Is the game hard? Yes, in many ways. Is it frustrating? I have to admit it got me on the verge of a mental breakdown a few times when it kept giving my enemies crit damage, and my heroes were all trying to kill themselves during the fight. But you have to understand that the, at times, almost unfair challenge is a big part of the appeal of Darkest Dungeon. It falls under the group of games which are fairly simple but also nebulous at times, and which will not hold your hand and choose to slap you instead. You can get very strategic about your playthrough and conquer the combat system, but it will take time and tears, and won’t make you invulnerable to a bad roll. 

Although I have not taken the time to mention, the art direction, music and sound design are all gorgeous and rub a sweet spot of mine. So much so that I would often come back to the game on a weekly basis just for the satisfaction of hearing those slashing, crushing, sounds or to look at my characters getting PTSD. Darkest Dungeon is a rough, painful and hopeless experience entirely worthy of your money, and whatever amount of time you are ready to invest into it. The community and Red Hook Studio have always made it a wonderful experience full of new content and kept it refreshing as far as today. And I’m sure this will keep going on and eventually repeat with Darkest Dungeon II: Mountain Edition.

[h1][b]Darkest Dungeon[/b][/h1]

[b]... the ultimate frustration tolerance challenge![/b]


[h1]The game in a nutshell[/h1]

Darkest Dungeon is a heavy, turn-based gothic role-playing game with roguelike elements, focusing on the psychological effects of adventuring. Recruit and train a group of heroes and lead them through gloomy forests, ancient caves, infested ruins and more. In doing so, you'll not only have to confront the worst enemies, but also deal with stress, hunger, plagues, the omnipresent darkness and, above all, important decisions on which your group´s survival depends.

[h1]Visual style, gameplay and mechanics[/h1]

- Unique, dark hand-drawn quill-style graphics
- Turn-based combat against a variety of disgusting monsters
- The agony system! Deal with stress, paranoia, phobias, masochism, anxiety, delusion and many other tics that affect the game
- Camp to heal wounds or use various skills of your party
- Level up buildings, weapons and armory
- Send your exhausted, war-neurotic characters to the village tavern or monastery to recover from the stress and strain... or to the sanatorium for mental and spiritual recuperation
- Classic features of role-playing games and roguelikes - including a permadeath, procedurally generated dungeons, and therefore incredibly high replay value


[h1]Negative aspects[/h1]

Some might say, that the difficulty level and the grind (esp. in the late game) is too high, even at the "easiest" level. But imho it is exactly how it´s supposed to be - a challenge at the highest level!

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

This is one of those games that you either love or abysmally hate. The pressure is high, you constantly have to make decisions between plague or cholera, your characters will suffer, go insane, get unrestrained drunk to forget the horrors of the last dungeon, droolingly enter a monastery, die in horrible pain and also contract syphilis without having sex. Darkest Dungeon is like your narcissistic ex-partner... and you are the one with the co-dependency - a relationship that you know is not good for you at all, yet the toxic attraction is so strong that you can't resist the temptation. Highly recommended for part-time sociopaths, masochists, or just anyone looking for a damn good, hard as hell and extremely demanding game to sink their teeth into.

I really wanted to like this game, but there were some real issues that I'm guessing they've just fixed in Darkest Dungeon II instead. 

First of all, your biggest enemy isn't really the the enemies in the game, but the fact that your units get stressed out of orbit for pretty much just entering the dungeon or talking to each other. The game should from start have a way better tutorial and functions on how to relieve stress. 

Second problem, if you think the Random Number Generator is bad in XCOM, then you're going to have a real blast with this one. I know it's supposed to be a bit of the game failing and winning at random, but some runs have just been a complete waste of time entirely because of the RNG in addition to being new to the game. 

I would recommend this game for people who're getting back-seated while playing and for those who like to do pretty much the same repetitive thing over and over again.

I played 60 hours. I played on the 'easiest' difficulty. I was drawn to this game by the very unique and beautiful art style, fantastic music, and great storytelling. I was aware this game has a reputation for being difficult. I even installed various mods to make it easier because I wanted a casual experience.

It wasn't too bad at first, but turns out the game gets 'more difficult' as you progress by turning up the terrible game mechanics to an 11. Enemies start dodging ALL of your attacks, oneshotting or two shotting your entire party with critical hits back to back, the enemy always out speeds you later in the game and always goes first. Traditional elements of strategy you may see in other turn based rpgs becomes less and less important as you progress.

It feels absolutely helpless and there's seriously no fun in throwing your highest level heroes at certain dungeons over and over again and having them all die. You spent 15 hours and went through 10 dungeons to level up a fresh party to go after a higher level dungeon? LOL here comes some terrible rng to throw away all of your efforts. Hard games are fun when they feel fair, and you feel rewarded for overcoming the challenge. There's none of that here. Only a smidgen of relief when you finally get lucky and don't get screwed over by unlucky 'randomness'.

Final straw for me was losing an entire party of max level heroes, to back to back crits from a basic mob enemy. The basic baddie put my entire team on 'deaths door' in one hit, the turn order reset and he immediately took another turn and proceeded to wipe my party.
Riposte beats every single boss in the game without fail. Just bring HwM :D

Edit: I beat the vanilla darkest dungeon on week 334. Since I'm not a completionist, I think that's a worthy achievement, 4 percent of players get "Victory such as it is..." on the Steam achievements. My resolve level 6 man at arms died twice - resurrected only to taste the bitter sting of death's embrace.

The ending left me feeling a bit unfulfilled. Not disappointed. It's like if I was eating at a buffet, and after every last crumb is swallowed, I'm not really full from it. Was I expecting something more grandiose for another rogue-like game, boasting a dark fantasy artstyle and setting? I'm going to touch on spoiler territory so here's that disclaimer. 

[u]Final thoughts[/u]

The game was enough to get a game completion, the lore was there and it had an interesting story to tell. DD is supposed to be a game that has high stakes and consequences. You suck up every failure and move on. I felt that at the end stretch the grind became the straw that broke the camel's back. Every delay made it hard to enjoy the game, and the end was just a "finally" to me instead of a gratifying "momentary abatement." I still don't want to give Red Hook the thumbs down, but I felt like the game's lore would have been better told as a comic book like Elric of Melnibone. I don't recommend this game for its stifled replayability value and mostly easy final boss (Vvulf was harder). 


[h1]End game analysis[/h1]
[spoiler]
The Darkest Dungeon quest is divided into several levels: clear each level and you will be able to challenge the final quest. The first one I recall gives you three darkest torches, trinkets that greatly reduce damage received on party members. It ended with a solo houndmaster dealing the last bit of damage, outmatched in a close call. Once the first stage is clear, you'll recognize that the party members you took who survived the encounter will have a torch next to their name. The torch means that this unit cannot be deployed into the next stage of the Darkest Dungeon. I like this feature because it means you have to adapt, but it meant spending several weeks gaining a roster of resolve six units in my playthrough because I was running thin. At the end game, I was very impatient, often spending weeks doing the same "explore 90% of rooms" quests on short or medium length dungeons to make time go by the quickest. Why would I want to take on a long dungeon when I was eagerly trying to finish the game? That's where I feel where DD took a giant hit to replayability. I'm not even sure I want to play the sequel, considering this. I did try to see if there was a new game plus after the game, and there is one called Bloodmoon, the hardest difficulty. It seemed interesting because there's a death counter that is used that dictates a game over, if you lose 16 party members you lose the campaign. I didn't want to sink another 300 hours into DD so I've decided against it.

The second stage of the Darkest Dungeon (don't quote me, I don't remember the chronology) is a tedious stage. In this stage the map is not revealed from the start, and the rooms procedurally reveal where the paths lead or intersect. You can camp twice. It lost a team the first time because the enemies were crit hitting frequently, but the torches were necessary. This is just RNG and not what I mean by tedious. The tedious factor in this level is that there's a creature that uses teleport [i]mid-fight[/i] and when that happens, your party gets teleported to a random location that you've explored in the dungeon. The creatures in that room are left with whatever hp your party dealt, so your efforts aren't nullified with a teleport. This paired with the unpredictability of battles you come across with the unrevealed trails makes for an artificially inflated experience. [strike]Cue the flashbacks to the Avatar encounter in XCOM 2.[/strike] All of this time is spent for a simple "find the thing" objective. When you find the curio, you can interact with it and that opens the portal to the last Darkest Dungeon stage.

The final Darkest Dungeon level is a direct path to the boss room. You have to listen to the Ancestor goad you into the point of no return. That "crowning thing" aforementioned by the Ancestor is laid bare before you. Gaze at the gruesome splendor of the - [b]Ancestor?[/b] Yes, the boss is the Ancestor, and I was astonished at this, but it made sense now how his voice echoes to you throughout the Hamlet after his suicide. The Ancestor transcended into an incorporeal being after all the atrocities he's conspired in. The first Ancestor has 5/5 hp, but he's immune to damage. He spawns different visages of himself, and you take your turns damaging them, and the key to damaging the Ancestor in this phase is killing the visages that have the eldritch skin. This phase is not so harmful, multi-target DOTs handle it well. The ancestor heals the visages, but it's not too much of a hassle. After killing the first Ancestor wave, the Ancestor morphs: same appearance but 200 hp threshold. He mostly did a high stress move or damage. This part isn't what killed my team on the first go. After annihilating the Ancestor boss form, he turns into the Heart, it had 250 hp. The heart at the beginning stays dormant, and hitting it heals but blights. I didn't have the provisions to deal with this and my party couldn't destroy the Heart when it transformed, and I was forced to pass when I was left with a solo musketeer. 

As far as the Heart's appearance goes, it looked like a malignant tumor with a bunch of beady pupils on its flesh. It has a large crack on the side of it, and a face that looks almost like a mutated peacock-humanoid with a spiked fan growing out of its head. It looked gross, more unsettling than mortifying. IMO it ranks far less on the grotesque scale than some other bosses from the other dungeons. [b][i]This[/i] is what the Ancestor "could not look, yet could not look away" from?[/b] 

The second time I deployed a different team composition, so I would have three units that could attack no matter their positioning: a houndmaster, an abomination, the resurrected warrior mentioned before, and a vestal. I equipped the three darkest torches, three martyrs seals and the ancestral ring. I was deliberating if I should even bring the MAA because he was at 70 stress in the Hamlet. Again, I was in a haste to beat the game, and brought him for better or worse. It was a stroke of luck that he got virtued in the Ancestor phase, and his crits were making him an MVP. Things were going smoothly, no one reached 100 stress. The Heart appeared again and I had the unthinkable happen: [b]I was forced to kill two of my units.[/b] The Heart took a turn to have me strike my units. I thought this was some kind of new debuff. No. Deathblow. Not deathblow chance [i]because screw your martyr seal.[/i] I clicked on MAA and he was killed outright. The final battle was a triumph, the blight and bleed stacked enough to shred the hp bar enough so that the lonely vestal blinked and it was over. 

The ending animated sequence was an affirmation of what I already knew, much less of a subversion of expectations. The Heart can't be killed; it's a rogue like. I know that the end isn't really the end. I suppose this was the way the story had to be concluded. [b][i]The broken place you found is left broken, no matter how much the buildings are renovated, or how pretty they look in the brightest sunlight.[/i] Your role in this story is the listener and observer, not the rising hero. You observed one man's descent into a self-inflicted, unceasing peril. You've listened to his grim autobiography.[/spoiler]

New Review:
This is a fun game if you actively try to win in your strategy, if you don't play with team comp, rng mitigation, long term in mind, you'll feel like your getting fucked by rng and there was nothing you could do, but you could have done something you just should have done something different an hour ago.
I'm still not very good at the game and I don't think rng in DD is good general, look at slay the spire it doesn't need rng 6-13 damage, and accuracy and resist yada yada, these things just feel like a chance to get scammed, you can scam your opponent as well but I don't think it evens out in terms of enjoyment. People proficient at will tell you: you can mitigate the rng, and they are correct, staying at 100 light all the time totally changes the game but I'm still not convinced it's great design as rng limits tactics though I can see the benefits as well for tone.
I think the games main failure is with communication and it doesn't lend well to playing casually, if you watch a youtube video about DD there seems to be an assumption that when fighting a boss you would know what the boss does before hand, why would you know this? Would you even want to know this? I'm not trying to go on the wiki and find the meta strategy for everything in the game that's never fun in a single player experience, I don't think there's anything wrong with an initial lack of info but why not have the player go fight the boss, and if the win or have and survivors then you could have glossary entry for the info available in that fight, that would add some interesting gameplay that could reduce wiki use and reinforce the themes of the game as players might want to send in bad employees to scout with little concern for their lives. Some other things I'd like are in the description of areas showing the common enemy types yada yada... I don't really want to play a game with a guide or keep a notebook, this is what I mean by playing casually. But overall I'm having a lot of fun with the game since giving it a second chance my tips for any others who want to try the game for a 2nd time is:
Keep torch at 100-76 (you can drop it down at the end of fights or save all the curios until the end and loot them in the dark but watch out for wandering monsters)
acc > dmg
kill > stun > dmg
spd is great
kill the stress casters in the back line first, heal is all restore at the end of the mission, stress limits you game play and spirals way harder.
dots are stronger than you think, delayed damage doesn't feel great for action economy but if you don't expect to kill an enemy before they acted then you will get 2 damage procs which generally makes dots very high damage plus it gets over prot.

I could write for hours about how incredible this game is, but I will sum up the beauty of it in a paragraph of what it is worth it to me:

*SPOILERS* You find yourself before the final boss, as prepared as you can be. Your Man-At-Arms has given two strong camp buffs to allow you to dodge attacks and deal more damage, and your Houndmaster has given reduced Stress, the mechanic that acts as a strange and flavourful second "health bar". You battle said boss, with all of your might, you come down to the last moments, all of your heroes but two are dead, and you have a full party wipe on your hands. The boss is low, but how could you bring down a quarter of its HP with only two heroes left? You are ready to fall, when you land a luck critical hit with your Leper, and follow up with a solid strike from your Houndmaster to defeat the boss. The relief as you finish that boss is worth all of the stress you received, both in, and outside of the game.

I highly recommend it for those that enjoy a mild grind with amazing gameplay, with a steep learning curve that really rewards planning your mission ahead of time, actually learning the various intricacies of the game, and mastering the game through practice and reading. It is rough around the edges at times, and frustration does occur, but if you are willing to put some time into it, it really has many rewarding victories throughout the game.

HEART ATTACK

Darkest Dungeon isn't just a game; it's a journey into the abyss that grips you from the start. The hand-drawn art style is not only visually stunning but also contributes to the game's immersive atmosphere. As you lead a roster of adventurers through treacherous dungeons, the stress mechanic brilliantly mirrors the psychological toll of their harrowing experiences, making every decision feel weighty and meaningful.

The strategic depth of party composition, skill management, and resource allocation keeps you on your toes, ensuring that each dungeon dive is a unique challenge. The unforgiving nature of the game, coupled with the ever-looming threat of permadeath, adds a level of tension that's both exhilarating and nerve-wracking.

The narrations, delivered with haunting gravitas, further enhance the game's atmosphere, making it an unforgettable experience. 10/10
love

This is a great game, BUT... Some things are too RNG dependent.
- You finished your mission with 0 stress on anyone? Nice, here take a bunch of negative quirks and diseases out of nowhere;
- You put a mark on yourself hoping that enemies will attack this character? Nah, they will decide to attack random targets anyway:
- You boosted your dodge to ridiculous numbers like 140 dodge? It's fine, but you will be hit anyway. Probably it is unfair talking about it, because the game doesn't show us accuracy of enemies in percentage, but I suppose that here is a fixed chance to land a hit in any case;
- You also can crit almost every hit even if your crit chance is lower than 20%, same goes for enemies. And you can easily do misses the entire round even if the chance to hit is more than 80%. This game, similar to XCOM, often makes you doubt what real chances actually are. Same goes with Death Blow resist, where 87% (cap) is nothing. and where you can send 0 level rookies to their death, and they just won't die for few rounds.
- The dice roll that is added to character's speed (1d8, I believe) is just straight RNG trash, it makes you to not care about speed stat at all, because it doesn't matter. 

Another annoying thing is the Shrieker. If you will lose randomly 1 hero with ancestor relic, without possibility to recover it, it will be not lost, but insteat stolen by Shrieker. And you can't take it back until it steals 8 of your trinkets (which is silly), so you HAVE to give 6 trash trinkets to rookies and send them to death in order to trigger Shrieker event. Otherwise you will just finish the game and still will never regain your items. It is tedious to say the least. Before Shrieker was implemented, you just lost those items and had to obtain it in another long 5 lvl dungeon.
Also, there is a smaller bug where the number of week in graveyard will be always incorrect if the person dies after you already was in Farmstead at least once. Annoying, but it wasn't fixed in years, and seems like players don't care either.

As an old player in this game, I also miss times when Jester wasn't so finale-oriented, where his solo was actually useful, where Grave Robber didn't have useless stealth and instead she had her dodge boost with ONE step back, where Leper/Plague Doctor/Man-at-Arms didn't have one-time-use skills and could stack them... Also, in Farmstead one-time skills don't work properly, because game thinks that the entire bar at the top - is one battle, so you end up never using them.

As for Endless harvest... Man, I feel so many missed opportunities. It could be something similar to Torghast from WoW, or Simulated Universe from Star Rail... Or it could be even difficulty that increases itself with every iteration, like in Diablo 3. But instead there is just a path to Sleeper, and after that there is nothing interesting at all, you just can leave. And if at the start you still could try to go as far as you can, for curiosity, then they implemented "endgame conditions", which killed this potentially great game mode completely.

[h1]Tough but Fair[/h1]

Found the game enjoyable and hard, but not overwhelmingly difficult that a defeatist attitude set in and I didn't want to play anymore.  I had read about the difficulty and random dice being what many others disliked about the game, but I didn't have that experience.  For me, it seemed that if you leveled your characters and played smart, it was usually not too hard to overcome what obstacles were in your path.  The few times it was quite rough were the best actually, in that victory felt very satisfying.  

There are a diverse group of 'heroes' that you can have in your party, with a max of 4 going into a dungeon.  This gives you a lot of room to experiment with the different pros and cons of each hero, and find out who works best together in a group.  

I have beaten the game several times now, the last on the hardest difficulty.  While there were times things went south, mostly it proceeded smoothly as long as I had the right team with good trinkets going in there.

Overall great game if you like this kind of rogue/dungeon crawls and a real good challenge.
What needs to be said? Endless replayability, challenging, iconic artstyle, and a wide variety of easy to use user mods.

I finally beat it after all these years. Yes, I used mods to take some tedium away (I'm a busy dad) and skin mods for fun, but I have played without mods, and it is still fun. Yes, it can be a grind, and yes, it can be stressful (pun intended), but your time will be well-spent if you give in to the madness. I am not a fan of the DLC other than the new classes because it adds a bit too much RNG and bullshit to an otherwise fair-feeling game. Play this game if you enjoy the thought that one small mistake on your part (forgetting enough supplies, etc.) can lead to stupid and totally avoidable deaths. Know what you're going up against and prepare accordingly, or you will suffer. Well, you won't, but your hirelings will. And tending to their afflictions, be they mental or medicinal, will cost time and gold. Roleplay with a Lovecraftian mindset and immerse yourself for the best experience. Light some candles. Drink some tinctures and commune with the dark. And remember, "Confidence is a slow and insidious killer."

Darkest Dungeon Review

Audio: 10/10 - superb soundtrack and voice acting

Balance: 7/10 - frustratingly difficult, but that is the point of the game and it does warn you as such

Design: 7/10 - systems are fairly easy to learn and understand but more directions would be helpful

Fun: 6/10 - occasionally straddles the line between fun and infuriating

Gameplay: 7/10 - gameplay is pretty good, a nice throwback to old turn-by-turns and dungeon crawlers

Graphics: 10/10 - haunting and gorgeous artwork

Extras: 9/10 - good DLCs that adds a multiplayer mode and new storylines

Playtime: 7/10 - long playtime, but the difficulty and grindiness can lead to frequent rage-quits

Stability: 10/10 - I’ve never witnessed any bugs or crashes

Story: 10/10 - Lovecraftian horror and lore, Cthulhu-esque madness, all of it great

Total: 83 slow and insidious killers out of 100

TL;DR: Use Darkest Companion, do your homework, and respect every enemy.

Darkest Dungeon is my favourite game to vehemently despise. The base game is incredible, the DLCs are incredible, John Wayne's narration, the art direction, the Lovecraftian themes, the modding scene; it's all incredible. But it's punishing. Really, really punishing, regardless of skill level. You'll lose heroes more if you're not cautious, of course, but sometimes you'll lose your best Crusader on his first death save after four crits in a row.

If a hero dies, they don't come back, and training a replacement takes gold and hours of work. I find saying 'use the wiki' is an excuse for poor game design, but... well, use the wiki. The retraining aspect is poor game design. Darkest Companion is a great tool, install some QoL mods like Faster Combat and Faster Walking, and research party comps in advance. Here are some I use to start you off:

Ruins: Plague Doctor / Vestal / Crusader / Crusader
Warrens: Houndmaster / Jester / Occultist / Hellion
Weald: Houndmaster / Occultist / Highwayman / Bounty Hunter (or Crusader)
Cove: Plague Doctor / Jester / Occultist / Hellion

Level in the Ruins since it's safest, use Highwayman if you're missing a hero, and buy the DLCs if you can. Respect the game, don't try modded content until you've beaten the game once, and have fun.

I love the whole vibe of this game, the comic book style art, the creepy, lovecraftian horror theme. And the voice narration really is what stands out the most. It's over the top, dramatic, and I am here for it.  The gameplay itself is addictive as hell (I'm 20 hrs in, and I literally can't stop playing). It has interesting combat mechanics, and a huge amount of different character classes to choose from. The game encourages you to try different party combinations as quite often your characters become stressed out and need to take time off, forcing you to try other character combinations instead, so it keeps the combat interesting. There's no SAVE feature here either, so if one of your characters die, they are dead for good, which really adds to the tension when you are exploring the dungeons. When it comes to investigating objects in the dungeons, like opening treasure chests or looking inside a bag, there's a risk that investigating something might harm you, but it could potentially benefit you too. You just never know what the game is going to throw at you, and I love that! If you like turn based RPGs, then give this game a try, it really is surprisingly good!

I was really hopeful about this. But it feels like they took the worst parts of tactical turn based games, explained nothing, and then added a system that takes away what little agency you have. The RNG might kill you in your first encounter in a level 1 quest, and with no way in the early game to deal with speed and hit chance, it felt like whatever I tried wasn't important. The initiative system makes all of the combos I was eager to try pointless. 

Ultimately when you get to surprise an enemy group, miss all of your attacks, the entire enemy party goes, then goes again before you in the next round, drives your characters insane and they begin skipping turns or auto-passing, you just get to watch an AI battle kill you and fail. And even when you win, you'll just "randomly" roll 4 more negative quirks across the whole party. 

Thoroughly disappointed, the negatives far outweighed the parts I tried to enjoy.

No game is perfect, but this one comes very close.  This game promises a difficult challenge & dark atmosphere, delivering on both flawlessly.  There is no protagonist, nobody is a hero, just normal people struggling the best they can to overcome unnatural horrors, their own mortality & the fragility of their own minds.  Even if you do everything right & play perfectly, a single roll of the dice will still inevitably lead to somebody's permanent end.

Replay value is extraordinarily high, with higher difficulty modes offering more mechanics, harsher penalties & new restrictions and limitations.  With one of the largest workshops full of DLC that I've personally seen & mods being constantly added & updated, you have a near-limitless source of ways to make the game fresh & interesting.  Furthermore, mods do NOT disable achievements, so feel free & have at it.

This game can be hard.  Like... unfairly, punishingly hard.  You will experience loss that will set you back a couple hours and then some.  The heroes come in by the caravan load and many enter the dungeons never to return.  There are some nasty surprises in store in the early game, and nastier still in the late game that will have you pulling your hair out.  RNG-sus will drive your party to madness and mutilate them one by one.  It's hard.

You can get good, though.  Your growing roster of varied heroes will improve in skill and through careful management of their afflictions and quirks.  Trinkets and baubles in careful measure will pull the party through the tightest situations.  Your decisions in supplying the party will make or break each foray into the darkest dungeons, and you will learn to mitigate the losses.

Holy shoot, it looks good.  All the grisly beasts, fungal growths, bloodthirsty marauders, shadowy shamblers, and spooky scary skeletons are illustrated and animated just right in a sharp comic book style that just oozes with that eldritch charm one might seek out on the brink of madness.  Our heroes look just as good whether they're losing their minds or experiencing a sudden pulse of courage, and in your respective rage or relief you'll feel those swings personally.  The level design visually fits right in, against the backdrop of a rundown hamlet to serve as your upgrade-able base camp, as your parties delve into a handful of impressively oppressive areas, all beautifully rendered, each with their own slew of specialized hordes.

Story's got some good spook to it.  Check out the trailers for a taste, though I would have liked to see some more storied animation within the game, it's still a great tale, mostly delivered through our ancestor's narration during the occasional loading screen.

In conclusion:  It's hard.  You might have a bad time.  Play it.

This is a great game that will make you feel angry or blessed and happy. It utilizes random to keep things fresh and interesting. I won't write what others already have written about the game - instead I'll write my last dungeon venture as it ended the game for me. On good terms.

Well, it's been the one of the greatest 37 hours of my life. Haven't had so much fun since the last winter.

Man, what a game! I really loved leveling up characters, finding optimal builds and parties for specific bosses. Pity though that I've lost my strongest party on the first Darkest Dungeon.

I've had Vestal, Bounty Hunter, Occultist and Crusader. Made a camp as soon as I got scared -- did not know how long till the boss so I decided not to waste the firewood. I think it's pretty unfortunate that there's no way of telling how long before the boss.

Got up to the boss and decided to get rid of the Cultist first. I killed it, but did not remove the corpse - I thought that way the boss could not send reinforcements. But it did! And I thought -- alright, gotta kill the corpse this time.

And...it got another cultist. So here I am -- my four AFFLICTED heroes, wasted amount of damage around 60 or 80 dmg; and I lost bounty hunter with crusader - no deal damagers anymore.

What do you think? The boss got exactly HP left enough for the two cultists that I've killed. Man...I feel embarassed, empty and at the same time respected. That I COULD finish the fight and emerge victorious, but from what I've read - this party could not enter the dungeon anymore? Looks like either way I'd need to come up with a better lineup and this I can't do.

Anyway, I decide to leave the fight and then the quest. Prompt tells me that I'd lose a random hero - I'm like "Oh come on. There's already two dead! Crap." So I went back to the boss that GOT FULL HP (man I wish my party could heal so fast and not in a fight), and let the rest face the death.

Now they all rest in peace with all the gold, the hours, the relics I spent on them. And I think that's "finished game" for me alright. I've got the lesson, I've enjoyed the game. And I've got neither the desire nor the time to grind another party of four exactly the same 6 leveled heroes with good relics.

Thank you, Darkest Dungeon, for the great time. But I won't be "finishing" you as in "Complete the game". Instead I'm finished with you, but I have only love. It's like breakup? Haha. I let you go and will save other heroes.

Maybe someday I'll pick it up again and retry the dungeon with another party, but we'll see.

UPD: Scratch all that vanilla femmey nonsense above. I finished the game with mods for +9000 damage a little time after the review. Got disappointed in the game. Felt that it all was for naught. But later I played a lot of roguelikes and roguelites and this game shines in a new light after that.

This is a game of choices and consequences. Almost everything in this game is a choice.
Every "sortie" in to the dungeon allows you to bring 4 party members. Do you bring the tank? the melee dps? The healer? The ranged dps? The mage? The other kind of mage (yes, there's a few different types that I'm grouping in to the "mage" category for this game)? Your experienced members? The less experienced? 
Do you put the dps in front, or the tank? What if that's not their favorite spot? What if they only have the skills unlocked for the middle 2 spots?! WHAT IF I MAKE A MISTAKE?!?!
Well...now that I've spent 15 minutes arguing with myself over the perfect party setup, now I decide on the supplies...
Should I buy antivenom? How many torches should I bring? I only need 4 units of food because they'll probably only want to eat once on the expedition...or should I spend the money on the extra 4 just in case? AHHHHH
Ok, now we're in the dungeon...as easy as encountering enemies, killing them, and escaping with the loot. Nope! The choices don't stop there! Especially with the larger dungeons.
Generally, about a few rooms in, some common decisions are...
Do I let the torch flicker out a little bit before relighting it? Sure, I'll be more likely to die but that sweet sweet loot though...Do I play it safe and keep the torch as bright as possible? Do I attack the enemies in front that are doling out all kinds of damage? Do I attack the ones in back because they're stressing out my characters and causing them to go mentally insane? Screw it, do I just run now and get back home with the loot I have? Do I push my characters farther in hopes for better loot? What..the heck is this? A statue, do I touch it? Crap, I touched it and made a boss appear...time to gtfo!
Ok, out of the dungeon and I'm about 5k gold richer. Just enough to upgrade 1 character's skills and MAYBE one of their pieces of equipment. ORRRRR...upgrade a building. Which do I choose? 
The choices and decision making are endless. And sometimes the consequences are BRUTAL. 
Worth a buy, or not? I'd choose to buy on this one. If you get it...don't get too attached to that character you're starting to favor.

Darkest Dungeon has stood the test of time as one of my favorite games of all time. The difficulty curve on the experience can be rough at the start and smooths out over the course of many estates. Each character feels unique in its archetype and sub-archetypes that form from the combination of various skill, other champions, and trinkets that you discover over the course of a run. Risk often translates to a tangible reward in the dungeons where "push you luck" can line your pockets with gold, trinkets, or crests, or you may wind up with four fresh graves in the graveyard. After a few estates, it can be a wholly different experience upping the difficult from Radiant to Darkest to Stygian (Bloodmoon with the Crimson Court DLC). You may have to re-imagine how you fought previous encounters when life limits, darkness increases. or a time limit are imposed. All of these factors helped shape Darkest Dungeon into a memorable experience that I come back to every year.

In addition to the base game, I suggest grabbing [in order] The Shield Breaker, Color of Madness, and Crimson Court DLCs. Shield breaker adds an incredibly useful and powerful companion that has a unique interaction in the dungeons. Color of Madness adds an optional 'endless' dungeon grind that pauses the normal time progression while keeping some of the risks. And finally Crimson Court adds in the powerful Flagellant companion, multi level mega dungeon encounters, and a ramping difficulty to the base game with bloodsucker infestations and the withering crimson curse itself. I think this order provides the best evolving gameplay experience in difficulty; however, this is not the order of my personal enjoyment. Above and beyond I personally enjoy the difficulty added by the Crimson Court the most. However it is very much not new player friendly. If engaged with too early you can feel overwhelmed with wasting champions and the punishing mega dungeons. And if engaged with too late you will miss out on incredibly powerful trinkets and be bogged down by repeated stress relieving activity reduction events in town. Color of Madness feels lacking to me, but I enjoy the trinkets before I get to the mid game. And the Shield Breaker can sometimes feel borderline busted near the mid game to late game. 

You will lose. The game will feel like it is picking on you. You will get overwhelmed. This gameplay style isn't for everyone and its okay if its not for you. But if you like this kind of challenge I promise that when its all said and done and the last champions head into the final layer of the Darkest Dungeon, you will feel rewarded.

Just taking a look at my hours in this game probably tells you how much I enjoy it. For all it's flaws and especially the ones that it had earlier in its life before some of the changes made to combat and the introduction of mechanics like the Crimson Curse from DLC, I still think this game has a warm place in my heart as one of my favorite games of all time. 

The aesthetics and artstyle alone are nearly enough to carry it for me, and it so sincerely captures the feeling of the games opening statement. Darkest Dungeon is a game about making the best out of bad situations. You will almost always be fighting an uphill battle, combat is stacked completely against you and you're likely to get completely screwed over by something you couldn't account for. 

This might sound absolutely terrible, and undoubtedly for some people this will be a frustrating and completely unfair game that is only hailed as "Difficult" because of the RNG involved in combat, etc. This is what I love about the game though. I am absolute masochist and always yearn for RPGs and tactical games that absolutely bust your balls and demand your A-Game. Sometimes through means that are usually seen as pretty cheap. X-Com comes to mind. 

If this sounds like you, buy the game.

This game is ass. After owning this game for 2 years now, I cannot force myself through the game. I want to love this game, but I cannot even get my moneys worth out of it. You die in the first dungeon, gameplay is basically sit and watch animations and hope your characters don't die. It's total die roll if they do or not. Entire teams will be wiped in the first dungeon by the weakest enemies in the game on a regular basis, you will be starting over repeatedly. Doesn't matter if you get a few levels or equipment upgrades, characters will just die, and things will be completely out of your control, which lead to me not giving a fck about any of my characters, or the game as a whole, and falling asleep in the middle of battles because of this. Game is boring, once you are over the over exemplified "difficulty" gimmick of the game. I truly think people only praise this game because "it's so hard it's good, right!" This game is boring and poorly designed once you are over the gimmik. The art is kinda cool.

One of the hardest games I have ever played. It breaks you down to your base components and then builds you back up again through careful planning and gaining a deeper understanding of how the game works. It makes you confident, and eventually should you not heed The Ancestors warnings, it makes you careless and sloppy. Overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer, and it lurks behind every victory, arrogant decision, and careless choice you make. So, I say to all who take the time out of their days to read this, great sorrows await you, but should you wade your way past them you will find an even greater satisfaction hidden deep within, The Darkest Dungeon.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
A near masterpiece of eldritch, Gothic horror. Dread and hopelessness without the generic horror genre cheese. Wayne June, you are a god, ‘nuf said. Expect several runs figuring out how to build good parties, and that thrill of victory when you win…on easy. Strategy and planning will carry you a long way, but the excessive randomness is why I need to put this game down now for good. It was a great run though.
[hr][/hr]
I hate to start off by calling [i]Darkest Dungeon[/i] a wonderful thematic experience because that [i]usually[/i] implies other elements are mediocre at best. [i]Darkest Dungeon[/i] is a near masterpiece because it is a great game that is [b]also[/b] deeply entrenched in Gothic horror.   It’s dark, moody, filled with your nightmares…and yet never relies on gore or cheesy jump scares to make you feel hopeless, desperate, and out of your depth. Surely this must be a full immersion VR, right? Nope…side-scrolling exploration with turn-based combat and town management. The thematic elements are simply [b]*Chef’s Kiss*[/b].

Wayne June as the Narrator also needs a special shoutout. He is the *[i][b]perfect[/b][/i]* voice to set the game’s mood. The Narrator is the only voice in the game and he is your dead ancestor, heralds your accomplishments and failures, and even narrates combat. Despite being the only voice in the game, playing for over 200 h, and having only 3-ish dozen routine lines…I will literally [b]never[/b] tire of hearing Wayne June shout [i]“Executed with impunity!”[/i].

Gameplay is overall good, but very hard…at first. Be prepared to lose several games just figuring out the system. But this is eldritch, Gothic horror set in an ironman style roguelike game. If you are getting into the setting, it wouldn’t be right if you beat the game on the first go…or second…or fifth. Also, you have to know when, and be willing, to abandon the dungeon because things just went really badly. And you will feel that loss, because you won’t come back with the resources to recover…much less make any improvements.

I put 40 h into the game before I had figured enough out to take my first real crack at it. Even then, I was still missing some key pieces. There are lots of ways to build fun and very effective adventuring parties. Once you understand how all the pieces come together, the roles your different party members can take on, the game becomes…not easy, but winnable.  

You are constantly trying to make the best of a bad situation. Heroes are frequently stressed to the edge of insanity, and you still have to put together an effective roster for the next dungeon. After you pay to give your heroes some much needed downtime (they can’t adventure), you have to make hard decisions about what to do with the little remaining gold. Buy one hero better armor? Upgrade a few skills? Make future healing cheaper? I love it.

[i]Darkest Dungeon[/i] isn’t perfect. There are a handful of minor gripes about mechanics I don’t like. Ambush, for example. If you get ambushed, it’s super bad…especially when you are still learning, avoid it [b]at all costs![/b] Then when you ambush baddies you go first, which seems good…but then they get 2 turns in a row. To me, that is a penalty. I would rather manage spread out damage versus spending the rest of the fight recovering from getting the ever-living shit kicked out of me (ambush fights frequently take [i]longer[/i] than regular fights because of this).

The game also indexes [b]very[/b] heavily into randomness…and virtually everything in the game has a random element. Want a Jester so you can reduce dungeon stress? You might not get one for 6…12…20 weeks (week = game turn, one dungeon per week). Need your Crusader to come back from the bar for the next run because he’s your only tank? Too bad…no telling when he will get back from his bender. Randomness is what ends up being [i]Darkest Dungeon’s[/i] Achilles’s heel, and prevents me from putting it in my top tier of games.

Once you are an expert or master of the game, you figure out how to cope with the randomness. Mostly by making sure the worst situation is still within the capability of your party. And if you chose to take a risky run into a high-level dungeon, you do it knowing that you already have the resources to recover. At this point I can guarantee a finish on Darkest difficulty run within a reasonable time frame, and without much angst or hand wringing…and because of that the game has lost a bit of magic for me.

And this is where the biggest problem comes in.  To increase the difficulty, you not only get tougher dungeons, but you get a limited number of deaths (12) and game weeks (86).  This is bad because the randomness might prevent you from getting the things you need to succeed. I went 10 weeks without getting a healer in my recruitment tent. Plus, the final dungeons become so hard that a single crit on the wrong guy will one-shot them. There are builds that help negate this…but that relies on getting the right trinkets to drop….  In the end, you might spend all your time and you literally cannot win, even with the right builds and playstyle.  That’s ok for a game that is 2-3 hours a run…not 20-30.

Despite how much I do like this game, I have to set it down now forever. The lower difficulties no longer feel like [i]Darkest Dungeon[/i], and the higher difficulties rely too much on randomness for the win/loss.  But I do have to say…[b]man, what a ride.[/b]

If you're looking for a game that will challenge you and keep you hooked, look no further than Darkest Dungeon. This game has a unique style that combines gothic horror and RPG elements, creating a dark and immersive atmosphere. The difficulty is high but rewarding, as you manage your heroes' stress and sanity while exploring dungeons full of dangers and treasures. I had a good time playing this game and I recommend it to anyone who likes roguelikes and strategy games.

Imagine playing for hours through a game and getting progression and then having one single boss or bad case of rng ruining everything. Literally killing your people you've trained, losing the rare items they were holding and a bunch of money. Where a boss has 4 moves to choose from, and it picks the one that hits everyone and stuns them more than 8 times in a row, and their stuns hit you every round, whereas yours (and everything else in the game) only lasts one round and then you get huge resistances. Imagine getting hit with diseases just for abandoning a quest, much less for fighting a creature that takes its turn before you and gives your character with the lowest disease resist the worst possible disease...and then stacks it three times on you with different diseases. Imagine getting stacked with diseases and mental illnesses at the same time.
If you want this experience, play this game, or slice up your body and jump into an open sewer.

This is an amazing game made by a passionate development team, and further bolstered by a dedicated and shockingly talented modding community. The soundtrack is grimly bombastic, and the sound design is top-notch. The DLC has also been crafted with as much quality and care as the main game.
It's also excruciatingly difficult. If you want the fullest experience and maximum amount of satisfaction, you either git gud or give up. That being said, mods! Feel free to nerf the difficulty as much as you want. Or, believe it or not, make it harder! I cannot emphasise enough how avid and amazing the modding community is. We've got game rebalances, class mods, new skins, new trinkets, new bosses, and even DLC-grade expansions.
I highly recommend buying this game. The vanilla product is fantastic, and the mods not only exponentially extend its lifespan and replayability, but optimise it for your enjoyment.
