I was instantly hooked when I started the game, but it all falls apart as soon as you make a mistakes later on.

This game is well known for the permanent death mechanic. Early on and in the midgame, this is a fantastic mechanic that really punishes poor play while still giving the player plenty of opportunities to recover from their mistakes.

Later in the game, though... If you loses a level 5 or 6 hero, you are looking at literal hours of grinding just to get back to where you were. It isn't interesting. It isn't fun. It doesn't create unique situations. It wastes the player's time with mindless grinding. By this point, you have most of the best trinkets, have seen almost every boss, and are just trying to finish up the game. Being forced to spend hours grinding for levels is not a fun mechanic, and the game does nothing to make leveling any faster.

If you have tons of time on your hands, maybe this isn't such a terrible thing. Though, if you have that much time, play something more engaging and interesting.

I want to love this game, but I just can't bring myself to finish it after losing a few max level characters to a combination of poor play on my part and an absurd amount of critical hits. Level grinding is an outdated mechanic that ruins the endgame of Darkest Dungeon.

It's not a bad game in it self, but I dislike games of chance and the depressing atmosphere. If it hadn't been recommended to me, I would've never bothered buying it. What good I can say about it is that the soundtrack is top tier and even though I dislike the depressing atmosphere – it is very well done.

Feels like what a dungeon-crawling experience should be like. Filled with unknown variables, unexpectedly brutal, dark, and full of high stakes. I'm pretty calm and collected with games, but this is one of the rare few that actually makes me feel like raging at times - I mean that in a good way, because my losses are usually due to me being careless or taking a risk, after an absence of bad luck giving me a false sense of security. As the (really good) voice narrator in the game occasionally says, "Overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer" 

That aside, the modding community is also great - base game has a good selection of classes (I'm guessing something like 15?), nearly all of them viable. With mods, even excluding the... questionable mods and being selective with classes that are a fairly close fit to the theme/balancing of the original, I'm currently sitting at over 100 classes. Not to mention extra content as well, such as one of them adding a chance for chests to turn into a mimic, and some even adding entirely new regions with the quality of official DLC expansions.

I’m of two minds with Darkest Dungeon. On one hand, it’s a game for masochists. Suffering is kind of the point. Darkest Dungeon doesn’t sugarcoat this; however, I don’t feel like Darkest Dungeon completely hits the mark, nor is it entirely honest. The biggest issue with getting into Darkest Dungeon isn’t the ‘difficulty’, which is really just excessive RNG, but how much the game relishes in wasting your time. Whether it’s crawling back through 7 rooms/halls of a dungeon you already explored cause you picked the wrong fork in a path, wasting turns in combat chewing through corpses ‘cause none of your characters can attack the remaining enemies, or wasting turns re-arranging characters ‘cause they don’t have abilities to dynamically re-arrange, or needing to wait for the stage coach to bring you a new healer after the one you’d almost got to max level died to a ridiculous cascade of RNG you had no opportunity to react to, or worse yet, having your entire party wipe and having to start grinding new ones up from square one. It’s Roguelite, so a degree of repetition should be expected, but the scale to which you have to repeat things, whether over the course of the entire game, or even in a single dungeon, and the slow pace at which the game runs to ‘build atmosphere’, is a painful combination. Not masochistic, ‘oh this requires a grand strategy’, not masochistic, ‘oh this requires razor sharp reflexes’, not even masochistic ‘oh I made a mistake and now I’m set back for it’, it’s masochistic because once you feel like your time is being wasted all immersion is gone and all that’s left is frustration… and yet I played over a hundred hours regardless, thinking back on my time with it I fondly remember the striking visuals, and dismal setting, and I do recommend the game, all because my time wasting gripes can be mitigated enough by workshop mods that increase the speed of dungeon movement and combat animations, among other things. Darkest Dungeon’s community has supported the game well, and I honestly think if you’re going to play it, you need at least the move and combat speed up mods to make it playable, but if that’s not to your satisfaction, there’s a world of mods from additional variety in graphics, to new character classes, and there’s even an overhaul mod that has its own store page, plenty to tailor the experience to your preferences.

It's a good game, but it's absolutely impossible to make any progress. I've played all on one save for these 68 hours and am at something like week 48. I still don't have anyone over level 2, because it's absolutely impossible to progress in this game. The only way you can complete dungeons after a while is by pushing through with all four members having an affliction, then you have to spend almost all the money you earned fixing them up, so in the meantime you have to use level 0s right off the stagecoach who either die or get so stressed out you have to cure their afflictions as well, so you're now in the hole again, spending all the money you just earned. You can't ever afford to upgrade anything because all your money is going into fixing everyone up from the last dungeon. By the time you get some level 2s and send them to a harder dungeon, you get more money but have to spend more fixing them all up again.

It's a vicious cycle that can never end. It's fun, but it's easy to get demoralized because there's just no way to make real progress in this game. Get it if if sounds good, but know you'll never, ever win no matter how much effort and time you put into it.

Unique, challenging, and memorable. Game is hard and the learning curve is steep. I like RPG-style games with a gothic feel. The animations and drawings are some of the best that I have seen in a game. Especially noteworthy are the character quirks, behavior in the hamlet and during battles, and stress mechanics. I liked the enemies and bosses (bosses were insanely dirty).

I highly recommend this game. It is good if you value the artwork, the gothic / midevil feel, character quirks and stress mechanics. It is a very different game that has not been replicated. Check it out!

Ruin has come to our family. You remember our venerable house, opulent and imperial. Gazing proudly from its stoic perch above the moor. I lived all my years in that ancient, rumor-shadowed manor. Fattened by decadence and luxury. And yet, I began to tire of conventional extravagance. Singular, unsettling tales suggested the mansion itself was a gateway to some fabulous and unnamable power. With relic and ritual, I bent every effort towards the excavation and recovery of those long-buried secrets, exhausting what remained of our family fortune on swarthy workmen and sturdy shovels. At last, in the salt-soaked crags beneath the lowest foundations we unearthed that damnable portal of antediluvian evil. Our every step unsettled the ancient earth but we were in a realm of death and madness! In the end, I alone fled laughing and wailing through those blackened arcades of antiquity. Until consciousness failed me. You remember our venerable house, opulent and imperial. It is a festering abomination! I beg you, return home, claim your birthright, and deliver our family from the ravenous clutching shadows of the [b]Darkest Dungeon[/b]

Darkest Dungeon is quite fun for the first couple of runs but really struggles to keep me engaged after that. There is a conflict between how much investment each hero needs and how they are meant to be expendable. This problem is exacerbated by the fact that you are forced to manage 10+ heroes since dungeons are level locked. Mixed with the punishing RNG, the game devolves into a grindfest that makes playing a save to completion really difficult. The atmosphere and narrator carry this game so you might be able to get the same enjoyment just watching someone play instead.
If you like sending heroes to inglorious death, this game is for you
awesome game!

I hate that I can't give this mixed. I love this game. The atmosphere, the design, the concept, the options, it's all great.

BUT, the UI is rough, and the random generation is sooo flawed. Perfect example: it takes forever to rank up, upgrade, curate quirks, supply, and develop one character, let alone the 10, or 20, or 30 needed to win. And you can have a character INSTANTLY killed on the first room, or last room by simply: every enemy goes first, strikes your unit, causes bleed, or blight, and you get knocked into a "Deaths Door" status, and then before any unit can heal or return fire - boom perma death. This happens on all difficulties, and really doesn't matter how much you prepare. The game tells you heroes will die. That's fine. But to spend so much time, effort, planning, items, upgrades, to have a unit wiped that way nearly ruins the experience. I've uninstalled and ignored this game for months because of it, and keep swapping reviews. 

ULTIMATELY, I would recommend this game, on Radiant difficulty. But know that it's got some critical flaws. And it's not like FTL, where you can re-load, or bounce back easy. 

ALSO, the DLC's are absolute garbage. I've done entire run-through's where some units simply don't spawn as an option. So you pay for a unit, and never get to play that unit. The Farmstead is a pointless grind that wears down your units with very little reward. And the PVP one is atrocious, and had hundreds of bad reviews lowering this games status. 

I'll keep playing it, but it IS a grind, and the RNG needed a heavy overhaul years ago.

Pretty fun game. Ridiculously hard, the RNG hates you, and some of the downsides of the items is pretty over the top. I don't mind difficult games. Love the souls games, 100% achievements on both Gungeon games without any mods or cheats. But because of how much of this game is RNG and how sometimes it feels like the game has decided its time to put you in your place. . . Honestly I recommend modding or cheating. If you don't want to download mods you can get into the XML files for character stats and adjust everything manually. Want your lvl. 3 Vestal to have 100HP and a 200% chance to dodge? You can do that. Don't want to make a group of terminators? Just boost them a smidge as a little treat. Play it, but if you are tearing your hair out after watching another party wipe it seems pretty fair to me that if the bad guys have eldritch horrors on their side, you get to have the blessed power of edited XML files.

Addendum:
I could not really get into this game until I accepted what it states in the opening scene. Heroes will die, quests will fail. The one constant is your hamlet, from which diligent upgrades will make those losses irrelevant. Utilize the idle stress reduction between weeks, constantly bring fresh recruits, and send them in screaming with minimal supplies. Don't worry about letting broken heroes go.

Upgrading the stagecoach to supply level 4 heroes will allow you to quickly fill your roster with max level characters, and losing them doesn't feel quite so bad. Level 4 heroes come with weapons, armor, and skills already upgraded, saving thousands in gold. I would not waste your resources on upgrades or stress reduction until you have them. Apart from that, tons of content to explore and conquer, and a free mod that essentially feels like a perfect sequel to the base game. I am nearing 200 hours between the two, and will likely hit 300 before completing The Black Reliquary mod and my Bloodmoon save. What a game!

This game already is incredibly charming, difficult, and feels good. But adding mods makes the game [b] ASCEND [/b], modding lets you make the game how you want it to be (thanks to the awesome modding community)!

-It can be a very grinding game for your first time through. If a character dies late game, it can set you back a lot.
-  Bosses are mostly hard when you have no idea about them.
-  Late game dungeons feel like if the game wants you to get beat up and/or die, it will happen no matter what you do.
- I really enjoyed the early and mid-game, where you plan out your parties and start building up your hamlet with the gold and items you find.  Late game is starting to slow down as it's annoying/tough to get your characters their final levels and upgrades. Even a short hard dungeon felt like it took forever to finish because of how bad some fights could go.
- Can cause real life stress/relief that your characters either killed themselves or somehow made it out without major injury.
Don't commit. Play for the first few hours and then drop this game - it would have already shown you its best parts by that time. The rest is grind, grind, merciless grind.

Darkest Dungeon is a game of meaningful challenge that is thought out in every aspect, no matter how small. The creative talent of Chris Bourassa and the coding prowess of Tyler Sigman, coupled with the great skill on display from all those at Red Hook, have turned what was once a small twist on power fantasy into a cult classic of turn-based cosmic horror. It's a true b*stard of a game, perfect for both aspiring and professional masochists, and it'll keep you reeled in from start to finish. Darkest Dungeon is a labour of love that came from a place of passion and creative liberty that is stifled in the triple A sphere of the industry. Get this game if the crack you're smoking isn't hitting right anymore.

These dungeons are dark.

--Pros--
1. Amazing selection of heroes with great abilities focused around certain party compositions

2. Ancestors narrations pull you into an incredibly atmospheric world of certain horror and mind numbing insanity

3. DLC is so much fun and so well done, easy to get into and hard to master

4. Turn based combat revolving around dice rolls, much like dungeons and dragons or other roll 20 games with a unique stress mechanic 

5. Artwork and Soundtrack are beautiful, dark and horrifically interesting. 

6. PVP mode for those willing to endure the pain for personal glory (The Butcher's Circus)

7. Large selection of skills and trinkets allow cool variations of the same hero (minus Vestal, she's stuck healing)

8. The poor miller, thrice a victim. The seasons took his livelihood, I took his land. And now, uncountable years later, the comet has taken his humanity. My only regret is I did not live to see that shoddy mill smashed to pieces by the miraculous bounty I reaped from beyond the void.. (The Endless Harvest)

                                                                   --Cons--
1. Insanely difficult, increasingly more punishing as you progress the story line

2. The Butchers Circus PVP mode is heavily RNG reliant and many of the best trinkets are locked behind leveling making your first games completely miserable

3. RNG can wipe you incredibly fast, especially in the final dungeon. Overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer..

Personal Rating: 4/5

Top 10 game. Top 5 game. Maybe even top 3 games of all time for me. Such a focused, intimidating, and endearing little journey. It's turn based dungeon crawling at its finest. The gameplay will demand you make do with whatever you have or fail. Sometimes, do all that and you still fail. Plan around the unknown, plan for what you do know, and press on to riches or ruin. All of the classes feel useful in spite of some definite stand outs. They also all feel fun to play. The sound design is top notch. The music choreographs foreboding, but mostly safe havens, tense treks through threatening hallways, uneasy firelit reprieves, and desperate battles. The stand out feature of the game's audio is the inclusion of the narrator, Wayne June, who brings flavor and injects some meaning in all that you do, filling in the blanks where the game might leave empty spaces or undefined ideas. The art direction and design is an endearing marriage of pop up picture books while also having a dark fantastical edge that makes it visually memorable and enjoyable to look at. If you're looking for an engaging gameplay experience, consider paying The Hamlet a visit. The road may take you to hell and other damnable places, but you'll have a surprisingly good, if a bit anxious, time purifying your ancestral home.

[ENG]
[b]Darkest Dungeon[/b] is a mix of a turn based RPG and strategy game in which we use 4-man group of mercenaries to explore randomly generated locations, gather treasures and fight with various types of enemies – bandits, skeletons and other kinds of abominations. Before we move into the dungeon there are a few decisions we have to make – not only which heroes we send to explore dangerous places (there are 18 different classes) but also pick their equipment (both individual accessories, increasing their fighting capabilities and utility items such as torches, food and medicine). Nonetheless planning doesn’t end after that – during fights we have to rethink every move at least twice since death of a hero is final and irreversible.

Like I said, gameplay is divided into few parts: managing Hamlet which is main hub where player recruits heroes and upgrade their equipment, exploring deadly locations like ruins or warrens in classic dungeon-crawler style and finally turn-based combat. Combat during which we have to use our protagonists as effective as possible since battles can be hard, especially because of RNG, which have huge impact on gameplay. Sometimes people describe Darkest Dungeon as [i]turn based Dark Souls[/i] but I do not agree with that. In soulslike games if you die it is because you made a mistake (most of the times). But in DD if RNGesus says you have to lose, you are going to lose. Sure, you can minimize the damage by playing really well and thinking three times about every move but in the end your sanity and patience will be tested. Nevertheless randomness can be helpful – sometimes RNG gods are on your side and you can pass through the long dungeon (which takes around 30 minutes to finish) without a single hit because your heroes are hitting crits after crits or dodge enemy attacks like crazy. To summarize, combat is double-edged sword - it can give ton of fun but sometimes can be unbearable. 

While describing pros I could also point out visual style of the game – it is nice mix of 
comic-like graphic, dark fantasy and stories/books written by H.P. Lovecraft. Despite being 2D it is very easy on the eye. Separate thing is music and overall audio design – it is not just nice, it is freaking awesome! Wayne June has done incredible work as a Narrator and became foundation of the game’s atmosphere. He delivers plenty of unforgettable lines and when we combine them with dramatic and intense soundtrack appearing during battles, the final outcome is just amazing.

Of course, there are cons, there is no flawless game (maybe except Witcher III). Like I mentioned before, to have fun while playing DD you need nerves of steel to tolerate randomness of the game which appears constantly during gameplay, from start to finish. Missing attack while having 90% chance to hit? Healing for 0 and applying bleed status on your ally which will kill him very next round? In this game it is possible. Morever, after longer sessions there can appear some kind of repetitiveness because of grind, mostly during endgame when our heroes are dying while trying to get through eponymous darkest dungeon. But despite these few disadvantages DD is a very nice title which can give a lot of fun and satisfaction.

I sincerely recommend you this game. At least give it a try. Either you will instantly love it or throw your PC out of the window <333

[b]Final note: 8/10.[/b]

P.S. Do not attach to heroes in your party. They are going to die anyway.
P.P.S. Remember – overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer.


[PL]
[b]Darkest Dungeon[/b] jest miksem turowej gry RPG z grą strategiczną w której korzystając z dobieranej przez nas czteroosobowej drużyny, eksplorujemy losowo generowane lokacje, wykonując wcześniej wyznaczone zadania, mordując bandytów, szkielety i inne maszkary. Przed wyruszeniem do lochów niezbędne jest dobre zaplanowanie, których poszukiwaczy przygód zabierzemy na kolejną wyprawę, w jakie przedmioty ich wyposażymy, a podczas samych starć obligatoryjne jest co najmniej dwukrotne przemyślenie następnego ruchu - bo śmierć postaci jest ostateczna i nieodwracalna.

Plusem jest bardzo ładna grafika w stylistyce dark fantasy z oczywistą inspiracją twórczością H.P. Lovecrafta, dobre udźwiękowienie z GENIALNYM głosem narratora i ciekawe, niezwykle przyjemne, choć momentami także cholernie frustrujące mechaniki gry. Bo oczywiście, są wady, nie ma gry idealnej (nie licząc Wiedźmina III). Żeby czerpać z DD jakąkolwiek radość trzeba mieć silną psychikę (zajebiście silną) i tolerancję na losowość, której jest tutaj dużo, a momentami jest, delikatnie mówiąc, frustrująca. Spudłowanie w przeciwnika mając 90% szans na trafienie? Uleczenie sojusznika za 0 punktów życia i nałożenie na niego krwawienia, które ostatecznie doprowadzi do jego śmierci? W tej grze to możliwe. Ponadto po dłuższych sesjach może wkraść się pewna monotonia wywołana koniecznością grindu, który występuje zwłaszcza pod koniec gry, kiedy nasi bohaterowi padają jak muchy podczas starć w tytułowym mrocznym lochu. 

Jednakże pomimo powyższych wad jest to tytuł niezwykle przyjemny i warty ogrania oraz na pewno jest jednym z lepszy roguelitów jakie kiedykolwiek powstały. A po ponad stu niezwykle intensywnych godzinach spędzonych z tą produkcją, dostałem weny artystycznej i napisałem fraszkę, która idealnie odzwierciedla zarówno moje odczucia, jak i obecny stan psychiczny po obcowaniu z nią:

[i] Na górze róże, na dole fiołki, dziś moja psycha naku**ia fikołki. [/i]

Serdecznie polecam <333

[b]Ocena końcowa: 8/10.[/b]

P.S. Nie przyzwyczajaj się do bohaterów, których masz w swojej ekipie. I tak zginą.

Very grindy, repetitive, tedious, and really just boring. There are elements of interesting game mechanics, but any semblance of "strategy" trying to use those mechanics is completely overwhelmed by the randomness.

Developers clearly didn't consider the gameplay ramifications of the stacked RNG: random characters, random dungeons, random loot, random hits, random misses, random effects. Everything is RANDOM. And we're talking TRUE randomness, not the balanced randomness of more enjoyable games like XCOM. 

Good games implement features to counteract their randomness, to give the player a break from too many bad rolls in a row. This game lacks any such feature. And as such, it lacks player-agency, making it barely feel like an "RPG" or even a "game". It's just a GUI for my computer to spit out random numbers, fighting itself. I, the player, am just here to click a button and see what happens next.

Darkest Dungeon is... really hard.

Treat the game like it hates you. I do not say this lightly, because if you play the game as if you're trying to spite the developers, it is somewhat easier. In order to really get into DD, you have to stick with a particularly grueling earlygame - something many people simply will not do. It's a frustrating game. At times, it'll feel like the game doesn't make any sense, or like you're not making any progress.

Because Darkest Dungeon HATES you. It wants you to fail. It will punish every single mistake you make, and will refuse to praise your victories. As you progress, you will be micromanaging well over 20 characters - that's 5 full teams! - in order to get their stresses down, their bad quirks removed, their equipment somewhat passable, and their skills in optimal position for success. This is an absolute logistical nightmare, since to do any of these things, you need money - lots of it, which you can only get by going deeper into the dungeons. You will lose characters. You will lose progress. The real currency of Darkest Dungeon is not artifacts or gold, but the hard-learned lessons of every mistake you make along the way. You will learn your lesson, or your future expeditions will be just as doomed as the one that taught you.

And I'm playing on EASY!

But it can be done. Stick with it. Make mistakes. You may have to restart a couple times. Learn every character you come across inside and out, don't be afraid to experiment, and most importantly - [b]running away is [i][u]ALWAYS[/u][/i] an option.[/b]

On paper, I should hate this game. It's has turn based combat (with RNG that can fuck you in a single turn,) there are roguelike elements, the dungeons consistently turn a muted color that bothers me slightly.

Yet this may be my favorite game I've played this year. The atmosphere does a lot of heavy lifting when it comes to the elements that would bother me. Having punishing RNG and muted colors fits the oppressive Lovecraftian vibe they were going for. But I think part of the saving grace of this game is that you always have options.

Permadeath is always around the corner, but you do have the option to retreat and deal with the consequences.

More importantly, due to the expeditions being finite challenges, you aren't forced to replay large sections of the game every time you lose.

There are a lot of positives going for this game, including the systems for characters to develop personality quirks, and the randomized stress reactions, but I'm mostly just impressed that the game was able to captivate me so thoroughly with game play mechanics I dislike instead of despite them.

"Darkest Dungeon" is a relentless descent into madness that has left me both exhilarated and utterly frazzled. This game is a merciless master, demanding every ounce of strategic brilliance and iron-willed determination, and I'm not sure whether to praise it or beg for mercy.

From the moment I inherited my ancestral estate, I knew I was in for a punishing experience. The game's dark and gothic atmosphere enveloped me like a shroud, and the narration, delivered with eerie gravitas, served as a constant reminder that despair lurked around every corner. The game's art style, a hauntingly beautiful blend of Lovecraftian horror and medieval darkness, only deepened the sense of foreboding.

The core gameplay in "Darkest Dungeon" is a relentless test of survival. Sending a party of heroes into the twisted depths of the estate is a game of risk and reward, where death is a constant companion. The need to manage stress, monitor health, and deal with the ever-encroaching darkness adds layers of complexity that can be both maddening and addicting.

One of the standout features is the permadeath mechanic. Losing a beloved hero, one who's been through countless battles and faced unimaginable horrors, is a gut-wrenching experience. It's a testament to the game's storytelling that each loss feels like a tragedy.

The character progression system is a double-edged sword. As heroes level up, they develop unique quirks and traits, which can be both beneficial and detrimental. It adds depth to the characters but also introduces an element of unpredictability that can turn the tide of battle for better or worse.

The game's difficulty is off the charts. Every decision, from party composition to resource management, carries consequences that can lead to disaster. It's a game that punishes mistakes with ruthless efficiency, and the learning curve can be brutal.

Furthermore, the game's narrative, delivered through journal entries and cryptic hints, adds an element of intrigue that keeps you pushing forward, even as the darkness threatens to consume your sanity.

In conclusion, "Darkest Dungeon" is a masterpiece of masochistic game design. It's a game that pushes you to the brink of despair, yet somehow keeps you coming back for more punishment. Whether you emerge victorious or succumb to the horrors that lurk in the shadows, one thing is certain: "Darkest Dungeon" is an experience that will haunt your dreams and leave you questioning your sanity.

This is definitely a hard game to recommend for anyone not familiar with its genres.

But for anyone that wants it, this game is a very solid intersection of Gothic/Eldritch Horror, Turn-based Strategy, and Rogue-like. It's stressful, but feels rewarding when completing an excursion. The stress and campsite resting make the Turn-based strat side more interesting, juggling traditional strategies with effectively a second health bar, and the Gothic Horror side is prevalent all the way down to how the game plays.

It is a steep hill to climb, but I'd say it's worth the trek up.

Most people that play games other than what's on their one and only console have heard or seen gameplay of Darkest Dungeon. While I must say this game is dripping in atmosphere, character, and style, it is also unfair. There's going to be someone saying "Just get better" and while that may be part of the answer to beating this game; It is not the whole answer. There are times in this game where you just have to sacrifice progress because the game has a wall that demands it. SPOILERS The final boss has a move that instantly kills  party members. I haven't fought the boss myself, but when I heard this I just stopped playing. That just isn't fun or fair. While the game is about making a bad situation not as bad as it could be, there's no real answer to "You just die". Imagine you create a team of characters that you feel very confident you can take to the final boss and knowing that one of them is going to die without any choice in the matter. I just wouldn't fight the boss. So I'm just not going to play the game.

HOWEVER I do recommend it because of the amazing quality of game you get.

I like design of visual and how you build your town, units, buffs and debuffs you get etc. But everything else in  mid and later ends of game is just failed attempt on game mechanics. Dont trust the % !!!

What started as a wonderfully atmospheric and grimdark fantasy adventure with eldritch tones rapidly turned into a gruelling death spiral. I love the premise of the game and I really like most of the execution, it was just frustrating to end up at a dead end hours into the run and realising I'd have to start over again, but it didn't feel unfair that I ended up where I did - it was entirely the result of my choices.

The idea is that you inherit a town that borders a land infested with eldritch horrors and you need to hire heroes to clear them out and reclaim the land. The heroes plunder the depths, go crazy and get injured, you have to nurse them back to health and in the meantime send out an alternate set of heroes.

While this loop is very fun as you go on expeditions and micro manage your different teams of adventurers, the problem is that there's a limited number of times you can run a given dungeon because the dungeon itself levels up. Combine this with heroes that can perma-die and you can end up with a bunch of level 1 heroes that can't explore anything and not enough high level heroes to be of use.

If you go into the game knowing that you can play yourself into a corner lets you set your expectations accordingly. Having that sprung on me made me feel like I wasted a lot of time playing the game the 'wrong way'. I look forward to giving this another try now I'm over the salt.

I once sent a Hellion to a mission, where she and her comrades had to kill a hag. 
The fight was a tough one. One by one the hag killed my party members until only the Hellion was left. The horrors of witnessing the death of her comrades in arms and getting dragged into a cauldron full of hot soup made her mentally as well as physically unstable. In a desperate attempt though, she managed to slay the hag and claim victory. Afterwards she collapsed right before she arrived at the Hamlet.
Since that day, she had nightmares of this traumatising event every day and even refused to eat soup, when ever it was served.

Anyway, some months later, I sent her again to kill another hag

The positives in this game are amazing, but still heavily outweighed by the cons. It's beautiful, the sound, the narration, the art, the ideas.
The gameplay however falls short. It's very RNG based, the healing is very few and far between, and stress will always be your downfall. One of my biggest problems with it is that you are almost always required to be either heavily over-leveled and over equipped for every encounter if you wish to get to the end, or make a very cheese strat to make it though, such as 90 dodge builds or 85+ prot builds. You have to find the most broken synergies available to you and max the hell out of them, or try to play the game in a 'normal' way and die trying. It had unbelievable potential, though the 2nd game also has quite a few of the same problems unfortunately.

Darkest Dungeon is a masterpiece that totally immerses you in its dark and haunting world. The chilling atmosphere keep you on the edge of your seat from the get-go.
Once you dive into the eerie estate, you're hooked by the gripping storytelling and wicked hand-drawn art style. The Lovecraftian touch is maintained throughout the whole game.

Customizing, and minmaxing my characters is one of my favorite things. They got quirks and flaws you need to optimise based on the challenges ahead. Its super satisfying to maintain your favorites and a big deal if you lose them.

Darkest Dungeon doesn't baby you, its the Dark Souls of dark dungeon games. It tests your strategy and creativity. Sometimes it can feel daunting if you want to sit back and relax, but you can always grind low level dungeons then.

In short, Darkest Dungeon is a must-play for anyone seeking an immersive dungeon crawling experience. Remember, overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer...

The game isn't that hard once you learn what enemy parties you might encounter, their abilities and what your heroes are good at. The gimmick of the game is that you cannot prepare for everything (unless inordinate quirk locking be considered a virtue), the trinkets always have some kind of downside (or kind of useless when they don't), but the good thing is that having stuns, lots of damage, speed, accuracy, some healing and some stress healing and camp skills to heal stress makes the game a lot more managable, so the conclusion is that you want to look out for heroes that have the aforementioned things and don't interfere with each other's positioning and always can do something useful in case you get surprised or shuffled. Another factor is more related to your personal blunders like forgetting some provisions like Blood or shovels and what not, or starting a fight you can't finish (Shambler, Collector) or having to abandon the mission because your team comp couldn't get to the boss room with little damage, or letting a hero get an affliction (this usually causes a domino effect and you'll probably abandon the quest soon).
Once you harness the game mechanics and RNG to some extent, the game becomes really enjoyable. The only feasible downsides are probably grinding level 6 heroes and RNG screwing you over on a rare occasion (like your level 6 Flagellant  with 87% deathblow resist dying on the first death's door check, have fun spending an hour or two grinding a new hero with good quirks! (also a reminder that deathblow resist doesn't exist)).

Its a fun horror side scroller dungeon crawler, with claustrophobic camera view designed to fully immerse you with your party. Its a difficult game, where you will lose heroes to the most pointless of things, even the ones you've been leveling up and upgrading since the very first week.

[h1] Darkest Dungeon is about making the most of a bad situation [/h1]
That’s the first part of the message that welcomes you into the game and I think it describes it perfectly, this game is hard sometimes even unfair but that’s why it so satisfying when you get to beat it.
Darkest Dungeon is a unique fusion of Side-scroller/RPG. I wouldn’t say it’s a roguelike, but it has permadeath once one of your heroes dies in combat is gone [spoiler] most likely [/spoiler] forever, this makes the game incredibly punishing. One bad dungeon expedition can set you back hours of gameplay towards the end of the game. The game makes an incredible emphasis on the positioning of your heroes some abilities are only available in specific rows so keeping the position of your heroes and messing up the enemies position it’s a key part of the gameplay. 
This game highly rewards knowledge and using the right tool for each situation. There’s a highly armored pig with poison resistance then bleed it to death, an annoying witch stressing your heroes bring it to the front so she can’t use their strongest attacks. Each dungeon is consistent with the kind of enemies you will be facing: 
[list]
    [*]The ruins are full of undead skeletons who are vulnerable to blight but invulnerable to bleeding
    [*]The warrens are inhabited by swine beast who are vulnerable to bledding but really hard to blight 
[/list]
And so on with each one of the locations, every battle is a little puzzle that you can approach in multiple ways according to your hero composition.
About the art style and the general setting it really hit the right spot for the general feeling of being trapped in a terrible situation, the music, the lore everything fits perfectly so if you find any of the elements of the compelling or you really like the challenges give the game a try and if you got yourself stuck don’t be ashamed to look for help in a guide or read the wiki about the game I did it myself and still today enjoy the game to a lot.
Also the modding community is full of great quality mods giving the game a lot of replayability, some modders were even hired to work in the team for Darkest Dungeon 2

Best turn-based rpg-style combat I can think of. Many complain about the game being "too hard" or needing a "wiki" in order to complete the game but that's really not true. As funny as it is to say "git gud lol" it really moreso comes down to "learn to prepare". Each area in the game has it's own unique challenges to prepare for and not knowing this (as you wouldn't in a first playthrough) can seem unfair but that's the whole idea of the game. RNG can be punishing but never too punishing to ruin your entire campaign. Heroes are disposable, no matter how attached you get know that they can and WILL die. The game is about working around this fact.

To be clear, I'm only recommending this if you are totally and completely ready to be disappointed, because you will be. Sometimes, you just lose. Everything will be fine, you'll go into a perfectly normal fight, and get such poor rng that a guy you invested a lot of money into just straight up dies. From full health to totally and irrevocably dead. This will happen over and over again until you decide to leave this game behind prematurely or finish it and leave on good terms. Unless there is something major I am missing (which after 39 hours would shock me greatly), then you will unavoidably have incredible setbacks because you can not just make the right choices to avoid death. The best you can do is try and tip the odds in your favor, but at the end of the day, luck will decide the fate of your every character. The best thing you can do is run away, which is kind of lame to me, but that's me. I love the aesthetic. I love the theme. It's so cool. But if you prefer a game where your decisions are what matters, then this isn't the game for you. This game is a gamble at every turn. It's hard, but it's incredibly unfair in the way it chooses to be.
stress

Just finished my first playthrough (Darkest difficulty, faster combat mod). When I first heard of Darkest Dungeon, the phrase I heard that stuck out most was "this game HATES you". After 90 hours, I'm not sure I'd agree. Rather, I'd say this game will take every opportunity you give it to screw you. DD is unquestionably mean, but not unfairly so. When things go wrong, the source can often be traced back to something you did -- characters' skills or gear is underleveled, you forgot important supplies, bad team comp, overconfidence, etc. -- and the game will happily punish you for it.

DD is a vast departure from what I normally play; I usually stick to fun, chill indie games that don't make you shake your fist at the heavens. There were times my sole motivation for finishing this game was spite. Even so, I'm glad I played DD. It drips with Gothic atmosphere, Wayne June is at the height of his powers, the breadth of viable teams adds to the potential replay value, and of course the memes are nigh endless. Even if I never touch DD again, I am part of this game now -- bound to it. Strong recommend.

What I like about DD the most:
*) the combat system
*) the level of difficulty
*) the balance between skill and RNG
*) the narrative
*) the pitch-black darkness

What I dislike about DD:
*) that you need to sacrifice heroes to learn about bosses (or read the wiki)
*) the unbalance of some parties
*) the cartoonish side of its artstyle
*) the small number of OSTs (they get repetitive after a while)
*) it feels unfinished

Recommended to turn-based dark fantasy game enjoyers.

It's a great game. Visually, audibly, the game mechanics. Keep luring me back. 
It feels very much like a game of Call of Cthulhu both in tone and in the punishing mechanics.

Difficulty settings are hard by default. I did NOT enjoy the game until I turned it down to 'easy' and turned off ALL additional difficulty options - THEN it became a fun game for me (others might of course like the punishing gameplay). 

The main downside - which is of course an intentional aspect of the game - is the loss of characters. So don't get too attached to them. You should, however, get attached to your hamlet (city upgrades stay, while characters die) but it feels a little weird / annoying. I think I generally like people more than buildings.

A smaller issue is how the effect of the various abilities are explained and shown. Both could do with a bit of tweaking for improved UX.

Ultimately, I simply cannot recommend this game.  I've played it quite a few hours, which by itself might seem thumbs-up recommendation, but it really isn't.

I like the battle line style games (by which I mean the array/position of your characters in a turn-based combat has meaning).  A front line, a back line, support, damage, looking for synergies.  Nifty. Engaging even.
I've read/watched the guides and tips.  I didn't find any of it particularly of use, I've been playing these sorts of things for a while.

The reality of this game is... frustrating.  At anything higher than the easiest level, the RNG is cruel and punitive.  At the easiest level... some mild challenge (which ramped up _sharply_ for the final dungeon).  The designers should note there is a significant difference between challenging and just mean.  Not to mention a nuisance factor.  
I'm okay with taking losses if it achieves my goals.  Slogging to earn enough money to make the characters viable so they can complete the only challenges available, watching them get crushed, oft with a series of crits from the enemies and misses on my part, in the first one or two meaningless fights in a run?  When there are likely to be 5 or 6 more fights plus maybe a boss?  Ugh.  The challenge is high enough that losing even one of four characters on the way to the boss is a death sentence (in the boss fight, that's fine, I've lost 3/4 and still won, dicey though).  
Healing, especially stress healing, is sparse enough, and defenses low enough that one might think that the all damage is the way to go, but attrition will quickly show the error of that thinking.  And, ofc, the decent support classes mostly don't do enough damage &/or tank enough to make them viable on their own (as it should be, but there is a balance to be achieved in there somewhere).

Oh, and the money grind.  Painful, right up until you are flooded with it.  But did I mention the building upgrade resource grind?  Which is dependent on the RNG?  And your limited space, competing with money at every turn?  Choices matter and all that, but you truly need _everything_, right now, no exceptions, or you die trying.  Repeatedly.  Over and over.  Which might be okay... IF the losses at times didn't leave you so destitute as to be unable to continue at all.
Not workable.

And after now rage-quitting from yet another excruciating and drawn-out series of failures and TPWs (which is the usual way I go in this game, build, build, nurse the characters and teams, try to scrape by, then watch it all collapse like a house of cards), the game is uninstalled.

Unapologetically difficult, Darkest Dungeon makes itself clear that it is a game that is not for the faint of heart. You will lose, and you will suffer setbacks. However, through experience and carefully planning out party comps you can begin to overcome the horrors pitted against you. 

With 17 heroes to create parties from, in tandem with a choice of 7 skills per hero, there's an incredible amount of variation in party builds. Since your characters will suffer from the psychological stress of the monsters you encounter, it is common to find the characters you like are indisposed for some missions, leading you to fall back upon other heroes you normally wouldn't use. This is a great method for encouraging experimentation that the sequel fails to capture. 

The art style, music, and narrator serve to create a capturing Lovecraftian tone that caught my attention and adoration instantly. Wayne Jude does an excellent job at adding tension to uncertain encounters, and grim satisfaction at the elimination of a particularly troublesome foe with incredibly memorable quotes.

While the game may not be for everyone, it is incredibly well made, and I encourage those not afraid of failure to give it a chance. 10/10.

For a long time, I wanted nothing to do with this game. I had heard that it is a sadistic turn based RPG that kicks your ass over and over until you are able to somehow luck your way through it or something. The megaten series came to mind, a series of extremely difficult turn based RPGs that I hate.

I was convinced by a friend to actually pick it up with the promise that the game is actually pretty fair most of the time, with the big important thing being making sure to prepare and strategize for what is up ahead. As it turns out this is correct and most people just suck really bad. Not to say that the game is easy by any means, many enemy encounters will have you sweating, and even seemingly easy enemy encounters can do enough damage to cause trouble or hit you with an effect that will disrupt your plans, but the game can be conquered if you really put your mind to it. 

A good example: One of the late game bosses humbled me after I had approached him with a little bit too much confidence and lost a unit before being forced to flee. For several days, whenever I was doing some menial task at work I started to think about the best way to counter this boss, taking all of the classes into mind. Then after over-preparing I nervously fought the boss again, to utterly destroy it because my strategy worked almost too well. THIS is what Darkest Dungeon is all about.

When you start, you won't really know the thin line between over-preparing and under-preparing, but if you really put your mind to managing your resources then you'll nail it pretty quickly and start doing pretty well. After that you can move on to figuring out which flaws are minor and which ones are major, figuring out good team compositions and formations, and finding a good balance of gold and relics to take home, and then like me you'll find yourself coming back every once and a while to push just a little bit farther.

TLDR: If you are looking for a really decent, challenging turn based RPG that is also kind of an army management game then here it is.

Have you ever watched an anime or read a manga about adventuring and dungeon crawling? If yes, I bet the one you read have one of those overpowered MC that makes the dungeons obsolete. If you play this game you will experience the struggles and horrors of the side characters on those stories.

Great style and sound design, addictive loop but it failed to keep my interest toward the late game, dramatically.
I can accept it's a game of rolling the dice and it can go both ways, I wish the game would accept that risk as well though, the later you get the more you have to lose and yet all the mechanics of the game bend the odds worse against you, the RNG is bent further against your favor with no benefit to you and the only way to keep up is equipment RNG, when the end game makes it very likely you will lose people it puts into perspective how much fun it is grinding a character back to max and rolling for the correct equipment to even give them a chance at success. Not to mention the rest of the team being functionally worthless until you train up a replacement for their comrade, since naturally as you get into the harder levels, less optimal strategies fall off in efficacy, though I do question the decision to make almost every status effect based team near useless by late game, starts to feel a lot like railroading. Not very fun, not at all. I'd go as far as to call it monotony. Whatever their goal with this game was I don't think it was boredom, yet that's about all the late game gives me, that and a desire to play anything else.

Darkest Dungeon and its DLCs is an exceptionally well designed turn-based RPG.  Well-balanced, flexible, amidst ranged/melee characters.  Stress and positioning play significant roles as you manage health and resources.  DD is one of my favorite steam games -- 800+ hours and counting!

The gameplay loop is tedious, and I found I could only clear one dungeon at a time before getting too bored to continue - this equates to about 20 minutes in the early game. It just lacks that "oomph" that sucks you in and compels you to play for longer than that. What doesn't help is that, quite often, combat drags on for too long due to you and your foe missing a high proportion of your attacks.

I appreciate that bad RNG is purposeful to sell the atmosphere, and I don't mind the "losing is fun" thing it's trying to do, but it just doesn't pull this off as well as other high-difficulty games. Progression is as slow as molasses, both in the "meta", and during combat, so I felt like I was just wasting my time.

Positives: the artstyle is great, the high difficulty sells the gloomy atmosphere and lore, and the combat is punchy and satisfying (when attacks land, which they quite often don't).

Not recommended for full price, but *maybe* recommend on sale. I'll revise this if it hooks me after a few more hours, but for now it's just not doing it for me.

[h1]It's hard, harsh and unforgiving.[/h1]

Most fantasy stories portray adventuring as an easy, even glamorous profession. These heroic badasses frequently swagger into labryinths, smash all the bad guys, steal all the loot, and when necessary, resurrect themselves with reckless abandon. But usually, these heroes are human beings. Humans can become frightened, they can have doubts, they can lose their minds and even betray their allies when their survival is threatened. They can succumb to post-traumatic stress after particularly harrowing experiences. These traits are at odds with the daring depictions of heroic characters, and so they are glossed over or sugarcoated. In Darkest Dungeon, they are an integral part of the game.

Before the events of the narrative, the player character's long-lost relative contacts them via letter, explaining that he has done something horribly wrong and paid for it dearly. He was a bored, jaded nobleman, and one day decided to investigate the rumors of an interdimensional portal underneath his castle. The rumors were true, and he unleashed a grotesque, terrifying horde of creatures on the surrounding countryside. The horrors were enough to drive him mad, and after summoning his estranged relative, he commits suicide.

Upon arrival in the hamlet beneath the hills of the haunted family mansion, I was given a small group of adventurers and a bleak message from the game itself, informing me that bad things were going to happen. I collected my eager, fresh band of heroes and an assortment of provisions (no Xanax, unfortunately), and then descended into the darkness for glory and treasure. Well, that’s what I hoped to find - more often I found derangement and despair. Every mission in Darkest Dungeon is randomly generated, with new rooms and hallways filled with curios, wealth, traps, and monsters. Whenever I reached a chest, corpse, or bookshelf to investigate, random effects would occur depending on my party’s statistics and provisions. Sometimes we were awarded some gold, or a trap would spring and inflict a party member with a terrible disease. Most of these encounters are avoidable, but the fights are not.

Instead of the tiles found in earlier roguelikes, Darkest Dungeon uses a two-dimensional presentation. During fights, my party of four was arranged to the left of the enemy party of 1-4, and opportunities are determined by the placement of a character within the formation. My arbalest-bearer, for instance, is better towards the back of the party, where she has enough room to shoot her crossbow. The healers like to be in the middle, and the paladins and shieldbearers belong up front. Party abilities can synergize with each other for tactical advantages - the jester can shuffle the party around and open up combo opportunities, while the bounty hunter can "mark" targets for big bonuses from other members. Of course, enemies can also do these things, and they have an AI capable of taking every possible advantage.

It’s not just the health of my heroes that I’m concerned with. Some enemies, as well as the conditions of the dungeon, can inflict stress damage. Stress is a secondary form of damage that, if accumulated too quickly, will generate quirks, neurotic tendencies, and downright psychosis. My heroes would crack when the burden got too high and lose their nerve, suffering from masochism, selfishness, or other maladies, which can lead to lost turns and increased stress on their allies. One of my first paladins, Reynauld, is a degenerate kleptomaniac, prone to stealing treasure in the field and keeping it for himself. One of my healers has an obsession with sainthood and takes every opportunity to martyr herself. My favorite highwayman suffers from alcoholism, and so on and so forth. These afflictions, as well as the myriad diseases that can be contracted in these filthy environments, can all be cured at the local sanitarium - for a price. Stress can be reduced via religious devotion and nighttime revelry, but all of this is only possible for heroes who are actually able to survive the expedition, which is a tall order. Heroes who die are permanently lost, but green recruits arrive weekly in the village. Little did they know they would become just another resource to me, as expendable as the torches and rations that accompanied them on their forays.

Darkest Dungeon is a mixture of stylish comic-like characters and a dark, gothic environment. The fingerprints of Lovecraft and Poe can be seen everywhere, from the tentacled monsters of the cove to the iron bars of the asylum. The effects match the theme perfectly - during battles, fighters cut into the foreground when they attack, and their model switches to a horrified grimace when something bad happens, like losing their mind. Movement animations are simple, but the character models are very detailed in their 2D way.

The music was composed by Canadian musician Stuart Chatwood, who also worked on 'Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time'. It is heavy on the strings and Victorian flavor, and like the gameplay, is deep, dark, and depressing. The narrator (whose character is the dead former proprietor of the castle) is the only voice besides enemy barks, and his pained, guttural delivery is excellent.

It's thick roguelike influences means that Darkest Dungeon is the kind of game that thrives when it is played over and over. Every dungeon is procedurally generated, every chest has a chance at strange fortune, and every new character offers a different set of abilities. Even when times are tough (and they will be tough, I assure you) upgrades can be made to the village facilities that slowly improve the heroes’ quality of life and chance at survival. In turn, the dungeons also get more challenging.

Darkest Dungeon is the rare game that gets my heart pumping while playing, not because it’s scary (even though it is a little scary), but because the stakes are so high. One battle can make the difference between waltzing out flush with loot, and returning home defeated, with the party dead or completely insane. It will punish your mistakes and it will even punish your good fortune, on the rare occasion it happens. Despite all of this, or perhaps because of it, I cannot seem to stop playing Darkest Dungeon.

This is a strategy game with tons of replay value. There are rooms that you move through each with a myriad of traps, monsters, or just nothing. You balance a party of four from a larger roster of fighters that you accrue. As with RPGs - weapons, potions, armor, position, skill, class all play integral roles in a careful balance between squad success or squad wipe.

If a game draws me in consistently on first play through then it gets a favored position in my library.

EDIT: However, upon regular play through, the game is slanted towards the player always on the edge of a major threat. It feels forced and manufactured to create a tension heavy playing experience. To me, this is inauthentic as a mechanic because it becomes a game of finding the "goldilocks" zone rather than being properly prepared for each dungeon encounter. In fact, you might be better off being less prepared because then the game might artificially balance it towards your favor. 

On my last playthrough I tried to intentionally wipe my party and that was harder than actually putting in an effort the time before that trying to keep them alive. That's when I knew something was seriously amiss with the balancing. 

I had high hopes that this was a true strategic experience and it falls way short of anything resembling strategy that could be impactful towards your playstyle. This is a game of chance. If I want to play a game of chance, I'll go play a card game. I think this is my first negative review.

This game has a really promising intro -- some of the best voice acting I've heard in a game, and one truly impressive animated cutscene.  But the UI is impenetrable and some of the rules are just.... stupid.  (After googling why one character couldn't target enemies, I discovered a lot of weapons only work when there are 3 or more enemies.  If only 2 enemies attack you, they get disabled. It's an enjoyable game because of the sense of uncertainty and risk that make your decisions seem more real life, weighted because if you miscalculate, someone dies permanently. I also enjoy the character management/upgrades. The mood of the game matches the title. It's also a game that I don't obsess over, I just play it for however long I want and then just walk away.

Darkest dungeon advertises itself as a brutal grim dark game where things can quickly go south if things go wrong and you don't make a recovery quick enough. And it lives up to that. Your "heroes" are lost souls and desperate nobodies at the end of their luck with nowhere else to go and the game really makes you feel.

I've had my eye on this game since it first came out and it is somewhat unbelievable that I waited until 2023 to get it. I wanted to hone my turn based skills in other games before i got this. This game really rewards preparedness and I prepared. It was very satisfying to build teams with synergies and plan out my strategies. The game isn't for everyone. The games difficulty wasn't mindless dungeon crawling and is more geared towards putting meticulous purpose in every action you take.

While the game is great by itself, the dlcs are a must have, and the modding community is phenomenal. With the community content alone you could pump in 10 times more time into this game with all the content. I personally am satisfied with having only have near 100 hours into the game, but I certainly could put in more since I haven't delved deep into modding beyond a few extra classes. Red Hook making the game so easily moddable was a really smart move that has kept this game alive relevant. I would even recommend enabling mods on your first play through. This and the fact the game consistently goes on 85% discount, this game is a must have for anyone that enjoys turn based dungeon crawling fantasy combat.

Also the art style and narrator are really great. Make the game instantly recognizable and memorable.

There is punishment in games to raise stakes. That is all good. If the player missteps or hesitates, they receive the punishment.

This game has RNG punishment. You can spend hours leveling up a character, and have it all go in the toilet in one encounter through no fault of your own.

You can have full torch light (which is supposed to give Monster Surpise++++) and...
- enter a Battle Room,
- not surprise the monsters,
- have all the monsters take their turns first,
- they all target one of your characters with 4 crits,
- you just wasted 3 hours and get punished through no fault of your own.

How are you supposed to "get gud" with encounters like this?

Such a shame. The game looks and sounds amazing! That's what grabbed me at first, but I completely regret putting 80+ hours into this game. I would take back the time if I could.

-- PS

Just to throw some Steam achievement stats out there:
- only 56% of players are able to beat only one boss in Darkest Dungeon.
- 50% of Dark Souls players are able to get all the way to Anor Londo (no small feat) and beat Ornstein and friggin Smough.

- 6% of players beat Darkest Dungeon on its easiest difficulty.
- 28% of players beat Dark Souls on its *only* difficulty.

Darkest Dungeon is an absolutely incredible game once you become accustomed to its mechanics. It brilliantly captures the essence of despair, illustrating the notion that when everything is horrific, nothing becomes truly dreadful. The gameplay itself imparts invaluable lessons on maintaining composure amidst adversity, guiding players towards a state of tranquility even in the darkest of moments.

The game's exceptional resource management adds another layer of depth to the experience. It feels akin to sitting at a table with a masterful dungeon master, who skillfully crafts a remarkably stressful yet captivating environment within the game. Paradoxically, this constant state of tension fosters a sense of inner calm, enabling players to deftly handle multiple challenges simultaneously.

Darkest Dungeon, with its unique blend of gameplay and atmosphere, provides a profound perspective on the human condition when faced with dire circumstances. It stands out as a masterpiece in creating a simulated yet therapeutic journey through darkness.

Highly recommended.

I have issues with this game. More than a year ago, I downloaded some mods to play with, and now it crashes when I try to enter in the mission area. Please help me, I dont know what to do and the problem persists.

You will mald, you will get bullshitted and you absolutely will get wiped for no reason at all, but you will learn and you will eventually win. RNG doesn't matter nearly as much as knowing how to plan team comps, understand party roles and knowing how to build your characters (there's even a hidden accuracy pity mechanic if you keep missing hits in a row).

EDIT: So after a couple weeks time away from the game after my biggest setback, I decided to come back to the game with the mindset of "The failure isn't falling down, but staying down", and ended up finally beating it after so many years of attempts.
I will keep my original review listed below, as it does highlight good reasons as to why this game might not be everyone's cup of tea. [u]But my own thoughts on the game have changed,[/u] I do still enjoy it despite it's frustrations - namely overcoming them. If you enjoy a ruthless challenge and seek to triumph in the face of adversity, then I would absolutely recommend the game.

Original review:
The game is fun, for the most part. But by the end-game a single mistake can cost you hours of work trying to make heroes resolve rank 6, which isn't helped by how evasive and dangerous enemies get in champion levels.
It's so unbelievably frustrating to, for example; [i]need[/i] a hero with the guard ability for the 2nd Darkest Dungeon, but every hero who reached high enough level to enter that location getting killed due to negligence and/or unlucky RNG, forcing you to re-train another one from scratch (even with all the stagecoach upgrades, the chances of specifically getting a rank 3 guard hero are slim, and still requires a ton of money and work to make them viable for DD).

I've had the game since early access - back when it was a viable strategy to have four heroes with the abusive affliction and go on pure dark runs, as heart attacks didn't exist back then - but was never able to beat it. And my latest playthrough to cross that off my bucket list has been plagued by scenarios like those described above, routinely sending hours of work down the drain.

The game is undeniably good - great storytelling, music and nail-biting difficulty. But if you're like me, there's only so much frustration that you can take before your enjoyment is completely soured. (It wasn't helped by the fact that I accidentally loaded a save before my mods had been prepared, which outright deleted half my roster of modded heroes. That's my own fault, I'll concede, but its still hurts since there's no way to go back to an older save to fix that mistake).

TL;DR: The game is good, but simply not for me. Something something skill issues.

[h1]Many fall in the face of chaos, but not this one. Not today[/h1]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
[b]Darkest Dungeon (DD)[/b] is a unique game, as I never played a game as punishing as this one. With the sequel recently being released, my interest was piqued to try out the first game that I happened to already own but never spent much time playing, and I'm glad that I took the opportunity to check out this gothic-themed experience.


[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Interesting gothic based story
[*]Fun but brutal gameplay that is very punishing
[*]Upgrades for your heroes, town, and more
[*]Beautiful 2D gothic art style
[/list]
[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]Playing this game can be a chore at times due to the needed grind
[*]There are times when you will be reliant on RNG and it might screw you over
[*]Activating some of the DLCs on your first playthrough is not recommended
[/list]

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story starts out with a man known as the [b]Ancestor[/b]; he learns of this special power that is somewhere deep in his mansion. He then uses up his family’s remaining fortune to hire people to help him dig up this mysterious power. However, it turns out that this power was something worldly and he ran from the dungeon. Only the [b]ancestry[/b] survived and he wrote a letter to the next heir of the family, to fix the mistake he made. After he sealed the letter and before the angry mob of villagers that were mad for what he did could get him, the [b]Ancestor[/b] had ended his life.

The story for [b]Darkest Dungeon[/b] is not fully told to you directly, rather, it’s told to you at different points in the game, mainly before you do boss missions. It’s interesting at the very least and I like the gothic [b]Cthulhu mythos[/b] theme it has going for it. Although [b]DD[/b] takes inspiration from the [b]Lovecraftian[/b] universe, there are also different inspirations that are included as well. The heroes you hire also have back stories to them as well.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The gameplay for [b]Darkest Dungeon[/b] is fun but also very challenging and at the same time, it can be very difficult to grasp. There are many mechanics that you yourself have to try and get used to. You will be able to hire different heroes that each have different abilities for them to use. Each of them also may have a different mechanic that corresponds to them, however, they all do share the stress feature. Stress in the game is determined by what the hero goes through in a given situation. When stress reaches 100, that hero will have a certain negative Affliction inflicted on them, like them being fearful, paranoid, etc. 

However, there is a chance that some heroes will be given a virtue when they reach 100 stress, they get increased stats and will randomly heal themselves. So, while most heroes get afflictions and break, others will use their stressful moments as something to encourage themselves. If a hero gets to 200 stress, they will lose the virtue and go back to zero stress, while those with afflictions suffer a heart attack.

During combat, your heroes can do certain attacks or abilities to buff/debuff allies or enemies. Each hero has a certain amount of health and it does vary, when their health runs out they will be put under a [b]Death’s Door[/b] status. When they are in this state, they will suffer state penalties and they have to go through a test to see if they will survive the next attack. I should note that if your hero is at 1 health and the enemies attack them with a move that does a lot of damage, they will tank the entire attack except the one damage. The only way for a hero to die is by failing the [b]Death’s Door[/b] test.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2995283070
If a hero suffers a heart attack while at [b]Death’s Door[/b], they will be killed immediately, when a hero dies, they are lost for good and will also lose the equipped charms they have. You can recover them if you lose a hero in battle but if it’s outside of one, they are gone completely. So pray that your best heroes survive the attacks and that their stress does not get too high.

There are ways to relieve stress, like taking out enemies or using a camping ability at a campsite. If your heroes survive the mission, you sent them on, you can send them to a few stress-reducing activities like making them meditate, drink at the bar, gamble, pray, etc. There are also times when a hero will get a disease, so you must take them to the [b]Sanitarium[/b] for them to get cured. A hero can get a max of three diseases, if they happen to get another one, it will just replace one of the current diseases they have. Last I checked diseases don’t necessarily work like that but who knows, I am not a medical expert.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2995282569
I should at least give a little tip/warning that if any hero happens to get stunned, for them to recover it will take that hero's turn. Enemies get the same treatment as well. In other words, [b]Red Hook Studios[/b] took some inspiration from the original [b]Persona 3[/b] game and wanted to bring back memories.

Certain moves will also only be available for you to use if that hero is in a certain spot in the party. If they happened to get moved or pushed back, they will be unable to use certain attacks or support abilities. It’s understandable for some attacks but for others it’s absolutely stupid - like, the [b]Vestal[/b] can’t use her [b]Divine Grace[/b] or [b]Divine Comfort[/b] abilities, which heal party members, if she is in the front. I understand that she is a support hero but it’s still pretty dumb that she can’t use those abilities if she happens to be pushed into the front.

Now as much as [b]DD[/b] is fun, there are a few issues with the game that don’t hinder the experience but can be a turn-off for some people. Playing [b]DD[/b] can be a chore sometimes, you will have to do a lot of grinding depending on the difficulty that you choose. This is normal for an [b]RPG[/b] like this game but it can get very repetitive for some people. To add to the fact is that the game also relies on RNG for almost everything that happens in it. Trust me, when your hero misses an attack you will feel pain.

Some of the DLCs in the game are also not recommended to be activated on your very first playthrough. Ones like the [b]Butcher’s Circus[/b] (which is online PvP) or the [b]Musketeer[/b] are fine because they just add features that don’t hinder the experience for the player. However, DLCs like the [b]Crimson Court[/b] add stuff like more grind, a very annoying status debuff, and is just punishing to new players. Buy the DLC on your first playthrough if you just want an even more painful experience.

[h1]Graphics and Performance[/h1]
The art style for [b]DD[/b] is absolutely beautiful, I love the gothic-based art style that the game has going for it, and is very detailed. I experienced no issues while I was playing the game.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2995283203
I tested the game on an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060 3GB, AMD Ryzen 5 1500X Quad-Core Processor 3.50, and 16 GB of RAM. 

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
There is a lot that I haven’t talked about with [b]Darkest Dungeon[/b] as there are numerous things to uncover from the game. If you are someone who wants to play a very punishing game, then this is the right one for you and you will get your money’s worth because a playthrough could go up to at least 50+ hours.

The clock struck midnight, and the old mansion creaked in the wind. The dim candlelight flickered ominously, casting shadows on the walls like the twisted fingers of the damned. I dared not move, for fear of waking the spirits that lurked in the shadows. Suddenly, a bloodcurdling scream shattered the silence, and I felt a cold hand on my shoulder. I turned, but no one was there. The air was thick with the stench of decay, and I knew then that I was not alone. The mansion had awoken, and it hungered for fresh souls to feed its insatiable thirst for blood and terror.

I played this game maybe two years ago with Xbox Gamepass, but I recently came back to it after I saw it on Steam for a huge discount sale. Originally, I played it and after a couple hours, I went "Oh, this game is just hard for the sake of being hard" and didn't touch it after.

After starting a new save today, I'm enjoying it more and more. Once you understand the mechanics and some strategies for it, Darkest Dungeon is up there with Morrowind. Most people that try games with in-depth mechanics and punishment for bad decisions just tend to say the game is unfair and uninstall it after they refused to learn or play by the game's rules. This game gave me that feeling of "eh, just one more dungeon" after every completed quest. This game rewards you for being good at it. It makes you feel smart once you understand the basics and play under the constraints (rules) that the game explicitly warns you about every time you boot it up. It's nothing but honest to a fault.

The music, art style, voice acting, and tone of the game are good. The combat loop can be addictive and it never makes you feel comfortable with it. The moment you get cocky, the game slaps you across the face and staunchly reminds you to not be too confident simply because you think you've mastered it. Most of the time when your party dies it's because it's usually your fault. Some people don't like that and that's fine. Some people that play games want to turn their brain off and want a power fantasy. Darkest Dungeon doesn't give you that luxury and it never feels cheap about it.

It's a pretty neat game.

Wow! Nearly 200 hours! You must really like Darkest Dungeon, right?

Wrong. Darkest dungeon is a roguelite with a fantastic start, and a woeful endgame. A wonderful idea twisted into a horrible, bloated mess - which I suppose is fitting given the theme.

Standard opening: Who the hell am I? I'm the guy who;

-Likes a good indie RPG.
-Likes a new mechanic
-Is a working adult with a full-time job
-Is not a 100% completionist
-Likes "Lovecraftian" a little more than "Lovecraft"
-But okay, 'Mountains of Madness' wasn't bad

Darkest Dungeon is a turn-based, dungeon crawl roguelike, set in a Lovecraftian world. You are tasked with recruiting various classes of hero into your roster, sending them out to fight the darkness. Over the course of the playthrough you will likely see many heroes fall, but with (an awful lot of) determination you will see you town and heroes grow, and push against the darkness.

Darkest Dungeon is incredibly well-stylised, and works its limited graphics better than almost any game I have seen. The artwork itself is extremely limited and the animation barely existent but time has been taken to make the transitions and feel right. This is complemented by an iconic narrator whose tone and extent of contributions meant that I never grew tired of listening to them.

Such is the commitment to the Lovecraftian concept, that your party members have not only a health meter but a sanity meter. In practice this means little more than juggling two health bars, but thematically it works well. Darkest dungeon is unusual in that its bullshit-o-meter runs absolutely off the scale - one enemy crit cascade added fifteen hours to my playthrough. However it all seems to tie in to the theme well.

Darkest Dungeon is enjoyable, challenging, well-written and generally well-presented indie RPG. I have no doubt whatsoever that you will enjoy it.

The start of it, at least.

See, Darkest Dungeon expresses some quite astonishing delusions of grandeur about its own lifespan. This is a game that you can happily sink 30 hours into, whose "abridged" campaign will take closer to 80, and whose unabridged campaign is probably closer to 150. It has no business being as long as it is. The four areas have two bosses each. For no reason other than length you fight these bosses three times each. And you grind and grind and grind.

When eventually the bosses are done, the end-game doubles down on the pain with the sort of level design they should teach out of you on day 1 of design school. Overly long dungeons that, should a character die (at which point your run is to all intents and purposes over) you must kill another character to retreat. Two enemies critted my full-health Vestal back-to-back, and she died from the resulting bleed. I retreated and lost my tank. Lacking another appropriate healer and tank (because characters can only take end-game dungeons once?!) I had to grind up from level 2 a new party. WHY?!

I have finally completed Darkest Dungeon and now can put it to bed. An exercise in how to outstay your welcome. Recommended with caution.
