Overrated. 
Not difficult due to decision making or strategy, but from the most miserly petty economy of any game in history.

First you spend all your money on supplies for a dungeon, then if you leave the dungeon you lose those supplies and have to buy them again when you go back out. WHY? Why wouldn't I keep my supplies that I bought with my hard earned money, especially with such a miserly economy? It's ridiculous and feels like it just artificially makes the game harder and not in a good way.

To make the cheap economy worse, you can go 80% through a dungeon and still not have picked up enough 'loot' to justify the equipment you bought to make the dungeon run. So leaving before the end leaves you screwed. Do that a few times and you're so broke you have to start a new game. Then again continue with such damaged characters and someone or more will probably die. Not a good design IMO.

Next you are always dealing with stress. And one enemy puts 17 stress on ALL your characters in one hit, but then your only recourse is a skill that ONE of your guys has that takes a full turn, but only cures A COUPLE of points of fear on ONE person. WOW. GEE, thanks for NOTHING. IF they survive the dungeon run, back at town stress persists and you have to pay a LOT of money for LITTLE stress relief. Again, stupidly cheap, intentionally frustrating economy.

Also you can't get attached to your characters because chintzy economy and worthless 'healing' mentioned above and practically forcing you to complete dungeons when people are badly injured and stressed.

Also adding to above, some of your characters just get focused like crazy no matter what position they're in or what aggro taking abilities you have on other characters. They all just INSIST on taking that one character out. Again, don't get attached to any characters.

And by the way, who the heck are YOU? 

You are supposed to be the owner of the land this desecrated castle is upon, but then you don't actually appear in the game as a character. Bizarre. Of course they had to go with such a weird design decision as YOU would just die anyway like everyone else in your broke impoverished healing-free party and the story couldn't progress. This decision ruins immersion and makes you as attached to the story as you are to the characters you pick, which is to say not at all.

Frustrating and disappointing. 
Artificially 'hard' to impress elitists / masochists, all for all the wrong reasons.

This game is intent on wasting your time, and I do get it. It slaps you over the face with a through line that you're trading meat for knowledge and progress. They give you so many cute little options to do things like change your units’ appearance name to ask you to care about them and it is a trick to ask you to waste your time. The core gameplay of dungeon delving is almost as horrifying in that every animation and move between rooms is excruciatingly slow. That means that not only is your time customizing the characters at stake, but the entire cumulative time of dungeons cleared and stress reduced is what you're risking when a character dies. This was genuinely intolerable for me when I first approached this game and I put it aside for later, presumably when I was better at video games.

Actual years passed, and I saw Black Reliquary release. It looked cool, so I poked around and saw it was a mod pack which was much more difficult than the base game, so if I wanted to engage with that fully, I might as well try this game. Looking through the mods of this game is very difficult because most of the collections arrange by users have completely unhelpful (predominately pornographic) imagery as thumbnails. Some of the quality-of-life mods are in all the most popular collections, and they are additionally bundled with cosmetic mods which may or may not be up to personal taste. 

As an aside, it can be considered unfortunate that the only consistent reskins of the game's assets are nsfw. I suspect this is because all the work it takes to bring a complete 'character' to life, which includes specialized animation knowledge, demands more than a hobbyist engagement. While there is a way to fund indie projects where it is free for everyone once it is completed, that crowdfunding model structurally favors porn, to be blunt. That fact is clear, but the why is well beyond the scope of this review. Know simply that the mods for making characters and npcs look different which are sfw are few and far between and are likely to have disparate and incompatible art directions.

What I did personally was download all the mods that steam marked my friends as having also subscribed to. I got all of the quality-of-life mods necessary to make most of the game's problems far more bearable, and it clicked for me. The game is a very tidy rpg if only it wasn't "pretentious" in hammering in the point of how brutal and high stakes it is precisely by wasting so much of your time. That said, my mod selection contained beastiality imagery, so I would strongly advise having more discretion than I did. 

After completing the first quest of the Darkest Dungeon, the game begins employing graphical tricks I would merely describe as 'cute' to try and emphasize a turn for horror. I won't be specific about what happens but suffice it to say I got tired of it over the course of two hours. I've had mostly negative things to say about the game and honestly, I probably should disown the game as a grindy piece of garbage which is intent on wasting your time, but that mod support really can salvage it. Mileage varies, but an assortment of "speed increase" and "automatic save" mods can go a long way in making the game accessible and breezy experience. If you have nostalgia for a difficulty implementation which resembles 'getting punched in the nads really hard and being told to go back and doing the entire section over again, perhaps with even less resources than before', the base experience and difficulty options remain.

This game is...wow, just wow. Unbelievable tension, I don't think any game has kept me so tense in my entire life.

What is Darkest Dungeon exactly, and what makes the game sucj a rollercoaster of stress and satisfaction?

Darkest Dungeon is a lovecraftian turn-based RPG with beautiful (or frightening) hand drawn lovecraftian-inspired character, enemy and environment designs. And does the game inspire fear with more elements than just its graphics...the bleakness that surrounds the game is directly translated into tough gameplay, intrincated mechanics and tough enemies.

Darkest Dungeon's most notable feature is the stress meter, which is a separate bar just above your health bar which will cause a trigger when it reaches its mid-point, with impacting consequences. Would the stress meter be full, your character could very well suffer a heart attack. It's just awesome, specailly in a game where you can continuously recruit new ¿heroes? but yet has a nasty permadeath mechanic.

This doesn't mean the game doesn't give you tools to go through its many dungeons: there are roughly over a dozen different classes to choose from and many combinations to try. Trial and error is vital in this game since it follows its own rules and mechanics, and experimenting with different party combinations made my day. Mercenaries can be upgraded when leveled-up and they can learn new abilites. Knowing who t chosse, or which abilities to pich depending on the different zones in the game, is crucial.

And whil the learning curve is steep at the beginning, with enough effort you can more or less master the game and its mechanics, competently entering dungeons with a high chances of success. But all it takes is one unlucky fight for things to get ugly...enemies will not want to make this wasy for you, specially when encountering new ones, and while the variety is just okay, some enemy party combinations have the potential to trash your party depending on its composition and placement. Big shout to the area bossess which are all not only way tougher than regular enemies, but also possess their own, and very flavorful gimmicks which you will have to learn and master...or face death. And don't get me started with the final zone of the game...you thought you had it all under control but there's a good difficulty spike there (and also a highly impacting design decision that will irritate some...and make others clap in respect to the flaour).

This game is not only challenging but also lenghty enough, at about 60hours to reach full completion.

For its current price tag, I would totally give it a try, and would recommend people to see if the kind of tense, pseudo-masochistic fun that Darkest Dungeon provides its their kind of spice. For me it's a 9,5/10 masterpiece.

This reminds me of the Dungeon Crawl Classics game I played in High School. DCC is an rpg where each player starts out with four characters, who all go through a level-0 adventure, called a Funnel. The game is extremely lethal and regularly unfair, and any character who survives that first excursion levels up and gets the privilege of being a main character. Darkest Dungeon is that experience in video-game form, you watch a herd of characters slowly grow and suffer over a protracted period, and it's really something special. The mechanics are frequently frustrating, but it feels deliberate. If the idea of having a bad time on purpose turns you off, you should probably stay miles away from DD. If you're a fan of pokemon nuzlockes, you're probably going to love this one. 
If I have to levy any real criticisms, runs go on a bit too long. The game's very punishing, but it's bad at telling you when you've lost. I don't know if I've ever actually scrubbed out of a DD run, but I've conceded a lot of them. Also, the number of characters you need to juggle over the course of a run makes it very easy to lose track of emergent narratives.

Ruin... has come to my party.... After hours of traversing the darkness, holding to the false hope granted by the waning light of our torches, and cutting down foul abominations with blood and steel, we came to a room full of glittering gold, trinkets and baubles. Our stress, our wounds and tears had finally yielded a treasure worth our pain and suffering. But, alas, it was a fleeting hope. We were then confronted by a creature of such a dreadful constitution half the part was driven mad by the sight of it, vexed by psychotic visions and terror, they became incapable of facing our foe and were felled with ease. The rest of my party.. we fought valiantly, but its strength was too great and their lives were snuffed out as a candle in the darkness of night. 

I escaped the abomination. Limping back to the estate to lick my wounds, relieve the stress of death and defeat, and prepare to venture once more into the dark depths of of the estate to fight for its salvation. Our hope, though a weak flame, continues to burn. 
10/10

True, RNG is brutal, but it is certainly not the singular factor determining whether or not you're gonna win your missions. Just like any game, you can get good at Darkest Dungeon. The difficulty is in setting up your team, fighting in a smart way, and manipulating numbers with buffs, trinkets and such. True, with 40 dodge you'll still get hit, but it's gonna happen less often than if you had 10.
Use your head, don't seethe and cope by leaving bad reviews because your dogshit team got obliterated. You can make it. You can get good at this. It's hard, it's emotionally consuming, but it's doable and it's fun, so it's worth playing. One of the most memorable and engaging games I've played.

[b]Overall,this is an amazing game and it is worth your money if you likes turn-based games.[/b]

TL;DR: Game will induce masochism through RNG rigged against the player and either sadistic game design, or severe oversight. Economy/Base-Building Side is very satisfying.

A game to recommend to someone for all of the wrong reasons.

This game should not be fun. It just shouldn't be.

You get punished for doing a good thing, you get punished for doing a bad thing, and occasionally, randomly, you get fucked because the game decided it's Fuck-O'Clock in the morning and you look ripe for the pickin'.

Surprising an enemy sounds like a good idea, right? Well, not in this game. Because surprising an enemy doesn't net you an extra turn, rather just you all go first. So, if you can't kill all of them in one turn, the enemy now gets 2, 3, or 4 turns to fuck up your guys without any recourse.

And let's not forget that the RNG is incredibly biased, or at the very least feels biased, towards the enemy. They will consistently crit and land low-chance hits while they dodge every attack aimed back at them. This compounds into the problem of surprising enemies actually not being a good thing, because enemies will line their ducks up, then proceed to double-crit a party member, promptly kill them, and all because you managed to surprise them, which is a random event in this game.

Make no mistake, this game is very fun and satisfying when it wants to be. Landing hefty blows in the 30s and 40s of damage is incredibly satisfying when you've built a party or character for that purpose. But my god, this game is an even tug-of-war game at its fairest, and a suicide mission at its worst.

As far as the economy sides of things goes, collecting treasure and upgrading buildings and managing your party through the Hamlet, it actually feels fairly balanced. Everything is a decision, there is no willy-nilly buying upgrades. The upgrades feel well-priced, allowing you to usually upgrade one or two party members per run, with some money spent towards recuperation. The Trinkets, the Busts, Portraits, Deeds, and Crests, work very well as resources, requiring you to hold onto them as treasures in the place of gold or other valuable items, or adventuring supplies, like torches, food, or curatives, forcing you to prioritize expanding your town or resting, recuperating, and fortifying your adventurers. 

The Trinkets as a system and as part of the Hamlet, are well-designed and play into the games focus on careful decision-making, even if that focus is shot in the knees by some odd design choices and really wack RNG.
If you like pain and having to lose like 10 times in order to actually play the game, this is for you.

[h1] "Remind Yourself That Overconfidence Is A Slow And Insidious Killer." [/h1]
Tried the game 3 years ago and gave up and ended up completing the main story on build 25721 a couple days ago with the large majority of the game being a great first experience into the roguelike genre.

[h2] Story [/h2]
Storywise this game is average, while it is explained why you are in the town and what your goal is through the narrator and memoirs, it honestly felt forgettable; nothing really stuck to me. I could not figure out what caused the black magic in the first place or the change in intro towards boss dungeons without watching a video after I completed the game. Then again you are not really playing this game for the story, but for the roguelike dungeon experience. Voice acting, music and sounds are top-notch especially during lower torch levels. It actually made me feel anxious about progressing.

[h2] Graphics/Level-Design/World [/h2]
Visually the art style fits the game and is unique, everything from the abilities, character design and the dungeon itself looked great. Each of the zones looked unique and you could tell what zone you are in without a name just from enemies and the environment. The only design direction I did not like was how some characters like the Hellion have a large head proportional to her body, kind of making her look like a Chibi. Enemy wise, they matched their zone with their resistances being relevant such as more blight resistance in the warrens. The only issue I have with the enemies is how their stats are presented, I understand this is roguelike but nowhere in the game glossary or hover is it explained the effect of value of resistances. For instance I have been able to stun an enemy with 50 stun resistance but in the 60+ hours I’ve played I have not stunned 100, 200 or 300 enemies yet for blight I have managed to get it to proc enemies with up to 150+. It’s the same for acc on enemies. Why do I need to use the wiki to find out a swine ability hit rate is 82.5, it should just show me that in game. It is actually convoluted how none of this is explained in game.

[h2]Bugs [/h2]
Performance wise the game runs great, it is not an inherently demanding game with the art style. So you should not have any issues running this game. Bug wise I did encounter stat bugs such as acc showing 0 when it should be showing a significantly high number. It does update correctly after an action but it's too late at that point. Aside from that I have not experienced any bugs.

[h2]Conclusion [/h2]
If you want to try out a roguelike for the first time this game is a great entry into the genre, the game does a great job at encouraging persistence when your hero dies. But I do think as a new player a lot of things can be better explained and presented in-game. I recommend getting this game especially if it's on discount.

I bought darkest dungeon 2 first, and then one as i liked the sequel. That being said, I really enjoyed this game and thought it was both fun and challenging. I like the affliction system and the stress system as a whole, and i liked having to push my adventurers to the brink just so i could get some more tasty dabloons. I like turn based games and i especially liked all the visual flare present in this game, which gives characters attacks more "omph" and makes the game more interesting. I originally thought i wouldn't like the town system of hamlet, but I actually quite enjoyed having to help heroes with stress and taking purposefully weaker teams into dungeons to level them up and to get my higher level heroes back. My only complaint is that heroes don't want to go to lower level dungeons at some point, but that was probably made for balance and you can disbale that with mods if you so please. Overall i give it a #Lepersweep/10. If you're okay with getting smacked in the face by a video game you'll probably have a jolly 'ol good time with this game. Do i prefer it over the sequel? nah, both games are equal in my eyes and i liked both of them quite a lot.

I've tried beating this game on two different occasions. The first time, I got to about week 50-ish, but eventually I just got rekt because I was a newb. I then put the game away for a while because I did not feel like starting all over again. Eventually, I decided to give the game a second chance because I wanted to at least beat it. I did a bit better and got a bit further, but honestly, after a while, the game started to feel like a bit of a chore. I felt like progress was slow and I was grinding a lot after a while. It seemed a bit repetitive and eventually I just felt like it wasn't worth it anymore. I couldn't force myself to get to the end because I just wasn't enjoying myself. I felt like I was just focused on farming trinkets/gold and leveling up the characters for most of the time I was playing rather than actually advancing. Occasionally, I would beat a small boss but that was about it. You really have to be in it for the long haul if you want to be a completionist.

That being said, I think there's a lot of good in this game. Most of the characters/elements are pretty balanced for the most part, and there is some fun strategic stuff here too. If you like this genre, it might be worth a try especially on sale. But if you don't like to grind, then I would think carefully about it before you buy.

I beat Darkest Dungeon today (05/28/2023).  To most, in the age of thousands upon thousands of titles to play, that might not seem like much, but trust me, it is.  Darkest Dungeon is a game that gets you to feel again.  You play, in hopes that you have set yourself up for victory, but know that there is always a chance in every step, turn, decision for things south.  When things do go wrong, it is often disheartening, but it is also a chance to really show your mental metal and pull things out of the proverbial fire - and even when that fails, Darkest Dungeon has that one extra layer of hope in the form a hero who becomes courageous when there is nothing left.  You get attached to your heroes, you grow sad when they die, you go to work mad on Monday when your party gets wiped because you just kept telling yourself "They can make it..."   Yes, Darkest Dungeon brings back something lost in games, it gets you to feel.   Mix all this with a solid system of abilities, stats, characters and a unique aesthetic of art and environment, and you have a true masterpiece of gaming to experience.   I highly recommend this title.

This is one my favorite games, and it's hard to list everything I love about it. The core of the gameplay is a fantastic turn-based and position-based combat system where every round feels like solving a tiny puzzle to try to make the best use of your heroes' abilities. Exploring dungeons is also a problem-solving adventure thanks to the stress mechanic and the constant risk/reward calculations with how much light you choose to have and how many curios you interact with. Add in fantastic artwork, great sound design, and some of the best music and narration I've ever seen in a game.

Some people may not like the amount of RNG - the game is deliberately unfair in a sense, with no outcome ever being guaranteed, but that's on purpose. Before you even get to the main menu, the game warns you that this is a game about making tough choices and you won't always be able to win. That might not be for everyone, but for me it makes it a really unique experience. Most of all, I think this game is fantastic at creating memorable stories that are unique to your playthrough, whether that's landing a crucial critical hit at the last second, or losing your favorite hero to a bad roll of the dice because you took too many risks. I'm currently on my third playthrough and still loving it - the DLC and the number of amazing mods makes it very replayable in my opinion. Highly recommend.

Much better than Darkest Dungeon 2, but still be prepared for what you're in for. This game is essentially a grinding simulator. It's not difficult. It's punishing. There's a difference. The gameplay is not hard. You don't really have to learn all that much to put together a decent team composition and make decent tactical choices. You are, however, incredibly reliant on luck. Now, this isn't that big of an issue, except that the punishment for losing, which is, again out of your control most of the time, is very high. Your units with all their expensive gear and fancy trinkets and great perks you spent so much money on are lost, and you have to start again. 

Now don't get me wrong, you are always making progress. As you build up the settlement your units start stronger and stronger so there's less work to do when you lose. But the sheer time commitment, as can be seen by my hours, is absurd. There really isn't that much content here that the game should take this long. It just takes this long because the game keeps snatching your progress away and if you want to win you just have to keep slamming your head against the brickwall until you get a good run. 

It's unfortunate because the game IS fun. The aesthetics and narration are fantastic. Individual runs are also fun. But the game should really be a 20 hour game not a 50 hour one, where the extra 30 hours are just the game forcing you to grind by leveling up new heroes since your old party lost at the final fight because of unlucky rolls.

This Game. 

I hate it.

I recommend this game if you can go into it expecting and accepting complete bullshit. It advertises itself as difficult, which it is, but I have only ever lost characters to series of crits and misses that should be vanishingly unlikely (most recently, I missed 3 86% attacks in a row against a low-health enemy who proceeded to crit and kill two of my characters). I'm left to conclude that the game lies to you about its various elements of random chance, for this and other reasons. For one, every time I should have experienced a party wipe after I lose a character and the situation snowballs, the enemy appears to begin to make less logical decisions and chance to resist death appears to go up. I believe I understand the goal: getting you hooked on the swings in momentum and taking away your sense of control - and the game does this effectively. It would be significantly more palatable if the game was up-front with it, however.

Going into the game expecting to lose every once and a while to bullshit RNG, you'll find its progression systems and core mechanics quite satisfying and frustration at your losses will make your victories all the sweeter. The narration, art, atmosphere, and lore are all astounding as well. I'd also recommend against torturing yourself by keeping track of how unlucky you're getting as I have, lol. That path leads only to salt.

To the folks who are on the fence about getting Darkest Dungeon because of the difficulty and RNG factor: I felt the same exact way and put off getting it for the longest time because I didn't want to spend $20 on what I feared would turn out to be a frustrating experience.

Two things initially drew me to Darkest Dungeon:

1. The advertised difficulty (making the most of bad situations), and
2. The gorgeous paper art style mixed with gothic horror elements.

I read reviews on Reddit and Steam and felt conflicted. On the one hand, some players were extremely passionate about this game, while others bemoaned the RNG and endless grind. Technically, both camps are correct: This is a wonderful game, but it absolutely can be tedious at times and is not something I could play for hours on end in a single day. There's a lot of micro-management and grinding and it can feel very repetitive at times. It's something I'll play for 1–2 hours a day and resume the next day.

Darkest Dungeon is different than other roguelites because it is heavily reliant on RNG—whether your hits land, whether enemies crit you (or you them), whether your heroes stand fast or expire... It's often stressful, but it's also exhilarating and draws you in like no other game. You'll become emotionally attached to your heroes and then devastated when they eventually die. One minute you're steamrolling the enemies, and then the boss at the end of the dungeon decides to return the favor. How quickly the tide turns! Again, the game warns you about this before you even reach the menu screen: Darkest Dungeon is about making the most of a bad situation. The odds are mostly stacked against you. What makes the game fun is realizing this, treating it as a challenge, and doing the best that you can despite those seemingly insurmountable odds. Don't expect skill alone to get you through the game—temper your ego and know when to quit.

For some additional context: I love Soulsborne games and roguelites like Binding of Isaac and Slay the Spire. These games can also be frustrating at times, but they are also immensely rewarding if you stick with them long enough to master the mechanics. If you have a similar taste in games, I'd recommend getting Darkest Dungeon—I think you'll like it!

I quite enjoyed playing this game most of the time, discussing locations, enemies, bosses, pros/cons/builds of heroes, tactics and trivia with friends. Only except when my heroes died in quests. 
There's a complete mechanism to ensure that a hero cannot be revived through S/L(save scumming) after death, and the situation of your entire squad will take a turn for the worse after your hero goes crazy or dies, which means that you have to think carefully about your team comps selection and everything before each mission.
Losing a whole team with all hard-earned trinkets due to some stupid mistakes drives me insane, it's just like the gamer gets paranoid affliction. This game actually emphasizes that mental health point is more vital than physical health point. D:

Btw, according to achievements, 4% of ppl beat Darkest Dungeon, for FromSoftware games(souls series, sekiro..) the rate is 20% even 33%, Jump King 10%, Getting Over It with Bennett Foddy 8%.
So if you've never been obsessed to party-based rpg or deck-building games, think twice about starting to play this game.

UPDATE - I blazed through a dungeon with four of my best characters and brought the boss down to half health with ease, only to have them ALL DIE from a sudden case of bad RNG. When I saw the tables had turned, I tried to escape with what I could salvage, but it was of no use. It's the kind of loss everyone needs to experience at least once in life. 

I'm not a fan of turn-based combat games, especially when chance plays a critical role. This is one of those games, yet I've found myself loving it. There's something bitterly cathartic about sending adventurers to their dooms in hopes of making just a dent of progress in this brutal, brutal game. At just over 20 hours in, I feel like I haven't even scratched the surface. Having gone in mostly blind, I'm not entirely sure this is a game that can be beaten. Obviously, it can, but the odds feel so insurmountable that it's shocking to learn someone out there was able to do it in under 3 hours. This game kills your team with heart attacks if they become too stressed, and friggin' everything stresses them out. They even stress EACH OTHER out. Death from stress can take the strongest of your party in an instant and it’s maddening and fantastic. And that’s before the monsters come into the equation— one of the first bosses is a hag that killed all my best heroes by stuffing them into her cauldron. As soon as you’re able to free one, she immediately stuffs another into it. It’s hard to really pinpoint why I love this game, but it may just be how all the odds are against you. Not a great sell, but it’s an addicting trial by fire. I only suspect loving it more as I progress, though I don’t see myself finishing it any time soon.

This game isn't hard per se, its just poorly balanced.
Everything in this game has a certain chance to happen, and it seems like no system was implemented in order to guarantee that RNG just defeats you, once in my dungeon my cleric was 80%-0% by a spider in the first turn, was poisoned, and on the next turn (she was SECOND, while being slow, due to bad rng or something, so I couldnt even heal her, or get out of combat) she didnt survive the skill check and died. The reason she died? She went on a dungeon, thats it, she shouldnt be the first on my team to act, shouldnt be 80%-0% by a minion, and failing deaths door killing her is just a result of the fact that this game has no balancing on rng, sometimes your character can not kill a guy at deaths door that had an 80% resist hitting him over 12 times (yeah, this also happened, but at the circus), and other times your characters can, miss 6 times in a row with an average of 80% hit chance, can get a combo of one of your characters only being able to go to the brothel for stress relief, and not being able to at the same time (at least you can fix this, my cleric dying is not quite fixable). This game does have strategy to prep correctly, but even with perfect strategy, you are going to lose fights, even with preparation, even with the right characters, because the game told you that you should, and that is unfair game design.

Darkness Dungeon is a challenging and rewarding dungeon crawler that will test your skills and patience. The game is all about quest completion, balancing your party, taking risks, and making the best out of a bad situation.

The game starts with you creating a party of four adventurers. Each adventurer has their own unique abilities and skills, so it's important to choose a balanced party that can handle a variety of challenges. Once you've created your party, you'll set out on a series of quests.

Quests in Darkness Dungeon are randomly generated, so each one is a new challenge. You'll need to explore the dungeon, fight monsters, and complete objectives in order to succeed. The game is unforgiving, and even the smallest mistake can lead to your party's death.

That's where the risk-reward system comes in. Taking risks can lead to great rewards, but it can also lead to disaster. For example, you might be able to find a powerful weapon in a dangerous area, but if you're not careful, you could get killed.

Making the best out of a bad situation is also important. If your party is low on health or supplies, you'll need to make tough decisions. Do you risk going deeper into the dungeon to find more resources, or do you retreat and try again later?

Darkness Dungeon is a challenging and rewarding game that will test your skills and patience. If you're looking for a dungeon crawler that will keep you on your toes, then this is the game for you.

Here are some of the pros and cons of Darkness Dungeon:

Pros:

*1000s of hours of game play.
*Addictive
*Challenging and rewarding gameplay
*Randomly generated dungeons
*Varied party members with unique abilities
*Risk-reward system
*Great atmosphere

Cons:

*Can be unforgiving
*Too Addictive
*Some quests can be too difficult
*Can be repetitive

Don't..... make mistakes. Darkest Dungeon won't have mercy on miscalculations, you nor your heroes.

This is a beloved game for a reason, but this game FEELS terrible to play. So many decisions seem designed to amplify the oppressing feeling of the setting through gameplay. 

- Inventory is a huge hassle. There's an intentionally designed tension between carrying enough supplies with you to have what you need and having enough room to carry back treasure. This should be interesting, but in practice it means that you just skip many curios when you don't have the appropriate item because it's not worth subjecting yourself to the whims of RNG. You also constantly have to just throw money and resources on the ground and move on because you can't carry them. The game is balanced around this of course, but it's intentionally balanced to make you feel bad while you drop loot. 

- The "easiest" difficulty setting sets you up for failure. Playing on Radiant, the recommended difficulty for first-time players, causes you to level up faster, among some other small bonuses. This leads to inevitably overleveling your characters for the level 1 and level 3 dungeon runs, and being hit HARD when you try to take them into level 5 runs without max gear and skills (that you haven't had time to afford before your characters got to max level.) This can easily lead to your first deaths after an easy run, and a slow, boring grind to get everyone up to speed so you can actually move on. 

- Speaking of grinding, good god. There is a single class that is used for making extra money, so good luck not bringing this extremely underpowered character on every run (it can be made to work well, mostly by literally hiding behind stronger characters.) There is a constant, demanding drain on money that increases every week. For every run where you bring back 20k, there's 2 negative traits and 1 disease that need to be purged. By then, your big payday is 2 upgrades on one of your 20 heroes. Better get back out there immediately!

- RNG is part of just about every aspect of the game. Attacks are dodged frequently, crits are hugely impactful, and whether or not your characters live or die when their health reaches 0 is a dice roll. The game is balanced around this all averaging out, so usually things work out, but the outliers are frustrating and not based on player skill at all. An example from my experience: Party has one healer, this character is hit with an attack that can cause a bleed DoT. The attack crits, one-shotting the healer down to 0 HP (but not killing her, that's a dice roll.) The attack applies a bleed DoT that will tick on her next turn. If another party member can heal her past the amount of 1 tick of the DoT, she is not subject to the death's door dice roll, but there are no other healers so she has to pass the roll and heal herself. Her turn comes up, she fails the roll and is dead with zero input from the player. That this RNG averages out to being balanced over a thousand runs is no consolation for this feeling terrible and giving the player a bad experience. The game is still winnable, I can get another healer, but see all previous points for why recovering from a disaster isn't fun either. 

Maybe they fixed all this in the sequel lol, I won't be finding out.

If you're looking for strategic difficulty and solid turn based combat -- this isn't the game.  

The game's primary mechanic is risk management.  The player has the option to play safely and patiently and have an easy time or take risky moves/decisions for more excitement.  If you like this type of gameplay then I highly recommend it.

The best part for me about this game are the music, voice work, art and those very small details that show the developers' love for their creation.

This game holds a special place in my heart since I got it years ago when I was going through a very difficult phase in my life. Seeing the characters suffer afflictions and heart attacks really showcased quite viscerally that humans just have limits for stress and once you reach that, not only does your performance suffer greatly, it can also affect other people. So resting is not only something you do when you feel like you have no other choice, it really is the best, most logical choice for everyone involved.

Beside my personal attachments, it's just fantastic game in general. The combat mechanics are challenging but a lot less RNG prone than you might think at the start once you get some experience and it clicks. The music fucking slaps. It has incredible high replayability, especially with the timeless artstyle and the countless mods that are available. Even though there's little said about the characters, you can easily get attached through the little tidbids of lore and barks...
only for the game to rip them away from you because of subpar planning or even an unfortunate crit. Well, that only teaches you that "Overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer". You'll experience loss and defeat, but that is part of the game balance (and real world). Important is what you do once the damage is done, because in general you can get up and try again.

An extremely cool game. I like essentially everything about it. The only reason i'm giving this a thumbs down is the RNG is truly awful. And I know many people would just say "Well just get good, learn how to play with buffs to your advantage". Which in many games i'd agree with. But there's absolutely no reason an opponent should dodge my attacks twice in a row when they only have 5% dodge and then turn around and hit me 3 times in a row while i have 45% dodge. There's no reason a creature with a bleed resist of 10% should resist bleed 5 attacks in a row. These are examples from the last 2 hours of gameplay. Rolls like this happen every single time a come back to this game, consistently. I really do like just about everything else though. The atmosphere, setting, gameplay, narration, graphics. Its all very good, but spending hours and 1000's of gold on a party upgrading and preparing and fine tuning with trinkets, just so they die because the game decided i'd get crit by every enemy in a random hall battle and then subsequently have each of my own attacks miss or be dodged several rounds in a row is extremely disheartening and disappointing for a game that I enjoy so much. I'll probably keep playing Darkest Dungeon, but if it doesn't already have you in its clutches, save your money.

Welcome if you are here to revisit the first instalment after the second game drops.

It is worth your your money for certain, although not necessarily your time as I would not recommend finish it. 

Darkest Dungeon one is, by all criterion, a game that succeeded spectacularly in what it set out to do, which is to put you in a harsh, unforgiving world and allow you to experience what it would be like to truly be a 'hero' in a dark tale. In the first 10 or 20 hours, it is everything a great game should be: reasonably good story well realised by its art style and voice actings, and a passable gameplay that complements each other with the story.

But because this is a harsh, unforgiving, dark world, to actually succeed requires luck, efforts, grinds, and patients, which is the opposite of fun. So once you pass that 20 or 30 hour mark, you will realise that you have got your money worth back, you have stopped to enjoy the combat, but the game is still as frustratingly stubborn to stop you from finishing it to get some closure., and the developers have no intention to alleviate the grinds even after the contents outstay their welcome.

Don't worry about that. When that happens, just close it, watch the ending online, and remember: While the handling of the endgame grinds can be seen as a hit and miss, and the second game might not be to your taste, the first game is, still, a very, very rare daring innovation so hard to find nowadays and a early access done right. It offers a lot for its price.

I legitimately had no clue at the time, that the name of the item was predetermined, and thought that the game will actually give you the heads of your fallen adventurers some time after they had died, just solely to mess with you.

It's things like these, when you go into it kind of blind, that makes this game the more endearing, the more you learn about it. For all it's faults, and the fact I'll perhaps never beat this game, I still can't help but find this game endearing.

I really enjoy the premise of the game, but it seems every venture can either go really well or really poorly. There's too many negative effects you can pick up and not very many good ones, so opening loot, getting random attributes/diseases, and exploring the dungeon isn't an option because of the higher negative chances each step. I get it's supposed to simulate a more realistic adventure experience centered around realistic stressors, but it translates to ACTUAL stress. Once you lose your whole team of your highest level crew on a lvl 1 mission, you just don't want to play it anymore because starting from scratch with essentially the same kind of fighters isn't a fun challenge; it just becomes grindy.

An excellent game both mechanically and thematically exploring the concept that "the parts make a whole, for better or for worse".  Read the tooltips, experiment, don't ignore the multiple mechanics and you'll figure out how to compound enough small advantages to overcome even the greatest odds.  Meanwhile, the narrator delves further and further into his own sordid history and the circumstances that lead to the current predicament.  Easily a contender for best turn based RPG combat of all time.

A game that seemingly created its own genre upon initial release, and has since released multiple DLCs and a sequel - Darkest Dungeon is like if Battle Chess characters from the 1990s left the chess board and all got super into Lovecraft-ian lore. The look and feel of this game immerses you in a world of dread and finality, while giving you numerous chances to face beasts, villains, and unholy creatures from the darkest part of the human psyche in a turn-based delight. Highly recommended for those who love games that can steal away hours as you grind and test your mettle against RNG and other flips of the percentage coin.

It's a stretch to call Darkest Dungeon a role-playing game. It's a game, certainly, but I can't remember ever once feeling like I was engaged or role-playing in any personal way when I very impersonally weighed the pros and cons of hero management or decided where to spend my upgrade resources. It's an adventurer-management sim with you "role-playing" as the inheritor of a terrible legacy which largely consists of feeding meaningless identical "toons" into a grid-based meat grinder (that owes more to B.F. Skinner than it does Lovecraft), until luck and RNG-selection leave you with a party capable of tackling the fairly punishing and ultimately unrewarding endgame.

This entire experience feels more like an exploration of the concept of just how little gameplay one can invest into delivering on a game's premise. Do you actually explore a dungeon? Naw, just make it abstract screens and "event nodes" on a grid. Well-written characters? Let's see if we can get away with just one (The Ancestor) rather than giving the "heroes" any personality or histories beyond vague traits. Plot progression? Erhm, well, let's not go crazy here. World-building? A touch.

I guess it turns out I'd rather be playing an actual dungeon crawler than an abstract simulation of one.

Credit where it's due: the art direction and sound design are great and the turn-based combat is fun...for a while, but the limited enemy variety in each zone makes every area feel really samey, really fast.

Do I regret my time with this game? A little. Is it worth your time? Maybe so if you actually want to play a "roguelike" adventurer-management sim with great art and sound, then have at it!

Darkest Dungeon is an incredibly challenging but equally satisfying game to play through. At first glance the game seems incredibly simple with a four hero team with each hero having 4 unique abilities but that barely scratches the surface on what Darkest Dungeon is. Most people will look at the game that way and come to the conclusion that its a RNG grind fest that is more equipment than skill based and that's exactly why less than 3% of steam players have actually beat this game on the standard difficulty. If you give the game a chance and push through the harsh skill curve than Darkest Dungeon is one of the most engaging and satisfying games on the market and it's already 4 years old.

The ring of hard-edged steel and pleading whispers resonate through the darkened halls, almost sinister with promise. Always leading us and solemn, Balian feared not the horrors that slither over the strangely smooth stone. His life was one of luxury, torn asunder by the creeping disease wracking his existence. Veriel's razor sharp daggers and even sharper eyes made sure no treasure or crumbled earth left unturned. Her dark humour almost fitting to the labyrinth we wandered through...she was my favorite. Priest Illith never far behind me, quick to care and even quicker to light a new torch. The gods had fled these lands, but they still hung over her providing cheap respite for us heathens. 

The days had passed and halls blurred together, when we gazed into the darkness...it too gazed back. Screeching flesh, gnashing teeth, and scuttling terrors overwhelmed our camp. Balian stood fast and cleaved through the beasts, sending them back to the abyss that bore them forth. His bronzed plate deflected blow after clawed blow as they tore him apart. A pooled mess of tattered cloth and broken steel was all that remained of him. Illith tried desperately to sustain us as we fled through the eldritch arcades beneath the manor. She fell too...as did our torchlight. As the blazing light of day pierced through small holes before us, we tore at crumbled stone and encased bone. As I heaved the last boulder away, a tentacle wrapped itself around Veriel's leg and wrenched her from my grasp into the growing blackness. Her screams filled existence as she disappeared from view, I ran bleeding and weeping into the safety of daylight. The tavern and endless mugs of ale are lonely once more, but I do not feel alone...her screams are always with me.

Reynauld and Dismas were a unbreakable duo. Ever since the Old Road, every expedition into the maddening realms of the estate they took, they took together. The shared an unbreakable bond- never straying from each other's side. Together they slew the evils that lurked in the shadows; one after another. They virtuously fought even the thing from that unspeakable comet, always cutting losses, regrouping, and returning even stronger. That was, until one fateful expedition into the swine-folk's lair. Early on, they were ambushed by a maddening beast, who single handedly drove the vestal to a heart attack. This was unfortunate, but my overconfidence drove me to press on with only the occultist as a healer. The three marched forth, felling all in their path, though not without grievous injury. Despite the unsightly madness all around, and with the occultist falling to madness, Reynauld remained virtuous and courageous. He was in good health, and mentally steeled for the challenge. But when they ran against one particularly bloodthirsty fiend, the tide turned for the worse. Crit 68! Blight! Reynauld is on death's door! 
"Shall this battle be my last?"
Deathblow!
Dismas's resolve is tested...
Hopeless!
"The things I've done. They pale by comparison..."
Dismas fled that cursed labyrinth, the occultist close behind.
I couldn't bare to lose Dismas. He retired in a sense, only ever going out on the odd farmstead mission.
The loss of Reynauld made me quit for a week, but evenutally I returned. Many hours later, I was apon the final boss and end of my campaign. One last time, I placed Dismas in my party, giving him Reynauld's Hero's Ring that he had had from the very start.
And he was the last one standing.
On the Old Road, Dismas found redemption.

I was on the fence about this title for a while. It's a goodish game. It has neat elements. Kinda a 2D extraction survival type game which I think is neat. But it lacked a certain depth that I couldn't quite put my finger on. It's simple to a flaw.

One of the main differences between this game and others is the Stress System. It's kind of a health metric. If your adventurers get too stressed out, bad things happen.

I like that idea on paper, but the application leaves a lot to be desired. You end up having characters in desperate situations that refuse to receive the support they need to survive. That's part of the stress system. They can be so stressed out that they refuse any form of aid, including counselling (which will reduce their stress). So as the player, you're left to watch a situation devolve into a disaster with zero ability to effect the outcome.

Taking control away from a player is rarely a recipe that results in a quality game mechanic.

The realisation that this game is not for me came after a stupid battle where everything that could go wrong did go wrong and I ended up suffering some loses. The specific losses were not irreplaceable, but the circumstances surrounding them were unacceptable to me, so despite my hatred to do so, I attempted a save scum mid mission to get a restart.

Upon loading back into the game, I found myself mid mission with all casualties still dead. Already on the fence about whether I liked the game or not, that pushed me over the edge. That was the end of my time with Darkest Dungeon and my 50 hour play through. 

I play video games to have fun. Being challenged is part of that fun, but not all of it.  In certain regards this game seems to want to be challenging at the expense of being fun.

Darkest Dungeon is a punishing, at times bleak game, and it's not afraid to rip your beating heart out of your chest and hold it in front of you, tauntingly. But despite its sadistic edge there's so much to appreciate, and it's easy to overlook some minor grievances. The art is beautifully twisted, the presentation slick across the board, the combat deep and engaging, and the city management adds a thoughtful strategic layer on top of what's ultimately an outstanding tactical RPG.

PROS:
✓ Excellent city and party management
✓ Spectacular art direction sells this grim world
✓ Gratifying play that rewards cleverness
✓ Deep, evolving play that encourages broad strategies
✓ Foreboding atmosphere sets a gripping tone of hopelessness
✓ Narration in the game, provided by Lovecraft interpreter Wayne June
✓ The music is delightfully evocative, and the sound effects are top notch
✓ Tens of hours of potential playtime, with almost infinite replayability
✓ 18 different classes to choose from (including DLC heroes)

CONS:
- Interface can be overwhelming
- Death and failure are frequent companions
- RNG is king here, and not usually in favor of the player
- Customization of your characters is very limited, with very few "true" RPG elements

The satisfaction you get from winning even after you lose a party member is really satisfying. 

What I would add, however is that the difficulty in this game is incredibly dynamic. If you start doing good then the boss of the dungeon will exclusively get crits against you. I was trying to die to test something and it was incredibly hard to die. It really makes the difficulty feel incredibly artificial and I would say that you should go into this for a lovecraft vibe and a good turn based game.

Also I highly recommend modifying the game or downloading mods to make it more fun. Tweaking character abilities is some of the best fun I have with this game.

After a break and some mental preparation I came back to the game with the mindset to not care about any unit below level 3 and that's allowed me to start truly appreciating the game instead of only being angry at it. 

My main issue was that I always played with the goal of losing as few characters as possible; so I went through every dungeon putting maximum effort into preserving lives and I would spend all of my money on reducing sanity and removing disease, which made the already slow progression of the game reduce to a snail's pace. This also made it so that when I did finally end up losing characters I lost a lot more due to the money put into them leveling their equipment and skills, which ended up infuriating me when combined with the massive stress I put myself under by trying to keep everyone alive and sane.

Now playing the game the way it was intended, by only investing in characters once they've been through enough dungeons and leaving the worse ones to leave or die, I actually have some fun with the game. However the meta progression of the game is still extremely slow and to actually build up a team of characters that's level 3+ takes many missions because you'll be going through up to maybe 15 level 0-2 heroes to make a 4 hero level 3 team, and that's not even mentioning how long it'll take to make a team of level 6 characters for the final dungeon. On top of both of those gaining upgrade materials (heirlooms) for your buildings is very slow too, if you're lucky you'll get about 15-20 heirlooms in a mission but it takes ~20-40+ to upgrade a building once; and to build new buildings instead of upgrading existing ones takes 100's of heirlooms which by itself can take ~5+ [u][b]successful[/b][/u] missions on the [u]low[/u] end and ~15-20+ successful missions on the higher end. Keep in mind that the amount of resources you gain and the amount of time each mission takes is dependent on both the level of the mission and the length of the mission, with easy/short missions taking ~10-15 minutes and medium/medium missions taking ~20-25, and i'm assuming that hard/long missions would take 30-40 minutes; so missions get longer to clear the longer and stronger they are, making it take even longer than you would think to get permanent upgrades.

All of this makes the game feel much more like a very grind-y RPG than a rogue-lite to me; as when I think of a rogue-lite I think of a game you can complete on the first run if you're skilled/smart enough that has replayability in the persistent upgrades you can unlock, the different combinations of skills and equipment or characters you can use and unlock, the RNG on the types and numbers of enemies you face, and other randomization factors that make the game unique on each subsequent run without removing the potential for success with enough skill/strategy.

As a rogue-lite I still give the game 3/10 as it still technically fits under the whole "play from the beginning each time with persistent progression between runs" definition, but it doesn't allow for game completion without large amounts of grinding and play time even if you know what you're doing (you'll just take less time with prior skill, but still a large amount of time).
But as an RPG i give the game a 7/10 due to the potential for making different teams with different skill focuses and strategies based on the area you go to. The game has a heavy focus on knowing what options your heroes have available, what heroes go together well, what combinations of hero types makes up a good team, what types of enemies are in what area, what types of status effects are in what area, what types of status effects each type of enemy are weak to, and overall how likely it is for you to succeed with each action you take and how much reward you get off of it (risk/reward play). The score is lowered because of just how much time you need to put in to be able to finish the game and the fact that the vast majority of that time will be spent doing very similar and repetitive missions, with the only strategy coming mid-combat and in team preparation.

Recommended for people that like more strategy focused games that they can play by themselves for a very long time. Not recommended for people that want a purely skill based rogue-lite.

This game is way to RNG dependent and NOT fun to play. Sure, anyone who plays the game long enough can get a good string of luck and beat it. However, the majority of people will just get frustrated and quit the game because of its cryptic unintuitive stat system and the RIDICULOUS "Bad Luck" RNG. Any game which punishes a player who plays the game PERFECTLY, but loses solely due to a string of "Bad Luck", is a VERY poorly designed game. This game purposefully and dramatically ramps up difficulty and puts your party into infinite stun loops at random and unforeseen intervals. Requiring several hours for the player to get back to where they were prior. A good game like Dark Souls is hard, but allows the player to try again and learn from their mistakes because it is consistent and fair. Darkest Dungeon will seem very easy, and then just randomly and without explanation decides to make your Party go last every time, miss every attack, make all of your stuns not land, focus kill one party member, and wipe your party. I can NOT stress enough how random and unfairly this game can ramp up its UNFAIR difficulty. Its is NOT a fun game. It is NOT a fair game. It is NOT skill based game. It is NOT a strategy game. It is a SLOT MACHINE. Avoid this game.

Ruin has come to our family. You remember our venerable house, opulent and imperial. Gazing proudly from its stoic perch above the moor. I lived all my years in that ancient, rumor-shadowed manor. Fattened by decadence and luxury. And yet, I began to tire of conventional extravagance. Singular, unsettling tales suggested the mansion itself was a gateway to some fabulous and unnamable power. With relic and ritual, I bent every effort towards the excavation and recovery of those long-buried secrets, exhausting what remained of our family fortune on swarthy workmen and sturdy shovels. At last, in the salt-soaked crags beneath the lowest foundations we unearthed that damnable portal of antediluvian evil. Our every step unsettled the ancient earth but we were in a realm of death and madness! In the end, I alone fled laughing and wailing through those blackened arcades of antiquity. Until consciousness failed me. You remember our venerable house, opulent and imperial. It is a festering abomination! I beg you, return home, claim your birthright, and deliver our family from the ravenous clutching shadows of the Darkest Dungeon.

Darkest Dungeon is an interesting beast. A rock-hard RPG with unforgiving systems designed to make the game an uphill battle. You will lose, you will die, and you will wonder what went wrong. To be frank, the game is rather unfair, and yet, I cannot seem to stop playing it.

Darkest Dungeon is a turn based RPG with position based gameplay. That is to say that you make a party of four heroes, each filling one of 4 slots, and they each can only use certain moves in certain slots on certain enemies in other certain spots. Each hero has unique attacks, functions and general roles within said party, meaning that party composition is paramount to success. Each hero has different quirks and stats which affect how they function. Each hero has their own stress meter which fills up as the horrors of adventuring mount, causing negative debuffs which can be game ending if not managed. Each area has a different feel and theme of gameplay, meaning that there is no ideal party, and each enemy and boss is it's own challenge. Many take issue with RNG in the game, which is an understandable issue, although, I believe  the RNG can be fully manageable if prepared for, and that is part of what makes it so compelling.

Darkest Dungeon is the kind of game that either grabs you or pushes you away, you'll know almost immediately whether you'll be continuing.
“Many fall in the face of chaos; but not this one, not today.„
Where there is no peril in the task, there can be no glory in its accomplishment.

Darkest Dungeon (DD) is a game that will either grab you from granted or make you abandon it for bull**it during your experience, so when I'm thinking about how to make a review of it, I can easily say this: DD definitely isn't a game for everyone.

DD is a rogue-like RPG game with some horror elements where you assume the role of a contractor that hire several heroes in order to purge a homestead from bandits and eldritch-like horrors in order to honor your ancestor, you do that by recruiting some characters and sending them away in randomized-size dungeons to fetch treasures a clear monster that dwell in it. To make that happen you not only hire your group but also manage its equipments and resources in order to raise your chances of success in each adventure, then the group of heroes delves into the respective dungeon in a side-scrolling like interface where it deals with not only monsters but darkness, tension, diseases, traps and anything that fits the medieval adventure trope.

The thing is, despite this game mechanics being simple to learn, the RNG elements on it that ranges from critical hit on attacks to find loot, gets in your way in a very aggressive fashion that may frustrate a lot of your progression and will to go on with it. It wasn't rare the instance on my group was on the edge of being finished by a non-boss enemy and a series of "misses" made me pull the group out, while loosing a character, and having my whole progress in that stance being lost. Sure, it also relies on your knowledge of the game and how do you approach each challenge by somehow planning ahead and deduce what will come for you on that expedition, but still I can sometimes see this issue as a non-organic way of the game to present challenge while "breaking" some of its concepts, being that it stacks some factors against the player even from the beginning. The above may give me some genuine frustrating moments on the game, but I can't say that it was enough to detract me from the experience, even thought I can see a more casual or less enthusiastic player abandon it for the very reasons stated above.

Despite that, I can easily recommend this game for any RPG lover that seeks some more direct approach on combat or just someone who likes to have some experiments regarding builds and some tactical combinations from other gaming genres. I do not possess the expansions (since I got the interest in this game only now) neither I have played with the mods on the workshop (by the look of them and the number of different content, I assume that this game is very modable and the community seems to uphold that, maybe I will check it out in a next playtime in the future). Do not buy this game if you are not ready to face (un)deserving consequences of your choices. (8.5/10)

Cheers,

Lycan

Edit: I bought the "Ancestral Edition", a bundle that have all the expansion on it so let's go to the following

The Shieldbreaker is a new class that whose specialty relies on the front-line dishing damage on high armored enemies while also being mobile on the battlefield. While I kind of like the concept, I don't think that it justifies being a solo DLC, and it should have been integrated with another expansion. (5.5/10)

Crimson Court on the other hand is a solid expansion that bolster several aspects of the game, it delivers a new class, the Flagellant, a strange front line character that relies on self harm while also focuses on dealing constant damage over the turns and requires some building and tactics to push it's potential from "weird" to "good and useful"; The new campaign is focused on the challenges the Crimson Court, a somewhat vampiric wannabe horrors that once were hedonistic noble humans, now they return to the lands of the hamlet in order to install new and gruesome games to satisfy these needs. The courtyard have a few maps to fool around while also offer 3 *very* long and repeatable maps in order to challenge each of the three court members, also giving new enemies and what I consider a divisive factor in the gameplay: The Crimson Curse, a debuff that most likely will hit your heroes making the challenges harder and somewhat more "unfair" (sometimes I wished to punch my screen on frustration due to this condition). Despite that, if you are looking for a greater challenge that wasn't felt in the base game (I doubt that someone on their senses would claim this), this one gives enough content to keep you fresh on it. (8.5/10)

The Color of Madness is...weird. It relies in an endless survival dungeon where you face eldritch-like horrors in a progressive fashion where you either pull your character off or let them die to the beings that dwell on it. It introduces a couple new bosses, trinkets and the aforementioned gauntlet-style dungeon to play, which I found...lackluster compared to Crimson Court. This one adds something for the game, but I felt that it was quite poorly implemented, like a great but rushed idea, still it gives enough to claim being an expansion, but underwhelming if compared to its sister product (Seriously, they should have merged the Shieldbreaker in this one to make it worth the price). (6.5/10)

[h1]Disclaimer[/h1]
I finished the game in the quickened "radiant" mode.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
I've seen people summarizing Darkest Dungeon as a 10h game stretched to 100h of playtime. My playthrough was only about 40h, but I played in the faster "radiant" mode which accelerates the progression, and I was still getting bored around hour 15.

I don't recommend it. It's a grindfest with tons of RNG that will force you to do even more grinding if you get screwed over, so you get double-punished for any RNG failure. The parts of it that are genuinely good are not worth the time commitment this game demands.

But take my opinion with a grain of salt. This game has a massive cult following and me not liking it doesn't change that, so maybe it's worth giving it a chance. But if you end up hating it - drop in a comment here, so I can at least see that I'm not alone. I feel like it takes a specific person to enjoy it and I am not that kind of person.

[h1]Description[/h1]
In Darkest Dungeon you will watch over attempts at purging evil from a mansion and it's surroundings by hiring heroes, commanding them on expeditions and rebuilding the hamlet.

During expeditions, you can move around a dungeon, explore for items and fight enemies. You command up to 4 heroes and all of them will have 4 skills. Your heroes are organized into a column formation and different skills may only be used from a specific spot. For example in order for your healer priestess to be able to heal - she needs to be at the back 2 spots of the formation, but if you want her to be able to hit things with her mace - she needs to be in the front 2 spots. Moving your heroes around and keeping them in correct spots to maximize their effectiveness is key to survival. Your enemies will be using skills to force your party members out of position, so having means to move them using their own skills is a good idea.

Combat is turn-based, with all characters having 1 action they can use to use a skill or move around forward/backward in formation. Attacks will deal damage, apply debuffs or damage over time - the usual RPG stuff. Different enemies have different weaknesses and tactics, but specific areas of the mansion will have themed monsters that you will learn to build your team around. One area may be filled with enemies that are weak to bleed, but resistant to blight damage, while another may be the opposite.

You also have stress mechanic. Most enemy attacks and even exploring itself will put stress on your heroes. Too much stress and they may break, making it difficult for you to finish the mission. You can always retreat in shame to fight another day - at least you retain all the loot you already found.

Once back at hamlet - you can use acquired loot to upgrade various buildings, like Blacksmith who makes upgrades to equipment, or Tavern, which heals stress. This is the main way to progress within the game - embark on expedition, get loot, upgrade Hamlet so that next expedition is easier and cost of healing your surviving heroes is cheaper.

As you complete missions in different parts of the mansion - you will unlock boss encounters, which need to be tackled in order to unlock access to future ones.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[b]+ Style[/b]
Dark-fantasy comic style is very fitting the idea of delving inside dungeons filled with things that murder people.

[b]+ Atmosphere[/b]
It's heavy and desperate. The voice of narrator really helps bring everything together. His comments reveal backstory, offer encouragement or mock your failings.

[b]+ Mechanically sound?[/b]
I guess? It must be doing something right when it comes to mechanics, since I didn't hate it for the first 15h and later I got bored not because of the mechanics, but because of constant repetition.

Learning what game has to offer is pretty fun. It's just a shame that there's all-in-all not that much to learn at all.

[b]+ Mods[/b]
This is the only reason I might play another round. There are all kinds of mods, from QoL features like bigger stacks of items or new classes to mods that add spice in from of nudity. You can turn most monsters into half-naked anime waifus if you so desire.

Really just for that this game gets a +1 to the score, as we all know - tits make everything better.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[b]- Padded[/b]
Between grinding for upgrade materials/gold, grinding away at hero levels, replacing dead ones and unlocking access to new areas - this game requires a lot of playtime. There is not enough unique content to warrant this amount of repetition in a tactical game based on RNG. Darkest Dungeon relies solely on novelties to keep me interested, and you hardly see or experience anything new after first 10h, but you still have at least 3x as much game in front of you. Even bosses are reused several times over.

[b]- RNG[/b]
This game's challenge is solely based on RNG and preparation knowledge. Once you know what heroes, skills and items to pick - there's little in terms of tactical decisions to make during actual combat. Most encounters are trivial if you picked correct party and there are party setups that can deal with pretty much anything in the game, so there's little reason not to take them if you're unsure of what's coming. Bosses require a bit more specific setup, but knowing that requires you to throw your best party in blind and hope for the best.

So what you are left with for challenge is just RNG, which can screw you over at no fault of yours. Many times you will have to retreat from the dungeon before completing the objective, because RNG can push your party beyond the point at which it's reasonable to continue. There were points where I lost an important hero to a bad RNG string and that resulted in having to retrain a new one in their place, which pads the game even more. It can take many hours to bring a new character up from 0 to max level.

You cannot win with RNG. You can try to mitigate it, but it's always there, looming over you, waiting to drop onto you like a ton of bricks. And when it does and you end up losing a hero or two - you get set back for hours of grinding.

[b]- UI[/b]
Grid inventory is unnecessary since all items take same amount of space. Hamlet's roster of heroes gets incomprehensible at some point when you have too many.

[b]- Story[/b]
As straightforward and predictable as it gets. There are very few mysteries to uncover and most of it isn't very interesting. Writing is passable at best.

[b]- Items[/b]
Tons of bad items and obtaining good ones is based on RNG, prolonging the grindfest.

[h1]Lowdown[/h1]
Really the main issue for me is the padding combined with RNG difficulty. If the game was less padded and didn't punish you with hours of grind for a bad string of RNG - I'd probably be less bored with it. Unfortunately making a game like this - a simplified turn-based classic-positional-dungeon-crawler RPG - makes it so it cannot by definition rely on skill. It has to be knowledge-based difficulty, where the only thing stopping you from winning is how much you know about what you will encounter.

So... while I do think Darkest Dungeon does a lot of stuff right, mainly it's core mechanics, I also have to say I didn't have much fun for the majority of it's elongated playtime.

I'd give Darkest Dungeon a
[h1]7/10[/h1]
This score may be misleading. I rate games based on how well they achieve what they set out to (usually, sometimes I just don't understand what the game wanted to be at all). But I still don't recommend it - why? Because it's a huge time sink and most of it was not fun for me. Just repeatable tasks with same 2 or 3 parties that worked for me over and over again until I finally had enough items and upgrades to tackle something new.

This is the most stressful game I've ever enjoyed. There's a lot of things done right in this game.

1. The atmosphere. This game will suck you in. The theme and mechanics mix perfectly, putting you and your team on a mission where pushing your luck is fraught with danger but is needed. Desperate times and all that. And who can forget the narrator? The narrator is the best thing in this whole game. 

2. The mechanics themselves. I normally don't like mechanics that include a chance to miss. Having a great plan and having it foiled by dumb luck feels bad. This game makes it work. The whiffs are rarely game ending, (though there is always that one), and play to the atmosphere the game creates. They're even offset by how good this game makes a Crit feel. It's visceral, and you, the narrator, and your team will rejoice.

This game is great. Turn based combat feels good, animation is iconic and well done, atmosphere is off the charts, and team structure allows for both creativity and strategic planning. With a good plan and a good team, success is clearly in view.

Or is it merely a trick of the light?

...OK but seriously the narrator (and the game) is fantastic.

Ruin has come to our family. A perfect "dark" game to enjoy, a few clones emerged, which speaks for what's it worth. Two blood relatives arrive at what appears to be leftover ruins of their family heritage. Despite huge differences between them, your goal is to lead them to the very end. You command up to 4 mercenaries in turn based combat, that will search a couple of areas in search of family heirlooms, riches and plenty of fights, until they are strong enough to take on Darkest Dungeon. You will face several types of enemy families like undead, beasts, humans and abominations. Needs of your mercenaries and their sanity are also a factor. Maybe it's cheaper to kick them out once their end their usefulness?
