[h3]SNAPSHOT[/h3]
A Lovecraftian game built to mirror the stress and sanity loss between the player and the characters in the game.

[h3]OVERALL - 6 / 10[/h3]

[h3]PROS[/h3]
+ great atmosphere / aesthetics
+ satisfying meta progression

[h3]CONS[/h3]
- huge emphasis on very poor RNG
- game is balanced heavily against the player early on
- gameplay gets repetitive quickly

[h3]FULL REVIEW[/h3]
I'm going to say this up front: I save scummed the shit out of this game, and I don't feel one iota of remorse. Overall, the game has a lot of fun elements to it, but the fun parts are dwarfed by the stress and frustration that it creates due to poor design choices, mostly those that were added post-alpha. Pre-alpha the game was a lot of fun, often pitting the player into darkness but giving them eventual hope and opportunities to climb out of it. Post-alpha the player is pushed into a well with no rope to climb back up. The game is built to be challenging, but what Darkest Dungeon delivers is an iron maiden of epic proportions: the more you play, the more you bleed out what little energy you have left to come back and get slapped in the face by the massive amounts of RNG you have to rely on.

Darkest Dungeon pits players against a perpetually stacked deck, which only gets worse the longer you play. The game is built to put the PCs into a dying state quickly and often, which is compounded upon by the heart attack mechanic. Introduced sometime after alpha, and a longstanding point of contention, heart attacks cause a PC to instantly enter a dying state, regardless of health, or die permanently if they are already dying. Because of this, often times the game ends up chaining multiple events together that can easily wipe a party, regardless of how well you are doing.

Sanity loss for PCs leads to afflictions, which basically makes the given PC suicidal for the rest of the dungeon. More often than not an afflicted PC will skip their turn, refuse healing, shift the party order around, or somehow injure or debuff themselves. It would be one thing if an affliction only caused one of these things, or even if there was a limit as to how often they could happen, but instead they often happen in succession, which causes other party members to lose sanity and gain an affliction, and the cycle repeats. This quickly leads to an entire party wiped because 75% of your turns are either skipped or used to re-arrange heroes because they can't do anything else (not even defend). This is, in short, not fun whatsoever.

Aside from the in-dungeon frustrations, the game also has a level restriction on those that can enter the dungeon, with PCs claiming that they "wouldn't learn anything from the experience", or some other ridiculous reasoning. This is actually probably my biggest gripe, even moreso than heart attacks. This level restriction makes it extremely frustrating to try and level up other heroes to replace the ones that die or are otherwise unable to function for the dungeon. Unfortunately, it appears that the lowest level dungeons are also the least well balanced, so the player is forced to trudge through them again and again, re-living the nightmares they thought they had previously overcome.

Overall, I do like Darkest Dungeon, when the dice are in my favor. When they aren't (which is ~75% of the time, it seems), the game is just an unending stream of frustration. The thrill, charm, and balance this game had with heroes constantly teetering on the brink of death in pre-alpha has given way to the hopelessness and malaise introduced with the post-launch changes, and given that I play games to relieve stress and have fun, this is the opposite of the desired result. As such I cannot recommend that others willingly subject themselves to it, however if you do make sure you keep the lights on and bring a lot of torches.

Some games are designed to create fun moments. Some games are designed to create challenging moments. Darkest Dungeon was designed to create frustrating moments. 2 systems are at odds here, one asking you to not invest too much time or effort in each hero because they could die at any time, the other requiring powerful advanced heroes to advance through later levels. Where these two systems meet is your high leveled highly invested character dying with little fanfare for a reason that was outside of your control setting you back minutes or hours of game-time. 

You could focus on advancing the town to get more powerful heroes to start out with but the resources used to upgrade the town are drip-fed so slowly that you are all but forced to advance characters as you farm materials and will inevitably end up losing time and effort to a death that may have been unavoidable. This being long before they are reasonably 'replaceable' to the degree the game seems to expect them to be because you are always behind the curve, leaving you at a painful deficit that means you end up losing whatever momentum you had going and have to go back to doing boring 'easy' quests just to grind up new heroes to take on... maybe you can see the problem with the overall gameplay loop now. It's not based on fun, it's based on pain. I don't have any problem with difficulty, I've played tons of difficult games in the past, but I've rarely felt so out of control and frustrated in any of these experiences. I feel no desire to better my 'skill' or to be frank try again and pray for better luck to take on the challenges, I just don't want to play anymore.

While Darkest Dungeon can certainly boast the content and fun moment to moment game-play I don't think the overall experience is worth it as the grind only gets worse the further in you go. Darkest Dungeon doesn't respect your time, so you certainly shouldn't respect it's.

an excellent turn based strategy game with lots of depth. you will never stop learning about this game, the skill ceiling is very high. many people think this game is too challenging, and i think this is somewhat overblown. the game will punish you if you're not prepared, and in the beginning you won't know much, but you will learn fast. losing characters is okay, do not get too upset, the stagecoach always comes with more new classes to try. half the fun of this game is building and trying new team compositions, so don't get attached to one class! (unless it's the leper). the short term strategy of each fight and dungeon mesh expertly with the long term strategy of building your hamlet, and all of the DLC is incredible.

the aesthetic of the game is really remarkable, there aren't many games like it. it takes a lovecraftian gothic horror, combines with the most interesting parts of history, and builds a vague story structure more focused on feeling than detail. the visuals of the wood-cut art design with such dramatic shadow are a perfect match. and the part that brings it all together, the incredible voice actor Wayne June narrating the highlights of your journey. you will be quoting the voice lines to yourself while playing, they're incredibly memorable and masterfully written.

truthful review here: darkest dungeon is a pain in the ass. The ideas and gameplay are really great, but the whole experience is bogged down by rng-heavy bullshit mechanics. Only play this game if you're prepared for a long grind, and potentially the death of your greatest heroes simply because the game decided that you should die. I can't imagine what the game would be like on hard mode. 

Darkest Dungeon is almost perfect, but I think it needs some more work in some places. The whole point of videogames is to feel powerful, to feel like you're growing and changing with time. That's the fun part. In Darkest Dungeon, you make so much progress only for your hero to get crit and die of bleed damage, causing your entire party to lose their minds and die of stress. 

tl;dr darkest dungeon is fun, though imperfect. look into backing up your save file.

The game sets up a barrier to entry for you to get over, which can be discouraging, but once you push through and start understanding the game's mechanics it starts getting quite fun. 

The gameplay loop starts to click and off you go dwelling into brutal dungeons, leveling up your characters to go through even harder dungeons or steamroll through easier ones to get some easy smeckels to upgrade your little town. At least that's how I experienced it and it was pretty nice. The game is unapologetically unfair at times but it fits well into the grim dark lovecraftian theme, you don't have full control over what happens just like you wouldn't in real life, you're just supposed to make the most of it, it's pretty immersive which I respect.

That being said, the game simply outstays its welcome. After a certain amount of hours it gets tedious and it never really feels as if you're making significant progress. You hit a wall and you're left to grind for trinkets and stuff so you can get the edge over the endlessly brutal dungeons to get some more loot and story exposition. The gameplay loop also gets old, you're constantly doing the same thing over and over, and while there's variety in characters and especially comps, it can't hold my interest in the gameplay loop.

I gave this game a chance and enjoyed my time with it, but when it stops being fun and I end up uninstalling a game I haven't "fully" finished (which I hate to do), I can't help but not recommend it. It's a really well made game tho, I'm just not into it enough to finish it.

I'm no stranger to actual roguelikes, and have too many hours in games like nethack and crawl where death means that you start over from scratch. And I might still have a D2 hardcore character around. Still death in those games almost never feel unfair, and you could see how you could have done things differently, and learn from that.

Now Darkest Dungeon has too many arbitrary restrictions in place just to waste your time. You can't do lower level dungeons with a high level character. You retreated from a specific battle, we'll just randomly kill off your healer. That's another 3h of grinding for your, lol. And if you manage to complete one of the final dungeons, all your heroes become retarded, and you will need to train up new ones. Because why not. And sometimes you just get unlucky, missing all your attacks, while the enemies lands multiple crits in a row.

While the game play can feel fun for a while, it doesn't hold up for the 100 or so hours it takes to complete the game.

I wish I could give this a Neither, instead of yes or no.

Lost 2 resolve 5 characters on a level 3 boss (the rest of the quest was a breeze) on medium difficulty with a bunch of mods to reduce bullshit factors. 

Definitely going update this if I ever find the game fun, but at the moment its just extremely frustrating and addicting. Yes, I know, this game is hard, but its not that its difficult, it just has a bunch of bullshit mechanics that require you to lose so much to do anything. 

Its so grindy without mods to the point where I'm obviously not even remotely strong with 20 hours of grind and over half of that was with mods that increase reward gains and give no penalty to swapping the 4 items for upgrades.

I get that bad rolls will happen, that bad planning is part of learning, and that you're supposed to make the most of a dire situation, but there comes a point where its just unfun. The rolls are anywhere between inconsistent and completely against you, even with high resolve characters.

Currently, I've tried to make the game less harsh by adding mods, stuff like no negatives to trinkets (I personally despise any game that does this, not just DD) and not gaining negative quirks on successful missions, to try to push me to actually complete quests. I've already learned from a lot of annoying mistakes, but in the incident above, there was no indication that was going to happen... at all. I already knew what the boss was, as it was level 3, and had a completely over-leveled group with gear and trinkets as best as I could possibly give them.

Ruin has come to our family.

You remember our venerable house, opulent and imperial, gazing proudly from its stoic perch above the moor.

I lived all my years in that ancient rumor-shadowed manor, fattened by decadence and luxury. And yet, I began to tire of... conventional extravagance. Singular unsettling tales suggested the mansion itself was a gateway to some fabulous and unnameable power.

With relic and ritual, I bent every effort towards the excavation and recovery of those long buried secrets, exhausting what remained of our family fortune on... swarthy workmen and... sturdy shovels. At last, in the salt-soaked crags beneath the lowest foundations, we unearthed that damnable portal of antediluvian evil. Our every step unsettled the ancient earth, but we were in a realm of death and madness! In the end, I alone fled, laughing and wailing, through those blackened arcades of antiquity, until consciousness failed me.

You remember our venerable house, opulent and imperial. It is a festering abomination! I beg you, return home, claim your birthright, and deliver our family from the ravenous clutching shadows of the Darkest Dungeon.

The Darkest Dungeon game tests your will to accept a challenge. Time, effort, resources, and victory can all be lost in a single battle. With a few simple game mechanics to learn and only four base maps to choose from the Darkest Dungeon provides a game that is easy to understand but will take hours and countless of your characters' lives to master. Claiming victory in a dungeon only means your party returned to The Hamlet with all of the members it set out with. The party returned with resources of plunder but also with afflictions causing disadvantage or masochistic tendencies forfeiting the "hero's" turn in battle.

Red Hook Studios describes this game as making the best of a bad situation and if you are unable to find pleasure in the chance of victory through great adversity then Darkest Dungeon is not for you. It is with my own graveyard over-following with the bodies of heroes I failed that I tell you, do not bring yourself to the Darkest Dungeon unless you can triumph in the face of adversity, watch your four bravest and strongest souls perish to the horrors in the manor and still consider it progress, or suffer defeat time and time again just by clinging to the smallest sliver of hope.

Darkest Dungeon is just a really fun roguelite  dungeon crawler.  It's grim an dark and you're trying all that you can to make the best of a   b a d  situation. I have great fun managing resources, estimating provisions, maintaining optimal Hero (and enemy) positions in battle, and managing the stress of the heroes as they dive deeper and deeper into the depths of the estate. (As well as managing my own stress.)  At times, it feels "Unfair, but in a fair way". The odds are stacked against you. And it is no matter of IF your heroes will see themselves six feet under, but when. And how many more must fall after them before  the task is done.

If I have to describe this game with one word, it is [b]UNFORGIVING[/b].

"No quarter is given". Worst part is there is no save (but you can work around that).

Everything else about this game is amazing - the Lovecraftian cosmic horror, the dark atmosphere, wonderful comic book style art, great voiceover... everything about this game is very unique.

My advice - read very carefully the text shown when the game starts. It's there for a reason. Listen to the advice in the game - it's relevant. Decide which heroes are expendable and which ones you want to keep.

P.S. Unfortunately I have to switch my review to negative. Too many CTD on Mac OS (Big Sur on Mini M1).

Game is both way too simple and complicated at the same time. The amount of time they want you to sink into grinding heroes is ridiculous when they are often effortlessly killed by things totally out of your control, like rampant RNG, which kills any strategic depth the game could have by making everything a crap shoot.

There have been tons of superior rogue-likes and dungeon crawlers and card games released since 2016. Just get one of those instead.

Just rage uninstalled after the Siren charmed my Highwayman despite me setting the battle up specifically so he wouldn't be targeted, all stuns fail, he crit one-shots my Grave Robber, which for some reason also brought the Highwayman to deaths door (still don't understand that part), everyone is bleeding and dies, losing lots of irreplaceable equipment in the process.

But if you have more patience with bad luck wipes than me (I admittedly have very little) and even if you don't, it's one of the most rewarding, unique gaming experiences around. The gameplay is addicting despite how unrelentingly brutal it is, the vibe is wonderfully dark, and it has one of the best narrators in video game history. I've yet to find anything else that scratches the same itch. The modding community is also fantastic. I'll probably come back in a few months like I always do. Can't quit you babe. I've been wanting to play this game for years and dodging information on how most of it works, I really like the concept, and while I'll still be keeping a try for game-design study purposes, I can't recommend it.

[h1] Art and UI [/h1]

The art style is frankly brilliant. It is unique yet familiar to anyone who has played darker settings or checked RPG art of dark stories. The animation in battle does a lot with very little, very dynamic.

I'd say the only real place where the art itself seems to blend is on the quests menu, it is pretty for an image, but as a map it is terrible, nothing is memorable, you don't remember where was your last mission unless you focus the green dots  you click like constellations.

UI-wise... I'm not impressed. Maybe it is my ADHD talking but... it sucks. Due to having so many details, I had difficulty finding what is just locked in the UI, what is just for looks, and what the game just didn't tell me it was there. This is very noticeable on the town, extending from the places, to how to make the character menus overlap and interact with inventory and so on.

In combat, it is even worse. Some might figure the equips and uses immediately, some don't, the major issue is how the spells have their effects listed line by line without context and you're just thrown to test them. The game sets you up for failure not because of difficulty but because you need to test them out, leading to a bad run. You just can't properly work with the information you're given until you get used to it.

It tries to save space on screen for no reason, using abbreviations and so on that you're supposed to know from reading about them elsewhere, on another menu.

A good example of a character I couldn't figure out how to work was the something-arbalest. All i could do was throw flares, i didn't know if i needed to buy ammo for the others to work, if i needed someone else to get a mark and i just fdidn't have them on team, or i just got very unlucky to not have a character with the mark spell unlocked.

4 hours in and I still don't know if I could camp or just didn't get there yet. I just could not find the button even when in the tutorial with the lodge i had to carry.

[h1] Combat and Level Design [/h1]

That one is the most disappointing. But let's start with the good first:

While characters don't have a personality, their quirks become rather interesting initiatives. Either them being masochists or deciding to take the lead to hit or heal someone, is nice. After you learn by testing how some skills work in movement, you very easily get into some combo ideas, and start repeating the classes you know to sit on the village so you can keep a solid strategy.

There is also a very clear decision that while many characters aren't made to deal that much damage early on, even tanky, heavy hitting characters can take a support build, and when a character is mostly a support, they become weirdly dynamic in the simple positioning of the game.

With that said, positioning being worth an action feels like a waste of time. Especially when characters can be fearful and retreat, or get pushed. The masked-bard that looks like a ygo card is great to prevent that (he'll move to the front and his finishing move makes him go back), but if your bruiser retreats, she is dead weight.

Sometimes very early on you're on a dungeon, you did everything right and you get wiped out because a lot of conditions and stuff. It happens very quickly and while the premise of the game is that you're not safe, not being communicated more clearly on why the difficulty curve suddenly spiked is very frustrating.

When the game is just being hard, however, the tension is perfect, you're carefully making moves, trying to keep everyone safe, dealing with the unpredictable and tracing patterns. You're not even frustrated with reinforcements of another 4 enemies or a critical hit. That seems to be the intention of the gameplay loop, and it is VERY engaging.

You really have to outweight the mission and the value of your characters, how much can they handle, so on.

[h1] What made me quit [/h1]


Heart attacks are such a random BS. I was on a great clear, with no character getting less than 70% of their HP down, they got stressed right close to the end (that was a very early, very brief quest), but I played worse, then suddenly on a fight with full buffs, no bleeding, no poison, not even worry because the HP of the enemies was very low at their max, Two characters have a heart attack.

Their HP went from 90% to 0, [b]I had no idea that was a thing[/b], I just thought something bad happened when the stress hit 200 points, but I wasn't even there.

I try to recover, fight a bit, but when I see it is a lost cause i manage to leave combat. The characters that were healed have a second heart attacks, and PERISH. Then the third character that was fine the whole battle suddenly dies from a heart attack.

This is very different from when a game throws you a curve ball or you're in say, a monster-house on pokemon MD. You're very early on, you're learning the game, and suddenly something you didn't know was possible ruins the flow of the game, you're not instructed on how to deal with this.

If I just lost because it was difficult I'd just grind my teeth and move on, but I don't want to be invest hours in a game that just feels like gambling because I didn't know something was a thing,

A few tips: 

Axe-lady is by far the most interesting character to collect, giving you several build options, odin-like warrior is a second close, and the tentacle guy is a great support, merchant sucks to heal but can deal damage very fast on the backline.

This game is so fun. 
It requires a lot of dedication and acceptance that things will not be good sometimes, but it's pretty easy to get back on track (just make sure you have at least a couple thousand gold). Each hero and enemy is meticulously handcrafted to feel exactly how they're supposed to. Every move, every design, every  detail is honed to the point where you don't feel like you're just managing expendable pawns, and you aren't discouraged from leveling or progressing in the game at all. 
The way each hero is tuned to accommodate the game's many mechanics (Chad Inspiring Tune Enjoyer) blends the game's strategy and plain old gung ho moments. Heroes will always die, but the feeling of journeying with each one, whether it be scrounging for artifacts on a quest (or finding 60 crests in a single run), having to painstakingly cure each disease your hero has, or fine tuning their equipment and moves to suit your bloodthirst, you really feel like you're making the game your own. Each quest, despite being the same explore/battle/collect system, is made so unique with each new encounter. 
The DLCs are perfect. They mirror the challenging yet rewarding feel of the base game 1:1. You can't even try to be bored, or stuck with this game. Red Hook thought of everything to the point where it pops up right when you think it'd be convenient for it to, like the crystal mercenaries or the ability to cure diseases while camping (just don't run out of gold. It's a bit tricky to bounce back from that). There's always new events and opportunities waiting for you, localized entirely in your quaint little hamlet and horrifying inherited estate. This game is amazing, and I couldn't've ever expected that such an outwardly foreboding game would be so incredibly enjoyable.

Starts out great, gets progressively more frustrating.

I'm not gonna go into detail about what this game does, the description (and other reviews) do a far better job...

One thing you need to be OK with before you consider this game is the concept of chance.
Sometimes the game feels out of your control. You can spend your time having fun micro-managing every aspect of your heroes and party, spending your gold on upgrading gear & skills and generally having fun with the game's RPG elements, only to have your progress wiped out by.... basically bad odds. Get "surprised" by a group you'd normally be able to take on easily ? A couple of "misses" at the wrong time in a close fight ? Sometimes your fate feels at the mercy of RNG Jesus, something i could not abide by.
Also, some of the Boss encounters are absolutely ridiculous and will frustrate the hell out of you. You'll see your best party just melt in front of you, losing all that gold you invested in training and all your fancy trinkets and all that time you invested into carefully tweaking every hero without actually understanding what more the game expects of you. 
One last thing to be aware of: you can absolutely screw your entire save over (usually if you run out of gold). Doing missions rewards gold but they also cost gold. Not only do you have to buy supplies for your mission but your heroes accumulate stress, contract diseases and/or gain negative quirks, all of which will cost gold to get rid of. You will have missions that you will lose money on, and a couple of bad ones in a row can easily bankrupt you, meaning you'll have to start the next on without any supplies, which in turn makes it more likely to fail and so on until you fall into a black hole of progression out of which you can barely dig yourself out of.

First of all, this is not my kind of game. I got it for free and decided to play it anyway.

I'm a lover of visual style, so I like to mention that first in a lot of my reviews.

Art style: It's like paper, everything is flat but positioned and animated to look somewhat 3D. Most of the side scroller games I have played look boring (except for the Lisa trilogy). This game looks decent, besides the surprisingly very simple and terrible home screen. I love the art style. It is very detailed and does a good job at creating a dark vibe.

Narrator: He is a bit repetitive, but at the same time, he says enough different things and he says some cool things. 

Details: Every hero has information and lore (A brief description) about them, and there is different information about them for each menu you are in. Unlike a lot of games, this game actually tells you a lot, there is even a glossary of terms. I like the dialogue the Heroes have. I don't think they actually talk to each other but they do just say shit every now and then. There are animations for characters just standing there and very cool animations for every single action. The standing still animation is just bobbing up and down but I don't know what else you'd do to make characters look alive. The plague doctor kind of looks like one of those women in silk clothes that do that side to side dancing thing with their hips (I don't know what you call those people). The plague doctor reminds me of that. I find the most random comparisons in every game I play. I could be playing a wholesome game and think - you know that one tiny detail reminds me of a horror movie. Then there's that one guy who is always leaning on his dog like he's a cripple that uses the dog for stability. He must have bad back problems because he never stands up properly. 

Other: Hotkeys, shortcut keys and the UI is all decent and helpful. 

Music: Repetitive, but good enough - fits the theme
Sound effects: Very good

[b]Other[/b]

One direction: I am not talking about that one boy band. I mean the characters hate moving to the left of the screen (they move slowly) and only face to the right. 
Font: The in-game title and header fonts are decent. Some body text is a bit boring.

The interaction range or whatever tf it's called could be better. I be spamming W sometimes and adjusting position until the object is actually interacted with. But doorways are fine - you get close enough and you can just go through

The option to continue exploring or gtfo out of the place pops up before you open the chest in the room. Le bruhski, that should pop up after. That would make more sense. Collect from that one chest then ask if the player wants to leave.

Also: Before I hover over the portraits of some heroes, it shows some kind of monster before changing back to the hero. That's creepy.

Nice idea in theory but far too much pointless RNG for me, when what passes for the tutorial level can vary upon completion from, completely unscathed and positive traits  to both characters picking up negative traits and being almost dead, that's simply too much RNG. That's against the same enemies using completely the same attacks.
When you combine this with very slow gameplay (waiting for combat to switch between characters) and load times I truly don't understand for a simple game this becomes an exercise in waiting, boredom, frustration and praying for good RNG.

This is truly a pity because with less of being completely reliant on good luck in dice rolls and less reliance on good luck in loot it (in 5 hours I never got a loot drop that was usable by ANY of my characters) might have been a great game

It's a bit fun at first, but it gets old very quickly.

If you wanna try playing something almost identical to it, there's a way to do it for only one cent. Simply flip the coin; if it's heads, you win and everybody is happy. Tails, you lose and you can try again.

Seriously, though, 90% of the game is dictated by dice rolls. There are certainly some levels of strategy, team building, and upgrades, but overall it's just dice rolls. Unlike good RPG's, you can't do much of anything to affect those dice rolls. It's quite possible that it becomes more affected by choice later on, but certainly in the beginning, choices don't matter at all. Why play a game where your choices make no difference? You get just as much enjoyment out of watching someone else play, because choice genuinely doesn't matter.

Instead, at every turn, I can't help but feel that the game actively doesn't want me to keep playing it.

Unique Art Style: The game's hand-drawn art style, inspired by 19th-century gothic illustrations, sets it apart from other video games. The detailed and intricate artwork creates a haunting atmosphere that fits perfectly with the game's dark and challenging gameplay.

Challenging Gameplay: The gameplay in Darkest Dungeon is notoriously difficult, which makes it all the more satisfying when you succeed. Players must manage their resources carefully and make tough decisions that can have permanent consequences for their characters. The game's RNG-based mechanics mean that even the best-laid plans can go awry, adding to the game's tension and sense of unpredictability.

Deep Lore and Storytelling: Darkest Dungeon has a rich and detailed backstory, which is revealed through cryptic notes and journal entries scattered throughout the game. The game's narrator, voiced by Wayne June, adds to the atmosphere and storytelling by providing ominous commentary on the player's actions.

Hero Customization: Players can customize their heroes' skills, abilities, and equipment to suit their playstyle, making each playthrough feel unique. The game's diverse roster of heroes, each with their own strengths and weaknesses, adds to the variety and replayability of the game.

Sound Design: Darkest Dungeon's sound design is exceptional, with eerie music, haunting sound effects, and the aforementioned narrator's ominous voice all contributing to the game's atmosphere and immersion.

Overall, Darkest Dungeon is a well-crafted game that combines challenging gameplay, unique art style, deep storytelling, and excellent sound design to create an unforgettable gaming experience.

Man, this game just fits everything I love about this style of game. I played for over 100 hours on Epic, and eventually just had to get the DLCs and everything on steam as well. It's strategic, ruthless, unforgiving, and frustrating. It's heavily RNG based, but balanced well enough that you can negate 95% of it with sufficient skill. For me, it goes up there with other strategy masterpieces like FTL, XCOM and such. And it does an INCREDIBLE job at setting up the atmosphere. Wayne June's voice lines have leaked into my every day life so much so that my friends and family start questioning my sanity from time to time. The amazing narration coupled with the terrific music and immersive artstyle makes Darkest Dungeon a masterclass in immersive atmosphere. Every lost and every win feels so much more impactful with the occasional gloomy commentary from the ancestor, together with the grim music. It's not a game for everyone, but it is a must play for anyone who enjoys the rougelike/turnbased/permadeath styles. Absolute gem, and one of my favorite games of all time.

Darkest Dungeon feels and plays like a cool dungeon delver but at 10 hours I constantly debated about not playing anymore.

- The game fails to keep me personally interested as I already have seen every talents/skill and acquired every class but one. (maybe)

- My characters get random negative debuffs at the very end of each mission which isn't explained how it was attained.

- Bettering my characters via weapons/armor feels like an unfair grind as I have to slog through dungeons over and over for GOLD which I don't find fun as I'm risking their lives to make them better. With GOLD.

- If you don't have proper knowledge of how sanity works, increasing roster size for carriage, stress relief, team management, you will find yourself restarting with new saves a lot.

- Now let's not forget gold management as to how on edge you need to be with spending, mainly because if you have a lack of gold you cannot get certain things which are required for doing more missions: Torches, shovel, food, etc. If you fail to have at least 6 torches, 1 shovel and 8 food you risk failing the WHOLE mission due to climbing stress, not enough light and losing sanity from clearing obstacles without a shovel.

(CONTINUED)  Let's say I send a team of 4 on a mission with 100% sanity and they are my only 4 heroes. I buy them 8 food, 6 torches and 1 shovel. That's more that 1000 gold, right? Hopefully the mission isn't too harsh and they come back with 6000 gold (high average for me) and all of them have medium to high sanity loss. I send 2 to the pub and 2 to the church (not 100% possible because of caretaker). Easy 3000 gold. One of them has a disease which reduces their stats by a lot. 750-1000+ gold. Reynauld is also a f*cking kleptomaniac but I cannot cure him for 1500-5000 gold because it would make me go broke. Due to him being a kleptomaniac I probably lost money and equipment that would've helped on the recent mission so that makes things worse. 

Do you get where I'm going with this?

Please understand that I like this game and it's provided content but I was trying to find a game that respects both player interest and player time, not be introduced to a possible pain fetish game.

EDIT:

I have decided after about another 20 or so hours of gameplay that i am going to change my review to a positive one. I decided to over obsess about figuring out team builds, studying peoples moves and how to create a solid team that meshes well with one another. Now that i have gotten the hang of building proper teams and figuring out how all the moves work (buffs, marking, healing ect.) I am having a MUCH more enjoyable experience. As of right now about 40 hours in i am finding that the only thing that is REALLY frustrating me at this point are my characters sanity levels. They climb so fast its difficult to keep sane and when they max out your character can die of a heart attack so its basically like having to manage 2 life bars. Aside from that.... not to shabby. I WILL recommend this game.

BUT OVERALL, I THINK "DARKEST DUNGEON" IS PRETTY GOOD. IT'S NOT LIKE THE BEST GAME EVER OR ANYTHING, BUT IF YOU'RE INTO GOTHIC RPGS AND LIKE TOUGH CHALLENGES, YOU'LL DEFINITELY ENJOY IT.

Darkest Dungeon is a challenging role-playing game (RPG). This is a game that offers players a glossary of terms used to describe its various mechanics. Exploring the Dungeons of the fallen estate evokes a sense of immense danger since you're never quite sure what traps or monsters could lurk around the corners. After familiarizing oneself with the game mechanics for a few hours, the game starts to reveal itself as one that offers plenty of depth for players to explore. In spite of its steep learning curve, this game can be rewarding for those brave enough to bear the challenge. However, the gloom and doomed atmosphere of this game isn't for the faint of heart. Personally, I don't always find myself looking forward to barely surviving the game's dungeons, if at all. However, RPG fans may be in for a gothic treat! 

This is a game that manages to feel fresh even after 10 hours of playing. This isn't a game that derives its challenge by simply throwing enemies with an unfair amount of HP at players. Inventory management, positioning, and equipping yourself with the right crew members all play a role in this experience. If you're looking for a mature and challenging RPG to enjoy, I'd recommend Darkest Dungeon.

This game favours grind above all else. The intro tells you that it wants you to "make the best of a bad situation" but what it doesn't tell you is that it will manufacture TERRIBLE situations that will ruin HOURS of your work and expect you to grind back through it. I wonder if they did enough testing to capture the fact that many people don't love grind, don't want to waste hours of their life, and that what they've created just isn't good enough to warrant that kind of investment. I spent much longer that I wish I had on this game, mostly cos I was killing time while waiting for my children to fall asleep. Don't make the same mistake I did and go spend your time and money on something that actually rewards you for what you put in (i.e. provides you some actual entertainment). This game is fun for about 30 mins, a massive grind for the next (hopefully not) 80 hours, and then delivers a massive F**K YOU as a result. I don't know why developers hate their players these days... maybe they needed to be hugged more.
I am not a masochist, but this game is both painful and enjoyable.

I've given this game many chances over the years and I've come to the conclusion that it is just not very good. At the start of a run it is pretty fun, but after maybe 10 hours it devolves into a repetitive and boring grind. You will be running the same few dungeons over and over again. Bosses get repeated several times each. A lot of dungeon layouts force you to do unavoidable backtracking through empty hallways for no reason. It is often correct to drag out combat for several turns to get a few extra heals off, since you can't use them out of combat. The game is hell-bent on stretching itself out and wasting your time. Contrary to what a lot of people say, it is not that challenging of a game. It is just tedious and overstays its welcome by about 50 hours. Difficulty is not the reason only 4% of players have bothered finishing a full campaign.

I would like to preface that Darkest Dungeon is not a game for everyone. The punishment of misplaying can be a bit too much for some people, and learning multiple complex game mechanics is not something many people are willing to do. However, although it took me a while to get into this game, I absolutely adore it. I do not consider myself an RPG fan, but this game is still incredibly enjoyable for me. The Lovecraftian theme of the game is amazingly immersive and grim, and will not get boring after hundreds of hours. The main mechanics are woven together so beautifully, and everything feels almost perfectly balanced. I think the best way to demonstrate is that there is over a dozen character classes, all playing completely different. and every single one is on par power-wise. The biggest problem beginning players seem to have with darkest dungeon is the RNG, but this is usually able to be solved with proper knowledge and planning. Sometimes however, you may not be able to afford that weapon upgrade, or the trinket you want from the trinket shop, and these little differences make up the challenge of the game. Almost every situation (spare the final area) can be made much easier with the proper forethought. There is always the risk of things going south however, and this makes the game feel constantly tense and exciting. This game is punishing. Very punishing. Losing hours of grinding because your strongest character died punishing. Oh yeah, this game has permadeath. if the character you sunk thousands of gold into dies you are not getting them back. Overall, Darkest Dungeon offers an experience like no other, and is one of my new favorite games of all time. I am incredibly excited for the sequel to release soon, and if you are interested in the game, it goes on sale for less than 5 bucks almost all of the time. Just stop reading the reviews and buy the damn game.

This Dungeon Crawler adds such a realistic touch to the idea what it means to be on a real adventure. No happy endings. No respawns. No one gets out unscathed. With a mature cartoon-ish style and clean sound and music design, this game will force you to make the best out of the worst possible outcomes. Good luck, adventurer.

Thanks to a friend showing me ALL the ways I was thinking about the game incorrectly, I'm now up to speed and able to dungeon delve successfully!

Trust me when I say, if you're failing, there's something that you're not understanding about the game.

The only complaint that I still have of the game is that the game loop is a touch tedious; I have absolutely no clue what to do to fix it, but there it is.

[h1]At first you will be ranting.[/h1] 

The features are confusing at first, the town as well, don`t know where to buy all your pagan stuff and other things. The game mechanics began to feel exaggerated for some reason. Too hard even on normal, as a cheap or out of control thing. It was so annoying that I was planning to thumb it down or refund.

Then "The Butcher's Circus" (some multiplayer form) keeps suggesting to activate DATA COLLECTION and popping up on screen. At first, it is mandatory to activate it. They let you deactivate it later, but it is obligatory all the same. Another corpo rat dictating what's best for me and my computer. After the game's success, someone decided to suck more money.

Then maybe by the destiny, astral congruence or some subtle CTD, I gave the game another chance. I can divide in 3 parts why I keep playing this. If you consider features report some sort of technical spoiler, then don't read it. But there is no story spoiler.

[olist]

[*]✞ This game is about imperfect heroes. An imperfect narrator describes some of your current actions, combat status and performance, yours or enemies`s, or things you do or take [b]with great voice acting.[/b] It feels specially satisfying when you do something right. Narrative is impressive, for many times I had this feeling I was reading those infamous interactive gothic books "if you choose right, go to page 40." Then, "The hero found nothing but death."  

Voice acting is only good on the original main game, the rest feels rushed. Like done in a hurry to please the business model wishes.

Time to roll the dices. The RPG is good thanks to the turn-based battles and this British, somber looking artwork staight out of some sick fairy-tale. It is cute and at the same time disgusting. Pretty much like Fable series artwork, only disgruntled. These things alone already makes the game likeable and playable.

[code]HP and mana is like all other games, but not like this original piece. Why I wasn't sniffing all that at first, I think I was suffering from anosmia. Battles aren't just based on lucky hits, or how many items you got on your inventory. You need some prep-work and other attentions but in a different way. If you're can't flow with the chaos, the unexpected, if you only count with planning, chances are you will fail.[/code]

Usually, big city gurls like me knows how to cope or deal or rush with chaos. Expect the unexpected. But without any planning you will also fall. Need everything, including common sense - and you will still fall. Just flow and see how you can dance. And then... Well, fall. 

I guess this game is about how expendable and glorious life can be.

[*]✞ For some outworldly reason, I managed to survive my first battle in "darkest" difficulty with only 3 warriors. I got angry and went back to replay it, I thought it was scripted. But this game is a survival in essence, it was my fault. So I tried again from zero like 5 times. I finally learned it, the core of problem solving is at the stress level.

I would feel proud with my victory, if the survivors hadn't all become a bunch of broken paranoid lunatics. Infected with phobias, psychological disorders, stress and unpredictable changes of mood. Even when a hero is good, if he/she grows up too broken, it will be better to retire/dismiss them than trying any treatments. There is inflation on the prices at some point you can't control. 

It is not random crap, it is all real. [b]Example;[/b] The light went off because I never bought enough torches. We had to fight the final fight in complete darkness. One of the 4 characters got used with it. After that, when there is light, she debuffs with it. It is mechanical, still can flows nice but hard as hell. 

[h1]When the adventure becomes a military operation.[/h1]

Think of the manor's state like how The Wall from GOT began. All types will end up at the outpost, or should I say death prison.

Preemptive measures aren't all that good, so you need to take care of them during battle and after battle as well. Maintain good relantionship on the team by camping. Find some funny traits, or avoid them and recruit them. Traits, negative or positive are up to your attention and strategy of how to better proceed.

1- Maybe you find a hero to recruit that has the "pep talk" trait. And curious abilities like smoking pot... I mean... "experimental vapours." Not all negatives are that negative.

2- Find one, or be lucky enough to maintain at least one possible platoon "leader", if he/she has speech traits or beliefs that may bring peace or order.

3- Maybe you find an entire group of good characters that can form a typical heroic band. Or the opposite and win the title of inglorious besterds. The combination can be surprising. 

4- You gotta evolve the town's size in the innards, for post-battle treatments or relaxation, gotta buy them by collecting treasures and money then using it on the town. Sometimes the mansion's caretaker goes in there town and uses one of the slots you will need, rendering it useless to use it. 

Expect British-like humor and sarcasm as you decay into the putrid abyss of the aged oblivion of the great nothingness, while the caretaker attempts to heal something like his sanity, he has probably already lost.


[h1]The Sanctity of this place has been fouled.[/h1]

Other games have tried that before, but just this little one made it into a complex battle penalties.

[list]
[*]A well fought battle and victory itself can really boost their minds and morale up as well.

[*]A hero won't always fall into desperation, some particular characters may brave the bad effects by themselves (but may lose it if you abuse it) helping the long-term. How cool does that sound? Others will disagree and get stressed, negativity can spread and debuff others, but the brave will be more buffy.

[*]But tough sonafabeaches are rarer. Usually when a character is really desperate or nervous, game over is around the corner. Funny how depending of the move, the opposite can change scenarios. A coward can get courageous and a brave can earn a phobia. Etc. Etc. 

If things keeps changing all the time, all the time, you're doing something wrong. Like stressing them on a over-level scenario or putting them in the wrong team's position. You gotta think, watch the penalties, go slow and do the pre-work.

[*]Planning is also needed when not in battle, that is where the war is actually happening.

[*]Characters can get to like or dislike each other, so just resting isn't enough.

[*]I appreaciate there is no main hero or main character, until you personally define by yourself some personal canon. Experienced survivalist characters may earn the proper badge, so it is really good when you keep them alive and sane (or not).

Who's the leader of the team for you? Who's the second hand? You can't lock that in-game but you can attach yourself some (thread your feelings carefully) I did that and I must say it helped me keep things right.[/list]

[*]✞ Music flows from ambience and dark undertones, to epic confrontations. It just fits perfectly in all occasions. Dude, when some indie game immerses you, you know you just bought some good s#*t . Animations are ranging from basics to hand-made but they are all pretty organic.

[code]Oldschool are going to be happy, as if Ogre Battle just had a sidescrolling little son. Also if you remember Tristam, well, the dungeons. The diablo under the church. It has been inspired by, but not copy-pasted, it is original by itself and deserves attention.[/code][/olist]

When I use acronyms such as LOL or LMAO I use them not to express humor, but my crippling depression. They are a silent cry for help from this dark void of sadness. I used to use them genuinely, but as time went on I found myself meaning it less every time I used them. How many people actually laugh out loud when they say "LOL," laugh their ass off when they say "LMAO," and roll on the floor laughing when they say "ROFL"? No one. This is the result of the pathetic world of lies we live in. As my depression grew stronger over the years I found myself questioning the true meaning of these acronyms when I used them. I decided they represent the mask of anonymous lies we live behind on the internet and since they are lies it makes sense that the user is experiencing the opposite emotion of what they actually express. I used these "humorous" acronyms on a layer of irony for several more years but no one noticed. No one paid attention to my wounded calls for help, my desperate cries for relief from this horrible life. I now seek to solve this problem on my own instead of relying on the cruel, heartless "humans" that dominate society today. Tonight I solve the problem once and for all, by ending my trial on the hell we call "earth." LMAO

Great rogue-like with round based combat. It has a dark fantasy dnd-esque style and you will be have many memorable (and/or frustrating) moments because of RNG. Also best narrator ever.

Way too much RNG to be playable for most people with a job or hobbies after hours of seeing "missed". The game prides itself on being punishing (which is a toxic trait copied from FromSoftware that they used for hiding bad game design behind blaming the player) but you would think that 'punishing' means that you're punished for mistakes that you make, when in reality you are punished even if you make every single correct decision that is possible which obviously becomes a pointless exercise in tedium.

To clarify, almost everything other than the RNG is wonderful in this game which makes it even more of a shame. But obviously if you are fine with insanely heavy RNG you'll likely love it.

Essentially if you like games that punish you depending on your actual actions (normal person) then you likely will grow tired of this game's antics.
If you enjoy games that make you spend countless hours making every perfect decision, full proof plans, amazing character builds and best upgrades just to say "your god warrior apparently missed due to the arbitrary dice roll and is now dead" (unemployed person) then you will like this game because you'll have something to endlessly fill the time you aren't spending productively.

If I was a teenager still I would be more lenient on the RNG in this game, but as an adult I just don't have time for a game to delete my progress even when I did everything right. 
It is the definition of a waste of time.

Darkest Dungeon is the ultimate test of your sanity and your ability to click the 'End Battle' button as fast as humanly possible. This game is not for the faint of heart - or the weak of mouse-clicking fingers.

From the start, you'll be greeted with a cast of characters who are either already completely insane or well on their way. But don't worry, you can always throw them into the sanitarium to be fixed - or just send them off to die in a hopeless mission. It's all in a day's work for a "Darkest Dungeon" player.

But don't let the game's punishing difficulty and unforgiving mechanics scare you away. There's nothing quite like the feeling of finally conquering a boss battle after weeks of grinding and rethinking your strategy. And let's be honest, the game's narrator is worth the price of admission alone. Who doesn't love being told they're in over their head by a gravelly voice?

In short, "Darkest Dungeon" is a game that will test your limits and your patience. But if you can survive the stress, the madness, and the occasional heart attack, you'll come out the other side feeling like a true hero - or at least like someone who's really good at clicking the 'End Battle' button.

I never really enjoyed Darkest Dungeon until my most recent attempt to get into the game.

It's still not one of my favorite game but I get it now. Like, it's very cool at creating an ambience and the actual fights, while very good, are only a part of it. Your characters are not perfect. The are flawed in a pretty human way. They will interact with certain things with no regard for their safety, the will steal, they will unsettle their teammates, they will briefly leave town or lock themselves somewhere. The whole game is covered with uncertainty which makes it so satisfying when you get a decisive crit or when a character becomes virtuous.

All of this is what made me frustrated about the game before and changing my perspective on this is what changed my mind. It's fair if you're frustrated by the game but if you wanted [u]just[/u] a tactical turn-based combat game, this might not be exactly what you're looking for.

Also for the love of god please just abandon an expedition if it's doomed and don't slaughter characters for no reason like I used to do.

I have had the same save, running from the beta of Darkest Dungeon, that I come back to every now and then when I'm craving it. 150+ weeks, and I still have not given a proper attempt at conquering the actual Darkest Dungeon ingame. I adore this game, even though usually turn-based combat is a dealbreaker for me, but the atmosphere, the context, the plot, the characters, the virtue system, the crimson curse, all of these things elevate this game beyond just a turn-based strategy game for me, and instead crafts a masterpiece. A cocktail of things I never knew I wanted, like crusading against eldritch horrors with the big two boys you start with, Reynauld and Dismas, upgrading and tweaking them as they go along, and growing attached as their journey continues. MOST importantly, what I never in my life thought I would love, is Wayne June as the Ancestor, and narrator of the game, who tells the tales of how the estate ended up a disaster, and encourages you throughout the game. Wayne June, is simply incredible as the Ancestor, and if you have any doubts about if you'll like this game, just listen to that man speak, frisson with every major voice line. If you enjoy his character, and are willing to put yourself through a tough experience, cause this game will not pull it's punches, you will seriously enjoy yourself.
Now, like me, you will begin to see things as they truly are

It's fun if you can stomach getting screwed over by nonsensical RNG and tedious grinding. Plenty of fun characters and mechanics. The setting is enjoyable as are the world's aesthetics. Too bad the game seems more intent on ruining the experience for the player over things they have very little control over. My Occultist healed for *0* for 5 consecutive turns--completely outplayed there! Not to mention the absolute chore of de-stressing and grinding through low level dungeons until your veteran crew is back on its feet. I get it, it's supposed to be hardcore. But I'd rather the difficulty come from actually being outplayed instead of random anti-fun mechanics that have very little to do with skill. If half the gameplay is hoping you don't get screwed over, I might as well pick up an actual strategy game instead of a random number simulator.

Once you're past the learning curve, this game is one long grind. You might enjoy the grind, but you probably won't. And after all this time, the game still kicks you in the nuts with the wrong kind of randomness.

This is a strangely addictive game.  You play as the owner of an estate who is sending groups of adventurers to clear out the evils unearthed by his ancestor.  As much time is spent managing the stress and quirks of the adventurers you hire as are spent actually fighting monsters, making this a sort of twisted resource management game.
This game causes me so much pain and sorrow... I love it.

Two abandoned campaigns and over thirty dead heroes later... Ninetysix weeks had passed on the final campaign. Fourteen headstones now littered the graveyard. But all bosses were slain, the darkest dungeon was cleared, and so the otherworldly corruption was finally stopped. Despite the hardships, I really enjoyed the 90ish hours it took for me to beat it. Darkest Dungeon is one of the best singleplayer games I have ever played!

One of my all-time favorites, owned it originally on GOG before buying it recently on Steam.

Unbalanced RNG trash.

When a game tells you to expect to lose recognize that the developer is saying this because they don't know how to make good games, and they are preparing you for the festival of suck that is the result of their failure.

The player has virtually no agency, the DM is god, and the DM harbors an irrational hatred of the player. Characters die and become emotionally crippled so easily that it isn't worth investing any resources in them. Every aspect of this game is tedious, every system is designed to draw out progression arbitrarily. The characters actions are limited by their position and their position isn't under your control.

One of my personal pet peeves is when a game includes a healing ability, but you can't use that ability outside of combat. What is the rationale here? The developer clearly wanted there to be healing magic, but they didn't like the logical consequence of characters that can actually heal each other, which is having full HP most of the time. So you end up with this completely useless class of healing skills that have no value whatsoever, because you can't heal enough to overcome the damage you take in battle, and you can't just use your mystical healing power outside of battle, and if you try to prolong a battle, monsters spawn constantly and your Stress level grows (Stress increments are like HP, you can reduce stress, but never more than the amount you get hit with). Every tool the game gives you is insufficient to match the problems and threats your characters face. If HP loss doesn't kill you, the Stress will. 

Saying that this is good game design is like saying you have a really great job digging ditches and the only tool you're allowed to use is a spoon. It's "challenging", but fair, because the task is technically possible. Oh and your boss is constantly shoveling dirt back into the ditches while you are in them. Yeah, that's real great. I love eating dirt and rocks while toiling under a blistering sun.

You can try to rationalize that there is something good here, but there really isn't. You can form a delusional mindset that makes you somehow deserving of the victories you experience... but it isn't the truth. The Truth is that if you just sit and roll  dice for long enough you're eventually going to see the result you want. You didn't earn it, it just happened.

If you can get past all of that, and more, you might start to enjoy the game...

Or it could just be that the madness lurking in the darkness has gained purchase within your own twisted mind.

I have really tried to like this game.

This has many elements I like - a gripping setting, turn based strategy and compelling character generation.  

It is ruined by it's crippling difficulty.  

I got the DLC on offer in case it made things better - nope.

Along with the usual couple of turns of bad luck crippling your game, it now drops dimensional attrocaties randomly into your encounters.  

It is just too frustrating - the only tactics that don't rely fully on luck are in the regional bosses.  And it takes a lot of effort to get that far.  

I'll be interested in the sequel but this way too hard to be fun.

Since the second game is coming to steam soon and some people will be looking to try the first game before then, i figured this was the best time to write my full review of the game.
(NOTE: you do not need to play this game in order to play or understand the second game. Like any predecessor, this game could help you familiarise yourself to the game play, but the second game is quite different to the first, and so it is not necessary. You can absolutely enjoy the second game to it fullest without playing the first.)

I could speak forever about every little detail about the game but ill try to just write what i feel i need to.
-Firstly: value. Is this game worth the price and time? Yes. It is a fantastic RPG that will test your abilities to think, form strategies, and most importantly, test your patients, and how far you are willing to press your luck. This price of this game is definitely worth the experience you will be getting when you play this game.
As for the DLCs, the musketeer DLC is practically worthless unless you feel like trying her out in the butchers circus( a free dlc), but all the other DLCs are 100% worth the pickup. What is also great is that you can integrate new DLC into old save files, so you dont have to create a whole new save in order to play any of the DLC. For this reason its entirely valid to complete the base game before buying any of the DLC, but if you wanted to purchase them halfway through a campaign, you could also do that.

-It is not an exaggeration when I say this game has changed me. The feelings I get when I play this game seldom are replicated in other games. I use to become emotionally attached to video game characters. You spend so long with some characters that you become sad when they leave or die. This game broke that in me. I had to learn to distance myself because every dungeon these characters enter could be their last. In fact, this game becomes much easier when you stop caring if less effective troops die for a bit of extra gold. These days, every character I play as i see as just 1's and 0's, and if they die or suffer, I dont care if it helps me progress that little bit more.
The stress mechanic is very interesting. Every time a character reaches 100 stress, they get an affliction check. At 200 stress, they have a heart attack, dropping their hp to 0. If their hp is already 0 upon reaching 200 stress, they die instantly. This means that hp is actually much more easily maintained than stress, and less meaningful to keep topped up. A low hp hero can do all the same things as a full hp hero, but a high stress hero is less effective than a 0 stress hero. Upon being afflicted, a hero will start refusing to act, picking their own actions, hurting your party, stressing your party out, move their position in the party, refuse to be healed or buffed, the list goes on. Not all hope is lost though, as every affliction check has a 25% chance of giving your hero a virtue instead! This is the opposite of an affliction, and that hero will start doing things that benefit the party instead. When you are facing a tough boss, and you're 30 minutes into a fight, your resources are exhausted, your Hero's health are razor thin, and your hope has faded, and now your hero has reached 100 stress. Surely now you will have to retreat and try again another time... right? But then you see the white light, your Hero's stress goes down, and Wayne June begins speaking and says: "Many fall in the face of chaos - but not this one. not today." and that one hero carries you to just barely win the fight... Its a feeling that to this day, I have never felt in any other game. On the other hand though, that only happens 25% of the time, so if you are willing to put in the time and the frustration of failing and getting back up again, it will be worth it.
-the visual art style of this game is great! Very compact and optimised, and I love it. everything in this game looks beautiful, but the music is the real rose of the art for this game. The OST for this game is fantastic, no matter what you are doing, you are listening the great music and ambience.
Of course, the narrator for the game, The Ancestor, voiced by Wayne June, really makes the game what it is. There is no reason this game needed a narrator, and yet, I cant imagine the game without him. He will amplify both your highest highs, and your lowest lows. I quote this game daily, its amazing.
-Every character in this game can work somehow, some way, doing something. This game is very well balanced, for both your Hero's and enemies. Though as you progress, higher level dungeons and difficulties will require better understanding of what works and what doesn't.
This brings be to the only 2 things I do not like about this game: The pacing and the difficulty progression. This game is slow. Your characters move slow, upgrades give very little individually, its only when you max things out and look back at where they started out that you realise how much better it is. Fights are slow, animation is slow, etc. There is no way around it: The base game is a huge time investment and it will get annoying how much time some things take to acquire.
I dont mind the difficulty but it is very annoying when every dungeon it seems like one of my characters has been designated the party's punching bag, when it should be more spread out. Or when 2 crits land on one character and a bleed proc kills them after only one deaths door check, and that character was level 6 so its going to take hours to replace them. there was nothing i could do to prevent such a thing. There is no way to predict when 2 crits and a bleed all in a row are going to show up. For all these reasons, its not uncommon the rage quit this game for a week or 2 before coming back and building back up. This game is hard but most times that is not a problem, but this game, more often than not, pushes all the wrong buttons when it comes to the rng and difficulty spikes you will experience.
-this game is open to the steam workshop so you can experiment with different mods at any point. I STRONGLY recommend faster walking and faster combat mods for all the reasons I mentioned above, other than that just have fun with it.

Is this game perfect? No. But its almost perfect and I love it. I could say more but that's really all I can be bothered to write. If you want a fun turn based RPG that will make you cry tears of joy and anguish, while expanding your vocabulary beyond what you thought possible, I strongly recommend Darkest Dungeon.

Darkest Dungeon has a unique vibe that I haven't felt in any other game; the sense of dread you can get when even the smallest thing goes wrong, the feeling of relief and triumph when beating a boss without losing any characters/having a flawless encounter and the utter despair when you know your favorite party is doomed and there's nothing you can do to save it. The game is unforgiving and leaves little room for error, you need to think and plan before and during runs, make sacrifices. Sound design fits the atmosphere perfectly, characters are diverse and fun and The Narrator's voice makes me wet. Soundtrack is also amazing.
Also, the modding community(the community in general) is really great. Definitely recommend trying some character mods and such after your first playthrough. Be weary though, some are very unbalanced.

"I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 16. My son recently started Dinkum and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories."

Darkest Dungeon is a masterpiece of a game that manages to successfully blend together elements of role-playing, strategy, and lovecraftian horror to create a unique and engrossing gaming experience. Set in a dark and foreboding world, the game puts players in control of a team of adventurers who must navigate through a series of increasingly difficult and dangerous environments while battling a variety of supernatural monsters. The game's narrative is presented through a series of journal entries and cryptic messages that slowly reveal the game's backstory and lore.

What sets Darkest Dungeon apart from other games in its genre is its emphasis on psychological stress and the toll that adventuring takes on the human psyche. As the player's characters explore the game's environments, they must contend not only with physical dangers but also with the emotional strain of facing constant danger and uncertainty.

The game is designed to be challenging, and players must carefully manage their team of adventurers in order to survive the game's many hazards. The stress mechanic is an integral part in this, as players must constantly monitor their characters' stress levels and make sure they are taking steps to reduce stress before it becomes too much to handle. Failure to do so can result in characters gaining negative personality traits or physical afflictions that can severely impact their effectiveness in battle. Additionally players must also carefully consider their team composition and equipment choices in order to succeed. Each character has their own unique abilities and strengths, and players must choose which characters to bring on each mission and how to equip them in order to maximize their effectiveness.

Red Hook Studios showed courage by breaking away from the generic dungeon crawler formula that dominated the gaming industry then (and today) and instead created a masterpiece that stands the test of time. In my opinion, Darkest Dungeon is one of the greatest risk management games ever created and the first game I recommend whenever I am asked.

Absolutely phenomenal game. Manage a roster of heroes that you choose, with classes that are masterfully designed. Manage a town that will give certain uses and benefits to your roster. Choose skills, items, and equipment then embark on a journey. There's a lot of strategy in this game and I'd highly recommend starting on the base game. I got the Crimson Court right off the bat and it changes the game a fair amount making it harder which may or may not be to your taste. The game is plenty hard enough though. You'll train characters up only to have them killed which brings the real intensity to the game. This game is just done right, I didn't encounter any game breaking bugs or crashes at all. All of the DLCs add something actually worth paying for. Now this company does adding base game features right and they do this with free DLC such as the PvP Butcher's Circus, no scamming, no shady practices, just a good studio all round.

Darkest Dungeon is dull dredge in tedium. 
What is touted as difficult is actually more of a matter of trial, error, and patience.
As a whole it is entertaining until you solve this formula.
After that it becomes a matter wanting to finish because the fights you "lose" will be a matter of pure RNG.
At best this game only allows you to prepare for the worst, with most interactions being a roll of the die with the illusion of choice. Because that is all you will be doing. Preparing for the worst. The hardest part of the game is figuring out what is needed and when. The combat is little less than RNG at that point.
Dungeon full of bleed resist? Take blight.
Dungeon full of high speed? Take surprise bonus's. 
The fights then just boil down to hoping you hit, and hoping they miss with little more to it than that.

I mean, how do I debuff the enemy's crazy dodge stat if they dodge the debuffing attack? This game is about patience, not skill. Plus the community is full of dickheads.

The game is hard, but it's hard like souls game: the game has important set of rules and concepts you need to grasp to success, with no clear tutorial to guide you to that realization. If you go in completely blind, you will have to learn through A LOT of failure, it will be a big challenge and a lot of time investment from trail and errors, and not everyone has the time or energy for that long process, so feel free to lookup all the tutorials and read all the wiki page you can find.

The game is very unique and well made, a good mix of risk and reward, punish you when you get too big for your shoe, but also reward you plenty if you do everything just right. I and many others find this game pokes our primitive monkey brain just right to keep us playing and returning to it again and again for that unique experience of excitement.

If you plan to play the game, don't activate Crimson Court in your first save, it'll make the early game a lot harder, and thus making the learning process a lot more painful that it should. The dlc is also controversial in general as seen by it's rating, so activate it at your own risk.

Here's some of my understanding of the game:

Don't tempt fate: Do everything you can to minimize the chance RNG fucks you over, and don't take any unnecessary risk. Get your chance to hit to at least 90% to minimize the chance of spending two turn and not killing anything. Get your speed at least on par with enemy's average, or have high surprise chance, to be able to somewhat consistently kill one or two enemy on turn one. Focus down that one enemy and risk tanking three enemy crits next turn, instead of trying to kill two and risk tanking four enemy crits next turn, which could be difference between surviving and losing one/two hero, even teamwipe.

Action economy is king. Do everything you can to reduce enemy turn, that means focus firing down one enemy at a time to permanently take away enemy turns, and stun enemy when the stun chance is reasonably high, proportional to the threat of enemy's turn, 50% stun chance on a ghoul that might give your whole team 12 stress in one turn is acceptable. Leave one low-threat mob after having killed everything else, stun it and kill it slowly to squeeze out more turns for your healer to heal. Apply a DOT of Y damage per turn, stun the enemy, and make the enemy take 2*Y damage in two turn.

Positions are important: Certain melee enemies is weak when pushed to the back, certain range enemy are weak when pulled to the front. Pull back line enemy to the front to also force front line enemy to the back, vice versa. Keep or remove the corpse via DOT damage to maintain/change enemy positioning. 

Scout is OP: scout turns traps into stress healing. You cannot be surprised by scouted enemy encounter. Scout gives you information that helps you optimize profit and avoid combat when needed. Critical scout reveals secret room with chest of 10,500 gold and rare trinkets when opened with key. Secret room only exist in medium/long dungeon.

I love this game to death. But it is hard to recommend, if you are interested in playing for the first time there is an easy mode and the options allows to modify some aspects about the gameplay. I say this in the context of recommending this to a friend. I took interest in playing Darkest Dungeon because of the art style and then because of the lore. Among the best RPGs I have ever played, but it will take A LOT of mistakes to get confortable with the mechanics. The best part would be playing blind for the first time, the anecdotes of people learning from their mistakes and random deaths because of crits and aflictions are very memorable 🤡. 
Some tips:
-Every hero has their uses, you can mix and match their skills in the middle of a dungeon and before entering a boss fight.
-In the early game, bosses will give you a random very rare trinket, try and go for a trinket thats worth the risk.
-You can (and should) dismiss heroes that may not be worth keeping.
-Anticuarian is a MUST in the early game, every time she interacts with a curio she gets an extra relic worth 500 gold that can be stacked 20 times.
