I am writing this review upon beating the game for the first time on Bloodmoon. I only play on Bloodmoon because I like that harsh challenging aspect of the game. So lets begin. 
     At heart it's a dungeon crawler. However, at no point did it really feel like a dungeon crawler. In the 275 hours I have played, it has yet to feel repetitive. It's almost like a paradox game, where after all this time investment I am still receiving knowledge checks and learning new mechanics and ways to play. There is always something different happening and the interactions constantly feel refreshing. 
     The customization is shallow, only being able to name the characters and choose from a few color palettes. Yet, I so easily feel myself becoming invested into my heroes. I enjoy naming characters after my friends who watch and names from fiction I like. Feeling genuinely driven to keep them alive and have them succeed. When they do well I often give them titles reflecting what it is they are doing well in. I named a Graverobber Lilith "Demon" because she would constantly drop massive crit roles and dodge like a machine. Which makes it all the more impactful when I lose these characters. 
     The progression isn't linear, and the game requires trial and error, more so reflecting an exponential curve in skill. The unspoiled surprises make the game exciting and intense. Leaving you on the edge of your seat wondering how you can adapt to the situation at hand. While on the flip side, being prepared and ready for engagements makes them all the more satisfying and enjoyable. The different areas, mobs, bosses, classes, and lore all are rather limited in the grand scheme of things. However, it is the presentation, execution, creativity, atmosphere, simplicity in design yet depth in lore and mechanics. That make this game truly a gem. 
     Once you are done with the base game, have had your fix and want something new. There is an entire workshop full of devoted fans who are looking to spice up the experience. I would name Pitch Black Dungeon particularly as something I look forward to playing. Which is a mod aimed at overhauling the entire game, and adding a completely fresh and re-balanced play through. People come up with some of the most interesting concepts for classes and characters. This game acts as an excellent medium for artistic expression in the facet of character design. Of course some art more... Niche... then others. There's something for everyone. 
     Within this unique small game there is an experience for everyone. At 25$ no less? The value is phenomenal. The narrator is a marvel in and of himself. I cannot stress how much I love this games art style. The three difficulties allow any and all players to find a desired experience. Usually difficulty sliders mean trouble for a games longevity (Total War I'm looking at you) due to the lack of proper balancing and creative limitations. However, this game actually found a way to make difficulty sliders add flavor and consistency. So whether casual (Radiant) or masochistic (Stygian/Bloodmoon), this game has you covered. I would absolutely call this a must play. There really isn't anything like it. This is no mere dungeon crawler, this is the Darkest Dungeon.

Incredible game overall. At the start, when you know nothing, it can be quite difficult, but when you get the hang of things it gets fairly easy, if played on the medium difficulty. The voicelines are spectacular, I have yet to consider turning them off. Overall 9/10, needs more leper

This game is mean,

Your favorite heroes will die
They'll be gone forever
And you will cry
That being said i love this game.

The combat has highs and lows, anything can happen. It's all about risk management and responding to problems when things don't go your way. Even if that means retreating and failing the quest or losing a hero.
Straight up my favorite implementation of turn based combat, albeit some game balance issues. But I've just had too much fun with this game to care.
This review is biased, this game is probably not a 10/10 if I had to guess it's probably an 8/10 in reality. But this game scratches such a particular itch for me that no other game has. If you enjoy gambling and risk management I think this game will resonate with you as well.
The core gameplay loop is so strong. If you lose a mission, or maybe multiple in a row just remember the new heroes on the stage coach will fight for you for free. All you need to do is pick yourself up and jump back in to...

The Darkest Dungeon

It's a pretty addictive loop for awhile, but boy is it just built to grind and be unfair. RNG crits, RNG misses, RNG diseases (gotta get that cured before you can take your hero back out), RNG fights while camping (That one is fun because camping is to lower stress and heal and it completely Fs that), RNG what your hero will refuse to use to recover stress -- oh, also RNG on if the random dude in town is taking up the spot you need to recover.

Even if you do everything right and have the best party for the dungeon, you will have to grind new heroes while others rest, you will have to wait for heroes to heal stress, ailments, swap quirks, etc. Buying supplies for every dungeon is pretty BS as well -- the dungeons are RNG, so you never know what you will or won't need, and even a best guess is only a guess, which means you will at worst be woefully underprepared and die, or at best spend too much money on factors you couldn't predict.

The dungeons and enemies get pretty old pretty quick since they aren't that diverse (stuns, dots, moving you so you can't use abilities). I'd also rather not have to try and predict what every enemy can do and just learn their move set, but they use them based on such (sometimes) strict rules that you will be surprised by abilities and not be able to adequately strategize.

I love this game while sometimes hating it.

First off, if you can't cope with some RNG which didn't go in your favour, don't buy this game.
But if you are one of those who can bear with some bad luck and into any kind of strategy games or dungeon crawlers, definately get this game. It offers a very effective "sugarbread and whip" system of frustration and reward which will keep you hooked and wanting to further level up your heroes and do another dungeon. Always putting you into situations where you have to decide what lesser evil to take, the game nails the art and audio style while still featuring an interesting storyline.
The only thing I have to criticise is the amount of RNG in the game which can lead to very frustrating moments and I think it could be tuned down a bit.

other than that there's really nothing to complain about for a 10 € game (Steam Summer Sale).

[b]NOTE: WHILE THIS REVIEW DOESN'T SPOIL STORY, IT DOES TALK ABOUT GAMEPLAY MECHANICS.[/b]

I wanted to replay this game after downloading the Darkest Dungeon 2 demo to see how much the sequel held up.
Over the next 2 weeks I ended up spending 25 hours scouring the many locations, killing monsters and bosses, collecting treasures, and finally: beating the game. 

[b]OVERVIEW[/B]

Darkest Dungeon describes itself as a game about making the most of a bad situation.
You send 4 heroes at a time to delve into one of the many different dungeons in the game, which holds monsters and treasures for you to collect.
The catch however, is that permadeath is constantly on, which means if you're not careful, or if you just get plain unlucky, your beloved houndmaster is dead.
On top of that, the game also auto saves, so no save states whatsoever.
All of this combined means that unless you are an experienced player, or look up a guide, you will very often have your nose to the grindstone during your playthrough.

With all of that being said, if you don't mind the possible death of some [i]debatably[/i] replaceable heroes, this is an extremely fun game for [b]ANYONE[/b] who likes turn-based combat, and exploration.

[b]WHAT I LIKE[/b]

I don't think I could fit every little thing that I enjoy about this game, so instead please accept this list of what I liked most.

-The Bosses: The bosses for me were simultaneously some of the most fun, and most frustrating experiences I've had in Darkest Dungeon.
On one hand, coming in with a party composition that just so happens to be horrible for the selected boss of the region simply sucks.
However the intoxicating feeling of putting enough DOTs on a boss so it's taking 20 damage on its own turn, or getting a lucky crit to prevent a character death is probably the best feeling I've had in this game

-The Narration: This right here honestly might be what makes this game special to me.
The amount of work put into writing and voicing these line is incredible.
This might be the only game that routinely gives me goosebumps with how well done its voice acting is done.

-The Characters: In the base game there are about 15 different characters to choose from.
What makes each one of them interesting and unique to me is the written dialog for them.
Each of the characters have different dialog they occasionally say depending on the situation, such as when they become stressed or hurt, or when they deal a critical hit.

[b]WHAT I DISLIKE[/b] 

The Speed: A decent portion of the game is spend wandering hallways in search of quest items, room fights, etc. but after a while, it just gets monotonous.
Not only that, but at the last stage of the game I was going to the dungeons simply to level up some select characters for the last dungeon of the game.
I just wanted to get it over with as fast as possible, so when I was leaning back in my chair with my mouse on my knee, listening to podcasts, I got pretty bored.

RNG: As you would expect, random chance plays a big role in this game.
It can be the deciding factor whether you have an entire party wipe, as it's entirely possible that your healer drops down to a quarter of their HP, or that your party gets "surprised" which randomly shuffles their marching order.
While it is certainly just a part of the game, and it probably gets evened out by the times you get a lucky crit heal, it still just feels really bad when your houndmaster drops to 0 due to a crit, and then bleeds out the very next turn.
Mind you, while I am speaking from experience here, that same houndmaster DID get revived by a random event, so again, it probably evens itself out.

[b]CONCLUSION[/b]

In the end, Darkest Dungeon is an amazing game, and if you enjoy turn-based combat, cosmic horror, or harsh gameplay, you should DEFINITELY pick up!

One of my favorite games in the past 10 years. The mod scene much like classic DOOM has, and seemingly will continue to keep this game alive for many years to come. If you enjoy classic turn based games and or dark fantasy you will love this game.

My friend recommended this to me and I like how the game runs. Extremely immersive as well as strategic gameplay! Teaches you not only how to manage inventory but also character well being. I highly recommend it.

**Gameplay:**
Gameplay consists of two main phases: the hamlet and exploring dungeons.

The hamlet functions as the players base, allowing them to: recruit new characters, upgrade and treat existing ones and manage resources such as purchasing charms and paying heirlooms to upgrade various buildings in the hamlet.

Exploring dungeons consists of building a team of up to 4 characters, assign a party order (different characters excel in certain spots, more on this later) and send them into procedurally generated dungeons with various objectives.

Combat is turn based, with each character bringing unique skills and abilities to the team.

As the party progresses through the dungeon, they will accumulate physical damage (HP) and stress (below).

HP damage can be resolved by healing and eating.

This is where party order becomes crucial, characters are only able to use certain abilities when they are in certain positions in party order.

Therefore, having a balanced team is very important, and one of the places where the game shined the most for me. I did not get very interested in the loot (the game does not place much emphasis on it and they are mostly thematic currencies for purchasing things), but the characters really kept my interest. Who goes where? Who does what? Who can do what because of where they are positioned? Who gets upgraded? Who gets dismissed? The possibilities widely range and kept me thinking about optimal setups of both individuals and party comps.

I find that my strategy changes drastically according to who I am playing, and taking a few battles to get into the rythym of knowing how to play each unique team I send out, as well as theorizing about potential dream teams

**Camping**
Here, camping would be useful to mention; on longer missions, players are given breaks to ‘camp’, this essentially means sitting in a room in the dungeon, eating, resting and allows players to use their second ‘camping’ set of abilities to reduce stress, heal,

Stress is affected by a myriad of factors, including: party order, hunger, darkness level, health and status of allies and enemies

**Thoughts:**

Overall I am enjoying this game and find the character building and composition really stimulating. The difficulty of the game: permadeath, cruel autosaves, no manual saves, hunger, stress, illness, disease etc all combine into a game that encourages you to go deeper into the dungeons and then intermittently punishes you for it. Have someone die, even if they are not your star player, feels big and that you somehow messed up quite badly. Having a sense of consequence and an ability to improve really make this game feel nice to play. However, there is something that prevents me from spending more than about an hour playing at a time, once I figure this out I will update.

**Core (One-liner):**
Build characters, build up their skills (RPG) get attached to them, send them out to die in very difficult missions that do not favor unpreparedness (or if they do not die, they get incredibly stressed and come back with trauma and disorders that the player must deal with)

It's one of those games that seems easy on the surface level but the further you go into its depths the more you realize that you're actually kinda screwed.

This game has an interesting difficulty dynamic where instead of pitting you against unstoppable odds and telling you good luck, the game actively encourages you to plan ahead of time and include the best team that synergizes well with eachother in order to excel and overcome anything that comes your way. 

On top of the already amazing design that the entire game is built around, the modding community just adds so much raw potential for this game that it makes it virtually endless. There are so many talented artists and modders out there pouring their best efforts to make this game more replayable than ever, and the workshop makes it extremely easy to install those mods and get them working.

TL;DR, if you don't particularly like difficult games, you probably won't be a hardcore fan of this. Still, it's worth trying out for a time.

Ah. Darkest Dungeon.

Let me cut to the chase; this game is unforgiving. It's quite easy to lose a level 6 maxed out character to permadeath. Maybe you pushed your party too far, maybe you mismanaged your supplies, or maybe it was just bad luck on the RNG. Characters can, and will, die through no fault of your own.

To me, the party management aspect was the most entertaining. I enjoyed forming parties that could play off of each others strengths and weaknesses. It was satisfying to build up their levels and abilities. Just make sure that you have a contingency plan. Your favorite party won't last forever, you will need to have apprentices in training at all times, otherwise you won't be able to form a cohesive party if you lose a key member. The dungeon exploring is pretty linear, and your party will constantly be affected negative quirks. In other words, your party is often more a danger to itself than the monsters in the dungeon are. Selfish bastards spring traps on themselves, cause you to lose treasures, etc. Rising stress levels cause heart attacks, diseases inflict negative status effects, etc. The combat is generally fun, but frustrating at times. Often your party needs to be in certain order for their best moves to function correctly, but enemies know this and constantly try to re-arrange your party which screws with your strategy.

Pros:

- Art style, music, and voice acting really set the scene
- A lot of different character classes, abilities, upgrades, etc.
- Dungeon layouts are ever changing
- The ability to add trinkets for added status effects is nice

Cons:

- RNG will have no qualms about completely screwing you over
- Some of the voiceovers get a bit repetitive
- It takes a lot of luck as well as skill to build up a successful party. If you need a certain class, you may have to wait (in game) weeks for one to show up at the stagecoach, and then hopefully you have a decent party to throw them in for training

Look... I have too much anxiety in my life as it is. I turn to video games for some fun and relaxation. I'm not opposed to a challenge, but this game literally stresses me out at times. For that reason I had to take an extended break. I may return to the dungeons some day, but not any time soon.

Overall, I recommend this game. If you know what you're getting yourself into, it's a pretty good game. But if you are easily stressed or are prone to anxiety, proceed with extreme caution.

The ONE and ONLY issue I have with this game is stress Gain and Stress heal. So You face SIMPLE dudes/mobs that Inflict 30 Points of Stress. So that's 30/200 usually you fight at least 2 of the at once. Some other simple dudes get casts on 2 heroes for 20~ on each. And by simple I mean like stage 1 enemies. Once you reach 100/200 your heroes Resolve Or loose Hope Which is cool right! Tho like 95% of the time they loose hope and fuck with everything but im cool with that. The problem I have is that the stress gain is like Insanely high. You might think that you can pervent those guys from casting the stress spells right? NOPE They have high speed stat which lets them almost ALWAYS go first so that 30 is guaranteed at least once And there is one of these fuckers at almost every battle. If you do A crit you heal for like 5-10 stress. There are some stress healing spells but they also cover like 10 or so stress. If you camp you can cure like 20 stress most of the time. So there is Straight up no way to pervent stress from skyrocketing every single time... And once stress reaches 200/200 you get heart attacks which bring your hero to 0 hp (+ There is a chance to die at every heart attack) and sets that hero to death blow status where if he takes damage from that point there is a chance he might die. (if you have all settings on default your heroes loose other stats also when ever reaching that death blow status) Now when you reach 200/200 and you have hearth attack even if your hero is at 100% you loose it all. The stress does not reset it goes down by like 10 or 20.... so even if you heal your hero from 0hp to any hp and remove the death blow status any other stress from anywhere will give you heart attack Oh and when your hereos have had lost hope at 100/200 they ussualy get stats where they talk shit and apply stress to ALL other heroes. So at every action you take like heal your hero from 0 hp and after the heal another dude talks shit stress goes to 200/200 and heart attack again.... and then it just starts looping around and you just die cause you cant even make a move.... Yeah sure if it gets bad you can retreat right? well not really... In my last fight I fell back from the battle and all my heroes died from heart attacks before I could take an action to return to town.... 

EDIT- Ok So after playing quite some more I realised that I lost 95% of my heroes to heart attack... how fucking dumb is that? like from going all the fucking time max hp to instantly dying to never ending hearth attacks... This mechanic is 100% ruing the game experience for me I REALLY wish i could just turn it off and enjoy the game... like its so fucking stupid... worst game mechanic i have seen in a while honestly... like after the heart attack any other stress is gonna give you a heart attack... so if you have 3 other heroes stressed out they talk shit and boom another heart attack... And I dont know how about you guys but when my heroes enter deaths door they NEVER last longer than 1 extra attack and they die... like this is so fucking stupid I'm really questioning if I want to play this game just cause of this ONE problem with the game... its such a fucking game killing mechanic!!!

Hello, thank you for reading this recommendation and I hope it is helpful for if you decide to purchase this game or ignore it.
If you have never played this type of game before, play it with only Character DLC or without any DLC at all. This game will be challenging and feel demeaning if you are not already use to this type of game. Character DLC helps to add more abilities for the player to use at their disposal, and that should be enough to help in the long term. Should you attempt to actually complete the entire game as I have.

If you have played a game similar to this before and dont want a challenge, refer to the first paragraph. 

If you have played a game similar to this before and dont care/want a challenge (are a masochist like me), then buy the game, get the Color of Madness and Crimson Court DLC. This game will ramp up in difficulty and have ALOT of content for you to complete while feeling challenging and question how quickly you can adapt to a worst case scenario coming true. 

Ultimately we will see if your efforts are worth it but, I am sure if you continue to try you will be rewarded with a moment of accomplishment before looking to the second game for more enjoyment~.
Please be safe, don't forget food and water and enjoy the Darkest Dungeon~

Worst thing about this game: 
Turn order is random, your speed is not the only thing determining the order your hero's activate, the game rolls a dice and often the enemy activate twice in a row, giving you no opportunity to take any actions. This is pure luck, there is no strategy to prevent this, and often results in the death of a hero, setting you back hours of progress.

--- The chances of losing your best hero are the same chances of losing a fresh level 1 hero, I have no idea why anyone would want to play a game that arbitrarily sets you back by hours of progress. ---

The game is much better played with mods, but the game is already a waste of time because of how random every action is, your attacks can miss, the enemy can crit for insane damage, you can be locked out of taking any actions while the enemy take 5 actions in a row... It does not reward skill or strategy, only patience.

Games that rely entirely on the player having infinite patience are just not fun.

Darkest Dungeon is less of a game and more of a slot machine with a gimmick. It seems like just throwing disposable adventurers at an eldritch dungeon seems like a neat idea for a game until you realize that to take on tougher dungeons or even to improve your performance in even the easiest ones on the easiest difficulty you have to put money into improving them, taking care of them after the adventure, training them, make sure they complement each other well... I am sorry but does this not all sound like the absolute opposite of the word disposable? If the point is to get as far as you can and do a little bit better each time, than why does dealing with stress soak up almost all the funds you get from dungeon diving? You even have to spend your upgrade currency just to improve your stress reliefs all the while you're stuck farming for the exact same resources hoping that the random number generator god just doesn't decide to fuck you over

This kind of do a little bit better system of game play only works well with games with fixed encounters so that you can learn from your mistakes and in fact do better the next time around, Dark Souls doesn't randomly change enemy positions or tactics every time you fail, X com doesn't suck all your resource into just keeping your experienced troops barely functional and when they did add a functionally similar system to Darkest Dungeons stress gimmick it didn't suck away most of the earnings you barely walked away with. 

And yet the strangest thing is that I would still recommend you play this game, I mean I wouldn't recommend you play very long or drop a bunch of money on it but it is worth taking a look at mostly for the way the game actually plays when you are delving into dungeons, whenever the game doesn't feel like a random number generator it is actually very interesting and fun.

There seems to be a fair amount of backlash regarding this game, as people like to criticize the new update for making it "unplayable".

That's really odd, because I find it to be a fun, enjoyable--albeit stressful--experience. If it is so unplayable, then why am I able to play it? A lot of people seem to complain about the game's difficulty and the fact that the game tends to throw a monkey wrench in your best-laid plans (a random trap attacks your Plague Doctor, enemies land a few critical blows in a row, etc.). I'd like to start out by saying, rather flatly, that this game is a roguelike, gothic, dungeon crawler. It is not Candyland.

The game does a great job of playing out the difficulties and trials associated with exploring haunted or possessed dungeons and labyrinths, infested with creatures and abominations created by your own ancestor who leaves you to clean up his grievous mess. Your team of heroes will get stressed and they may go crazy or pull through and save your team from utter ruin. This makes sense from a regular person's perspective. You're going through creepy dungeons with a bunch of strangers, armed only with the best gear a nameless heir can provide you (or is willing to), only to hope that you can survive fighting disgusting, fleshy pig creatures, skeletons, fish monsters, zombie mushroom creatures and more. How would you, as a normal person or even as a hero, not end up stressed out by this?

Of COURSE the game is supposed to be stressful and arbitrary in design to an extent--that's the point. Do you remember a roguelike game where you remember the layout of every dungeon and the item drop rates and enemy spawn rates were overly-consistent? That wouldn't be a very roguelike game if this were the case. So, if you were traversing through the halls of these places, you would be stressed out too, fighting such monsters. This would lead up to the point when you would fear for your own life from dealing with such insufferable creatures, or pull through and refuse to take this kind of treatment lying down. Sure, the game is quite spontaneous with some of the situations that occur. I once interacted with a curio incorrectly, only for my Vestal to end up with Syphillis. Needless to say, she wasn't welcomed to the Brothel any longer.

This game sets out to do what a roguelike does best: throws spontaneous game mechanics out at you while you do your best to fight them off. The objective in the game is not to expect what happens next, but to survive whatever that next thing is. If your characters can't survive the onslaught, then I hope you've upgraded your Stagecoach.

tl;dr This game is great, but a lot of people complain about the difficulty, claiming it to be unfair or "unplayable". The game does get frustrating, but it is understandably so. It is a great purchase, especially for the $10 it is on sale for at the moment. I highly recommend it if you like gritty, dark, challenging roguelike games with turn-based elements.

I, personally, think this game is shit. On the presentation side of things, this game is great, the art and narration are amazing and the music is pretty solid. On the other hand, the gameplay is some of the worst i've experienced this year. The dungeon crawls are repetitive and boring, the combat is simple and a bit bland, and the stress mechanic is easily avoided and negated. But strangely, for a bit, I enjoyed it, because for all its flaws, the narration and art is great, and despite the combat being bland, you still can get some fun out of it. And then the mid game to late game came along. A pleasant early game gives way to a boring grindathon with no new content added, so it gets boring fairly fast. Yeah, I don't want to play another minute of this garbage. It just doesn't click for me. If you came to this game looking for an interesting turn based strategy game, you're not going to find it. On a scale of shit to shit, I would have to rate it shit.

Ok I never sit down to write reviews of games but I just had to do this just to find an outlet for my frustration. According to Steam, I have played 117 hours of DD. Around half of these were played more than a year ago when I rage-quit for good. Or I thought as much. I tried to check out the sequel which is still in early access just to see if the devs were fixing the issues I found obvious, but without luck. Anyway, this year, I returned to this game and tried once again to beat it but again smashed into a wall.
After 30 years of gaming, I don't believe I have hate-played a game before, but Darkest Dungeon takes the crown for being a major disappointment. But before discussing what I believe are flaws in game design and presentation, I have to talk about its virtues: First of all, the art, music, narration and overall atmosphere are all amazingly good, -I would say iconic- and are in the end what make me come back to this game. The gameplay mechanics of stress, in addition to normal damage and the afflictions, quirks, torches, loot system, and virtue mechanics are all wonderful concepts and work well in the game. The settings, monsters and story are also very evocative and hint at an eerie Lovecraftian worldbuilding. The classes are ok, with some being totally uninteresting and bland and others some of the coolest in any game ever. 
BUT my main issue with the game is that in order to enjoy all that greatness you have to push through a random, grind-dependent, limiting and obscure way of playing, presenting the story, and (not) teaching the player how to ...play
Yeah ok I get it, the devs wanted to make the game HARD and want you to "GIT GUD" and not take you by the hand to show you how to win. I get all that. But for me that is not the way to do it. And even if you do "GIT GUD" in this game you just have a better chance of winning. 
In Darkest Dungeon the getting good part mainly means two things: Grinding and becoming more familiar with the game itself. But the game never tells you how its own mechanics work. This is work you must do on your own, and I mean not in the game, but through googling and visiting wikis and watching other players play. You need to do that for example to understand what "PROT" means which is a stat in the game (it's basically ARMOR lol).
If you already know what works for one area of the game, you can stroll right through it. If you have fought the bosses once and you remember how you beat them before, and you know what each hero's stats and skills are, you can select the appropriate party for each boss and kill them easily. If you have grinded enough to upgrade all the necessary town buildings and all your heroes have good armor and weapons (which basically means having money and heirloom loot) the game is not that hard. BUT the game doesn't tell you that you don't need to upgrade some town buildings AT ALL while if you don't upgrade others you are F***D. This is why if one follows a guide from a veteran player and do the exact same things they do, they will most likely win (and it's the way most people have learnt to play the game successfully, through meta-gaming). 
But that is the definition of boring. And call me old-fashioned but I think games should be fun.
Darkest Dungeon doesn't help you build any skills as a player either, unless it's skills in accounting, bureaucracy and nomenclature (and don't tell me the skill is strategy because that is cancelled by the RNG half of the time). Don't get me wrong, there is quite a bit of fun in the randomness and tension of the encounters but after the first 30 hours the fun stops and the game becomes mainly a chore in order to get to the few next fun parts. An example of that is that it takes waaay too many runs, way too much money and way too many hours of your life to build a roster of heroes strong enough to attack the actual Darkest Dungeons. The stories are also kind of good but they are spread really thin throughout the game and none of the narratives actually have any serious impact, they act more as excuses to keep going through the same dungeons over and over again, fighting the same enemies over and over again, having to throw away too much loot you cannot fit in your tiny inventory and trying your luck with the game's supercharged RNG. 
This game is a bit like playing backgammon with Lovecraft themed graphics and sounds where if you lose, you die and go to hell :D
I have played 117 hours of this game and not once have I managed to get beyond the first Darkest Dungeon where all my level 6 heroes (which take around 30 hours of playing time to build) get wiped out. And it's not for lack of trying or a lack of maxing out on being a DD nerd.
To be clear: we are talking about a totally devised way of making a game difficult and long: having a huge percentage of battle decided on pure chance, deliberately limiting the amount of loot a party can carry, introducing overpowered enemies in the late game and after your heroes have reached max level, presenting a mediocre 2 hour story in short snippets just so it can be dragged along for 100 hours or not disclosing basic information to the players that should be available from the start in order to play the damn thing properly.
And to all those that say "but in real life things don't come easy and are many times random like in DD" I will answer "Yeah, this is WHY WE PLAY GAMES because real life is shit".
Those were my two cents. I will now escape to my escapist utopia of GUD GAMES and leave you to self-flagellate with DD and the upcoming DD2 which is even worse.

Victory...a hollow and ridiculous notion. And not all of your final team survived the last battle. Sacrifice had to be made to uncover the secrets of the darkest dungeon. All the while you have spent time improving their quirks and leveling them up. You treasured them so much, planning punctiliously about every move and circumventing potential pitfalls. All in vain. They were gone forever. The truth is learnt the hard ways. They were just spent torches discarded into the void, tools for your delirious ambitions. Their names were not remembered, nor were there any tombs to venerate their noble deeds. So how are you different from your ancestors. In that absolute emptiness, you end the game.

Intro: This game introduces it'self as a turn-based game that will require thinking, planning ahead and picking out a team, that'll work well all together. It's Gothic/med evil/ horror theme works very well in bringing the game to life. Unfortunately that's the only comment I can give this game at all.

Pros: this game will give you a huge amount of Characters to work with, upgrades and if you are a masochistic or a sadist this game is for you because clearly you either hate yourself and want to punish yourself or just love to watch your main characters fall every round you get a chance.

Cons: The game doesn't give you any help what so ever, you get thrown into the deep end within the first round. You will immediately lose players in the first run you do because all the monster are on roids whilst your characters are sat there trying to jam a flute up there backside hoping it'll debuff them, well in reality, you just ****ed them off. 
after a few hours of playing you finally figure out the construct of the game and go back to the first dungeon with a semi-decent team and all of a sudden, the game will throw what seemed to be Solomon Grundy and the HULK, in the first level where they proceed to spit roast your entire team on a BBQ when you barely even gotten through the entrance. 
The chaos, Randomisation and number generator are so unfair, you might we well tell your players here is a 6 sided dice whatever you roll you do Damage. now here is your dice game you get a D20 (20 sided dice) with ALL 20s on them. 
The last time i was this annoyed and angry with someone I was still date my Ex.

Overall: if you want to punish yourself go right ahead and play it. but from every game I play I would highly NOT recommend this game.

I play this since it was out and i have way more time on this than it's actually show. 
This game is a modern day classic and it will forever leave it's mark on videogame history and game design in general. 
The systems are simple, but elegant, the Lore is elusive but concise and the Ambience is a masterwork. 

This game has a sort of cotextual storytelling, that you have to be in the flow and feel things. It's not like an RPG like baldurs gate or kingmaker where there is a story going on with a main plot and subplots and the characters in your party are talking and all that. The thick of the story in DD is how you with your choices and the RNG generate memorable pieces of memory, like how a party of powerfull heroes will fall to overconfidence and badluck and how a group could beat overwhelming odds because one of them, when faced by the nhilistic nature of the cosmos and his own weakness and insignificance, decided to give a middle finger to fate and make his own destiny, becoming virtuous and beating the crap out of the enemies.

Darkest Dungeon is about human struggle, resulting in victory by perserance, failure or the middle ground, sacrifice. 

Where a flame burns in the darkness, a human heart beat, Defiant.

It's difficult but, in an irritating way. Not a challenging one. A large part of success or failure is based on luck rather than strategy.

It sucked me in early on. The dungeons are cool, the world is neat, the lore is great. And I've never heard such awesome in-game narration. But, after a dozen hours or so, the problems became evident.

My biggest complaint about it is the inventory system. You have to buy supplies before each dungeon and they don't carry over into the next dungeon. Anything you don't use on a mission is discarded. You don't get to keep it and you don't get a refund. But, since the dungeons are randomly generated, you'll be either constantly wasting your gold on supplies you didn't use, or else risk losing the dungeon because you don't have enough supplies to continue. 

Also, progress is slow and requires a lot of grinding to level up, and given that there's not a lot of variety here, it quickly becomes a slog. I enjoy difficult games but, I pretty much lost interest in this after less than 20 hours.

I tried to like this game but in the end, I can only recommend this game to masochist ( like me ).

I'm the type of person that if they start playing a game and if I want to get good at it, I will start reading the game's wiki, watch guides of experienced people and try to use the most optimal strategies so I can enjoy the game. And then here comes Darkest Dungeon and says "I know you have good knowledge of this game, but I don't want you to have fun".

I've got so many character die because solely of the RNG. And before you say "Git gud" or "You're just bad because you under prepare" or "Overconfidence is blah blah blah" or "You should instead play on Radiance difficulty", there is nothing like that. I never attend a difficult dungeon if I am not at least the same level with the specific dungeon with my skills, equipment and trinkets and even then, when everything goes smoothly and I play the safest can someone play, the game just tries to "spice" things up and hit you with the most unlikely scenarios that can happen. The game sometimes induces you a false sense of you doing great. I am saying that because early dungeons are easy and you'll have for some reason, more chances to deal critical damage with a very low chance ( I had multiple instances where my heroes would crit 3 times or more in a row with only 10% chance ), but beware, the game turns into CBT when you attend higher level dungeons. 

Here is only ONE of the many, many times this came just bended me:

I'm in a champion dungeon, I bring a party with great trinkets and heroes that synergies with each other according to guides and people that has sunken thousands of hours in this game. I get into an encounter, I start playing safe, stun important targets and here comes my antiquarian, +50 dodge, using Protect me to put it on someone with riposte. Everything goes well, then I have only one target remaining so I think "He is the least threatening enemy, I will just start healing and stress healing the party until the stalling mechanic is about to kick in". So only for ONE round I didn't guard the antiquarian. Next up, the enemy hits her for a crit of 30 putting her to deaths door and giving her bleeding. I notice my mistake so I am like "Oh, no problem I can put my healer to take her off deaths door". Wrong, the game doesn't even care about the speed mechanic because even if my main healer had speed of 7 and the antiquarian had a speed of -3, she goes first and dies from the first bleed damage. Have I forgot tell you that she had over 75% death blow resists?

I could go on and on with all sorts of events that lead to my heroes die in utterly unfair and frustrating ways but I'd rather not. Some positives of this game on the other hand are the art style, atmosphere and music. They are absolutely bangers but that is everything I could say good about this.

I might play this game now and then because I hate myself but in no way I recommend this game to people that want to enjoy their free time.

Darkest Dungeon is a grim and merciless tactical strategy game whose great tension comes from its many layers of complexity, unpredictable randomization, and willingness to put our fragile characters in mortal danger if we dare to venture into its depths in search of treasure and glory. Brilliant narration and stiff yet surprisingly expressive animation make it easy to be drawn into its vague but tantalizing world, though the end feels artificially out of reach.

Darkest Dungeon is a roguelite RPG about the psychological effects of dungeon crawling, and the pursuit of knowledge and power. At the behest of your ancestor, return home, rebuild the hamlet, cleanse your family's estate, and close the portal of ancient evil that lies beneath. 

[i]"Remind yourself that overconfidence is a slow and insidiuos killer."
"Be wary, triumphant pride precipitates a dizzying fall."
"Great adversity has a beauty, it is the fire that tempers the blade."[/i]

These are three of my favorite quotes from the narrator, and I must say, the narration in this game is excellent. This goes hand in hand with the art style and sound design which all mesh fantastically well with each other, and with the gameplay. 

The gameplay can be quite challenging at first, and may seem downright unfair at times due to RNG. It's also very grind heavy, though less so on Radiant difficulty.

I played during a free weekend in 2020, but didn't buy it until 2022. Glad I gave it another shot. The game uses a custom lightweight cross-platform engine, and the native Linux version ran perfectly. 

There is a convenient web app for dungeon prep and curio info [url=https://arnaud.rocks/darkest-companion/]here.[/url] Check out the mods on the Steam Workshop too!

PS: You can use the -skipfeflowintro launch option to skip the intro.

I would recommend this game to anyone that believes "hard" and "getting screwed over by RNG" are the same thing. In that case I would recommend Candy Crush Saga. At least when you decide to stop playing that game you won't regret the 20 euros you spent on it.

Ruin has come to our family. You remember our venerable house, opulent and imperial, gazing proudly from its stoic perch above the moor? I lived all my years in that ancient, rumor shadowed manor, fattened by decadence and luxury - and yet I began to tire of conventional extravagance. Singular, unsettling tales suggested the mansion itself was a gateway to some fabulous and unnameable power. With relic and ritual I bent every effort towards the excavation and recovery of those long buried secrets, exhausting what remained of our family fortune on swarthy workmen and sturdy shovels.

At last in the salt soaked crags beneath the lowest foundations we unearthed that damnable portal of antediluvian evil. Our every step unsettled the ancient earth but we were in a realm of death and madness. In the end I alone fled laughing and wailing through those blackened arcades of antiquity until consciousness failed me.

You remember our venerable house, opulent and imperial. It is a festering abomination! I beg you. Return home; claim your birthright, and deliver our family from the ravenous, clutching shadows of the Darkest Dungeon.

Don't worry about my low playtime, I spent 120 hours playing this game on my Switch. I also bought it for my PS5 and I want to get it for my iPad. 

I had to delete the game. It is so addictive, thrilling, satisfying and beautiful to look at and hear. There is lots of depth to the combat. Trying out a bunch of party formations and synergising them is fun and so satisfying when you pull it off. I mean this is the stuff that, as a gamer, I live for. 

However, I hate the fact that the bosses have these gimmicks that would never cross your mind. Some of them make sense but only after you know what they are and some of them are plain stupid; they don't even make sense. So if you want to go through the game using your own brain, you are going to have to wipe out a different lvl 6 party 2 or 3 times in the learning process which is just brutal. This is my biggest problem with the game and why I got so scared of attempting the darkest dungeon on my Switch.

After putting 120 hours on my Switch with this game. I downloaded it on Steam, installed some quality of life mods and had a ton of fun. I only attempted the darkest dungeon and beat the game after installing a mod that gives me lvl 6 heroes after every dungeon. I beat most of the darkest dungeons after the first try but I feel like I cheated because that removed MY stress.

Extremely fun game that is addicting right out the door. It plays like a DnD game that met the old turn based strategies in 2D format (good amount of RNG). Its a looter, RPG, and a dungeon crawler packed up nicely into really beautiful 2D graphics with a Lovecraftian feel to it. Story is told through excellent narration, where you find bits and pieces of journals and letters that are sent to you as you progress through dungeons.

Very risk-reward based, and not an easy game by any means. Gameplay is straight forward and about as difficult as you want to make it (harder difficulties require much more planning). If you plan well and get a good synergy with your party going, you will make it through relatively alright. If you dont... get ready to die a lot. Everything is procedurally generated, making the difficult higher as well.

10/10 excellent game that you can play for hours, with a great amount of replayability.

Amidst the desolate soil
We heard the repeating cries of a fragment of metal
So, true to Magnus' orders
I take my company's reins onto the surface, we settle
And as we branch out and explore the wreckage
We uncover a terminal's long-lost message
A visage of the past and of beautiful cities
So what has occurred here? What are we missing?
There is something wrong here and there is something hidden
With every second growing closer, I feel it near me!
My mind shudders, why does my heart race?
A psychic scream, like a crushing weight
Resounding in every corner of the world
"The Ancient awaits!"
Enwrapped in grief and beset by pain
It bides it's time, all it does is wait
We shoulder the hardship now and we endure
And to its source, we'll trace
The sight before my eyes is stark
A Dreadnought here, bearing the Emperor's Children's mark?
Unexpectedly, it interjects with pointed thoughts
Awake once more, energy arcs
Across its words now, demanding to know
Are we standing here gathered as friend or foe?
Its shattered form yet still poses a threat to us all
It shall not be deceived, nor ignored
I speak in half-truths to not invite alarm
"I see through your words, and I am not disarmed
We had learned from Him to hold to truth with every breath"
The wrong word here may mean death
"Even your words may be twisted and turned into weapons"
There is danger here, with every phrase now it beckons
I know the name of he who has me in his sights
"I am he who remembers, the Ancient of Rites!"
All at once, the pieces come together in my mind
This place was Istvaan III!
And we are here upon its corpse
On the grave that was left behind!
"Would you convince yourself I am a remnant seeking saving?
This was not a cry for help!
This was a lure I laid to invite something in need of slaying"
"Was this trap set for me, old one of mine?
You look terrible. A disgrace, even"
"At last, Fulgrim, you have come to me, abomination"
"Words uttered by a shattered pile of metal, rust and stagnation?
You've had millennia to think of what to tell me, you've my attention"
"I need not glory nor for words to speak
When I have held
A Virus Bomb!" ("No!")
Reaching out
My Raptorae uses his mind to hold the pace, to silence time
I channel him all of the strength I have
His power desperately relying on mine
And from my peripheral sight
I can no longer see that frail shell, devoid of its might
But rather a righteous being of defiance
Who is not without the will to fight!
I watch the Dreadnought lash out in wrath
His blows deflected away from their path
Despite the years he has endured
It's clear that he will live and he will die by the sword
Fulgrim then returned a strike
His sword slitting through bravado and machine alike
His face a mix of contempt and glee
The eyes of one who can feed off misery!
"You can never be forgiven for the things that you've done
And so it falls to my hands to end the prodigal son!"
"You cannot imagine the beautiful bounty of Chaos"
"Those things I'd never even wish to know!"
"There is still your potential that shines through
Imagine the unfulfilled glories we'd see to!"
"That you'd still think I seek any glory
Betrays the true blindness that has overcome you!
I recall the virtues I stood for
I recall the struggles and the things that we have done!
I will not be deterred from my vengeance
I remember the lessons passed on to the Sons!
I am one of the Emperor's Children
I am Rylanor and I am the Ancient of Rites!
So I reject you for now and for always!
To strike you down I have waited for a million nights!"
Inspired by the things I've heard
I raise my voice and shout clearly and out of turn
"Rylanor deserves better than you, oh Primarch
Rylanor deserves better than all of us!"
With but a single shot
The Raptorae is relieved of duty and released of his task
I feel the virus rend me apart, with my honor intact
As I'm enveloped by the encroaching flash
"Although this body of mine's still intact
A part of my pride, I fear, will never come back"

Even the party is expendable exactly because it`s completely unbalanced and when you lose a character is out of your control - full hp and/or sanity and by the end of the enemy`s turn your character is dead with zero inputs on your behalf. I have a question for you dear Reader: What do you say about a game that is insufferably random, grimdark as the warhammer universe, makes you want to toss out the computer out of the window and has you coming back for more 5 years after the fact. 

In short it is abusive. This game grips you, squeezes out your sanity and spits you back out. The narrator and the movies are positively haunting, terrifying even. I am 30 years old and this games scares me shitless. In the beginning you think: neat i get to slaughter little evil buggers. But more and more you learn the backstory of the game and in all honesty, having played through it twice, i am not so certain you play the good guys or even good guy adjacent. Some of the bosses are pitiful, some are as evil as can be, some made the wrong choices, some never had any. I will not spoil the big bad of the end but you are left with two thoughts: Did I do the right Thing? Or is humanity doomed?

I'm not certain if it was the intend of the developers but this "game" shows the very worst of humanity in form of the ancestor. His voiceovers leave enough to the imagination, that it is sickening. He is eloquent, has a magnificent voice and a Rythm that draws you in. You get lulled into his exposition and just want to listen to his story. And than you realize what his stories are about. If your reaction is revulsion at this point, then congratulations, i think you are a healthy human being, and a good head ontop of your shoulders and no tendencies of psychopathy. 
(I'd like to imagine that he is a little bit like hitler, or atleast how hitler felt to most people. He drew them in and left no room for doubt, lulling you into his falshoods and evil machinations)
At this point i'd like to point out, that the sound design of the game is absofuckinglutly amazing. I have never played any game that is anywhere close to the quality of cutscenes and voiceovers. (Yes it is THAT good.) 

The gameplay is not bad either, not perfect mind you, but it is fun and adrenaline inducing. I hope this review helps you. Personally i would not advise anyone below 21 years to buy and play this game. 

One last shoutout to the community: You are fanastic. this game is a bit aged, but still recieves love from the developers and the modding community. (though in all fairness a lot of... questionable NSFW mods have been created recently... not sure what that is about)

TLDR: Creeping. Grinding. A Painful, yet inexorable journey to victory. But at what cost? 

[b][u]General Thoughts/Overview:[/u][/b]

Well. Darkest Dungeon is definitely the right name for it. Two attempts, almost 4 years of real time, and many pick-ups and put-downs to actually finish it. Darkest dungeon will grind you down until you have nothing left. But you [i]will[/i] be back. 
Take on your role as the caretaker of this godforsaken hamlet, and the poor souls who dwell within. Seemingly the last of your line, it comes to you to cleanse this place. Hire waifs and strays, call them heroes, discard your humanity, and march these forsaken souls upon the bones of those that came before you. There is no other choice, there are no other paths. Only forward. To victory.
Use the riches and the heirlooms that they uncover to improve the heroes lot, arm them with the trinkets found within the ruins, and return the town to its former glory, in the shadow of the forsaken mansion. Delve into that forsaken place once the survivors appear strong enough. Who knows, some of them might even make it out again. 

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
[list][*] Dark and broody in the right ways. 
[*] The duel physical and mental health mechanics are gruelling but interesting. They truly give the game an added depth, and the choice between how healed healed really is adds to that. The cost of recovery can be exorbitant, the cost of failure worse. 
[*] The narrator is just perfect. The music and sounds are also excellent. Even after the 100th time of hearing the same lines, they still land… It never even crossed my mind to turn him off.
[/list]

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
[list][*] Grindy as all hell. This is particularly bad if you happen to lose a hero, or more. Getting heroes up in levels takes time. Esp if they need recovery time after delves… which they almost certainly will. 
[*] Massively disproportionate losses and costs. You can mill through newcomers, however, to simply explore short missions with little to no equipment, fleeing once the burden becomes too much and taking what you have. 
[*] RNG hell. “How quickly the tide turns.” Will haunt me forever more, after watching three group-wide crits in a row decimate my previously untouched party, followed by a round of tick damage kill every single one of them. I’m sure every player of this game will recall a time their healer gave 1-0 points in critical moments, ending runs or even entire team’s inches from victory. 
[/list]

[b][u]Suggested improvements:[/u][/b]
 [list][*] I’d like the journal notes separated from loot, in order to make collection easier… OR they should impact other things, such as making certain boss fights easier, or unlocking characters.
[*] It should be possible to ‘press’ higher level party members to undertake tasks ‘beneath them’. But at added stress cost, higher chances for their flaws to come through, and they take loot up to a certain value for themselves… This could also lead to additional perks and flaws. (Darkest Dungeon survivors should be willing to go on them for free… “Anything to not be sent back to that hell hole”. 
[*]Some saved layouts, or some way to see what I’ve encounter in each of the areas would be nice. My memory is pretty bad and I ended up bringing everything to every mission, it was wasted space and gold, all because of my own imperfections. Just some way of seeing which items I’d used in each space would have helped with this. 
[/list]


[b][u]Overall Recommendation:[/u][/b]

Darkest Dungeon is not for the faint of heart. It is not for people who hate grind, it is not for people who grow super attached to their characters, and it is not for people who give up. It literally mixes some of the worst aspects of rougelikes with some of the worst aspects of traditional dungeon crawling adventures… but this is by design. 

DD is also [i]for[/i] all of those people. It will grind you down, you will put it down… but if you’re not a quitter you’ll be back, maybe not today, maybe not tomorrow, maybe not for another year… You’ll suffer a loss, it’ll be too much… but you will be back to try again, and there are always more bodies on the stage coach, ready to try their luck and make their fortunes.
Be wary, for overconfidence is a slow and insidious killer.

Darkest Dungeon is all about taking control of your emotions and greed, not the other way around.

While RNG plays its little game all the time, if you plan around minimizing risk from week 1, and manage to consistently execute this strategy through the entire run, then around week 40-50 you should have -

1. Maxed-out Guild and Weaponsmith.
2. You first team of four Resolve Level 6 heroes.
3. Some, if not all, tier S trinkets, class-specific and general.
4. A few ancestor's trinkets, although they are far from mandatory.

This means the player should be ready to take on DD1 (We Are the Flame) by week 50 in the worst case. On Stygian difficulty, the base game gives you 86 weeks to beat the game, so that's 36 weeks' leeway for four quests. Because failing a DD quest is heavily punished, it's more preferable to keep farming for useful trinkets / quirks past week 50, than launching a premature assault on DD (prevention > reaction).

This is a simple and effectively way of having successful runs. Over time you'll accumulate enough game knowledge and start thinking in a new way - 'what exact party composition, hero level and gears do I need to have a reasonable chance at quest X'. Ultimately, X is the Darkest Dungeon level quests (win condition).

On your first run, it is not possible to deduce preconditions from this win condition, because you don't know about them at all yet, so working from week 1 all the way to DD is like scouting the game to get a map of it. This is what Darkest difficulty is for. Then you should have all you need to make deductions from win condition and make a path on the game map, so the second run will be all about execution, walking that path. Of course, there are many possible paths, some safer and longer, others riskier but shorter. Speedrunners are always looking for the shortest path and they don't care about failing a hundred times as long as the 101st attempt succeeds.

Now, the real fun (reads punishment) comes when you get emotional and greedy. When emotions take control, you tend to make faster, but not better, decisions. The game rewards good decisions and punishes bad ones. So we don't want emotions. But emotions always emerge, so what I like to do is walking the *** away from my keyboard for a while. Relax and watch some porn maybe, and come back only in rational mode.

Greed is all about risk management. Risking something you can afford, like a disposable hero, for a huge potential reward, like a Focus Ring, is OK. Risking your best men on quest reward, which usually includes some gold, heirlooms and a trinket, even if you are just one room away, is often not. Click that X button, bite the bullet, and live to fight another day. Always make favorable bets, never hope for godly rolls on unfavorable ones.

And of course, there will be times when the game just decides to **ck you up with really bad RNG. My mental model for this is simple - it's not my fault. Rather, it's just another way of the game saying 'I say 86 weeks, but its' really just 84. RNG tax is a thing'.

That's pretty much it for me. The first run is all about enjoying original art, music and combat design from the game. Then, if you are up to it, the second run is all about executing a reasonable plan, cold-blooded, and with a heart of steel. Darkest Dungeon does a really good job hand-crafting good experiences for such two runs.

Lastly, I must say the game has its problems. My biggest two complains -

1. Focus Ring.
2. Abuse-able stall-heal mechanics in combat.

Focus Ring is just strictly the better trinket 99% of the time, which defeats the purpose of the trinket system.
Stall-heal is tedious but too rewarding not to abuse, sadly.

That said, you can always play the game with self-imposed challenges -
1. No/Limited Focus Ring.
2. No/Limited stall-heal.

So, still a great game )

I'm going to challenge the normal negative review complaints a little bit. Is it too hard? Honestly I'm not sure. I don't think the dungeons are too hard. Very luck based sure, you die a lot sure, that's common in the rougelite genre and I don't think that part is that much worse than any other.

The problem is that Darkest Dungeon is not a rougelike. Or even a rougelite. It's an RPG. It REQUIRES you to grind and level characters. The only thing rougelike-ish about it is that the dungeons layouts are randomized, and permadeath. RPGs also have sequential dungeons, random encounters, and randomized loot drops. If it weren't for permadeath, it would play exactly like a turn-based JRPG.

There is no skill based way to complete a higher level dungeon in DD without leveling characters in low level dungeons. And unlike actual rougelikes, it punishes you for losing. They took "punishing" much too literally. In fact, they seem to have spent a lot of time thinking of creative and complex ways to punish the player. It literally requires you to just wait for your characters to heal and recover from the permanent damage they take while fighting. I don't mind dying, but I HATE waiting. There is no reason for this gameplay choice other than maybe sadism? You should never include both grinding to level characters along with permadeath. Avoiding grinding is one of the central reasons to play rougelikes over traditional RPGs, and that's the thing they decided to bring back. You can't manage the hard dungeons if your whole party of four isn't high level, so losing even one character requires you to go back and grind a new one if you don't have a replacement.


Most rougelikes suck me in. I die a hundred times, and every time I die I think "THIS time I can do it!" Even in rougelites with a lot of metaprogression, once I unlock a level, I always have a decent shot at beating it when I launch the game. In Darkest Dungeon, when even one of my characters dies, I think "time to give up and play slay the sprite on max ascension for six hours and die over and over"

In order to start having fun with DD after losing all my characters to bad RNG, I need to grind the first two dungeons for several hours to stand a chance at the higher level dungeons I managed to unlock. And the early dungeons aren't actually hard! So I'm actually NOT being challenged 70% of the time I'm playing, because I get punished for losing when I do face a challenge, and the punishment is grinding. Imagine deciding to punish your player for losing to challenges by making them play the easy part of the game for a hundred hours.


The bummer is that every other part of the game is awesome. The combat is awesome, the lore is awesome, the dungeons are awesome, the artstyle is awesome, music is awesome. But I don't want to play it. Sometimes I think about giving it another try, and I always get bored and feel like I wasted my time. I think that for me, the one change of figuring out a way to remove the grinding would turn it from a 4/10 to a 9/10. They could let you recruit characters that were already high level once you've unlocked the high level dungeons. The combat would still be exactly as challenging, but you wouldn't feel like you wasted your entire save file if you get a bad roll and lose every character.
A swirling miasma of pain of misery

This game should have easily swept the game awards for art and theme.  
the mechanics, music, visuals, and story blend together flawlessly to communicate the experience of bitter ruin and abrupt descent into calamity.  The gameplay loop is pretty standard for a party based RPG.  Prepare, Enter the dungeon, kill the monster, loot, gain power, then do it again in a tougher dungeon.  The sanity system, very good writing and voice acting personalize the experience and keep you locked in your gaming chair anxious to delve deeper into just how bad things really are.

Update: Im no longer too fond of this game. After playing it for so long, its easy to notice the very gimmicky nature of the game at this point, loaded with arbitrary and meta-game mechanics. What I mean by the last point, meta-game mechanics, is that it doesnt feel like you are playing in a living game world, but rather it feels like you are playing against a computer opponent sitting across from you whose very adept at consistently targeting your partys weak points, and hammering away at them relentlessly throughout missions, no matter what they are, all the while completely ignoring *any* area that you even moderately defended against (ex: one party member has cove phobe, another has cove adventurer. Guess what? Enemy stress attacks in cove *never* target the adventurer, and *only*, and relentlessly, target the phobe.)

Its just not very fun. Its hard, but feels hard in a quite artificial way.

Original review:

Base game recommended for those who enjoy very difficult RL challenges, however, the game becomes exceedingly repetitive rather quickly. There is also very little feeling of actual player progression; things scale upwards in difficultly rapidly and outpace your ability to match the difficulty. That is not necessarily a negative, but it is something for players to be aware of at the get-go.

Some other things to be aware of: there is essentially no exploration in this RL beyond familiarizing yourself with the different areas to go through. The movement is literally walking linear lines from point A to B, chosen on the mini-map. The stress mechanic is interesting and novel, however I personally find it in its implementation more annoying than fun. Weapons and armor, mainstays of RLs, are "streamlined" (read: boring and linear) to a point of being an after-thought. Actual equipable items only come in the form of trinkets, of which each character gets 2 slots for, and of which 99% of the trinkets themselves always have an equal number of negatives to literally counter the positives, in terms of attribute modification. This becomes really annoying, really quick, and goes towards the feeling of a lack of power progression.

But I recognize that some RL fans do enjoy the sadistic style of certain RLs, and if you are one of those, I think this game would probably suit your fancy.

Darkest Dungeon looks like a great comic book, sounds amazing...and is incredibly tedious and grindy. I recently re-installed it, and re-discovered why I'm frustrated by it. At first, it's not too difficult, but the enemies keep getting harder over time, faster than your heroes gain strength, unless you're grinding in just the right way. That would be bad enough, but then it's got random difficulty spikes with certain sub-boss enemies that occasionally appear, which are actually harder than some of the real, actual bosses that you encounter at that early stage in the game. (I think those sub-bosses might be bugged, and spawn the levelled-up versions, instead of the ones appropriate to your dungeon and hero levels.)

The game opens with a line about "making the best of a difficult situation", but that's actually not true. (Even if it's unintentional, because of poor testing or balancing.) Instead, every setback that you encounter can just be solved with grinding, and the difficulty of the game is high enough that you *need* to grind, in order to overcome those and finish the game. For example, if your experienced knight hero dies, you just need to hire a new knight when they show up in the barracks, or play with other heroes temporarily if a new knight hasn't shown up yet. The monsters and dungeons keep getting harder, but you just need to keep spamming missions to get gold and heirlooms, to upgrade your town and heroes. Those upgrades are all also really shallow, since they're just linear upgrades, and every knight can get every knight skill with enough gold, or every healer can get every healer spell. All of your heroes are interchangeable cogs in this machine, grist for the mill as it were. That fits with the pointlessness theme in this Cthulu-ish story, but makes it just a very slow, frustrating game to play. The ending of the story also fits with the pointlessness theme, which really just adds insult to injury, after you slog through this game.

If you want a horror / Cthulu story, I'd recommend enabling the difficulty option for monster crits to not double damage, and add the Reforged character mods, and the one that rebalances all the trinkets. (The vestal, alchemist, occultist, and antiquarian are all already balanced and don't need their mods, IMO.) After that, the game is still a little slow and grindy, but can just be played without frustration. (I listen to a podcast and zone out.) If you don't like or trust mods, then I'd say you're better off reading a book instead. Or you can wait for the sequel, which from what I saw on a streamer's preview of the game, looks like they removed some of the tedium. (I could be wrong, but I think the game and story can handle you losing one or two heroes, and you only ever have four maximum, and don't need to manage a huge roster of interchangeable mooks.) The sequel also seems to be adding some more depth and breadth to the mechanics, like better in-combat items and a fire damage type. :)

I would recommend this game if it wasn't for two major flaws. The first flaw is the way the game assigns missions according to the level your heroes have attained. What they've done is that they limit variety missions if you have one or more heroes with higher level by filling limited slots of missions with higher ones you may or may not have a party to take on. If anything they should have added a drop down window for said mission slots instead of making the quest screen a huge sigh and eye rolling endeavor. The second flaw is that they have artificially extended the play time of this game with grinding gimmick that gets stale very quickly. This gimmick isn't flawed from the onset, it is that they have extended it way way way way way way way way too far, making the player have to grind for lord knows how long to complete all the upgrades and modifications one wants to complete the game with. Not my cup tea. I hope the sequel fixes these flaws because otherwise this would be a stellar game.

I haven't raged playing video games for the longest time, then came whatever this is... Don't get into it if you value your mental health, otherwise it's a brilliant(see what i did there?) turn based dungeon crawler.

It's great at what it tries to achieve: instilling a sense of hopeless dread and what feels like insurmountable odds in the aesthetics, music, sfx, artstyle, narration, a beautiful game, harsh and dark, but sadly so too is the gameplay. 

tl;dr: It's not awful, but its so grindy and full of dissatisfying reliance on luck it detracts from the overall experience. (Cool game, playing it feels like a chore)

I appreciate it for what it is but it felt like i was actively wasting my time at points throughout my playthrough when it came to the gameplay. The over abundance of luck when it comes to many facets of the games design is just such a turn off for me, you must be sufficiently lucky to have you're heroes:

Land attacks, dodge attacks, have the intended effects of said attacks be put on enemies, hit within a range of damage / do a meaningful amount, roll for initiative for when in sequence they can attack, be able to withstand trauma, survive fatal blows, have positive mental breaks (rare), gain/keep/replace positive quirks, gain/lose/replace negative quirks, not become afflicted by debilitating diseases by chance or in battle, not disappear for weeks on end from your roster, keep trinkets or traits after relaxing in the hamlet between missions, or even having new recruits that are worth the time investment, etc. I could go on and on.

The gameplay is a rollercoaster. I found sometimes it was satisfying, having to think before doing an attack or even trying to think of the capabilities of my enemies, enacting a plan, making mistakes and being punished for them. Where I stopped really having fun was when i realized i wasn't in control of whether i could have a positive outcome from a fight or not and what seemed like being punished for even playing the game, feeling like i am just wasting my time. 

Getting crit/hitting one, heroes/enemies dodging, missing 95% chances back to back/landing crazy 5% chances back to back, losing/saving valuable heroes despite my best efforts. It really feels like you live and die by the roll of a pair of dice, what does it matter that i hit 1,2,3,4 nasty crits back to back if my lvl 5 leper just got hit with 3 trauma attacks in a row, became hopeless, refused any healing, skipped his turns, and died a stupid death, resulting in me having to run away, failing the run away check leaving my remaining heroes open for even more harassment by the games rng.

 It boils down to grind, the impact of good things happening in Darkest Dungeon seldom outweighs the effects of a few bad things happening. If you just get unlucky enough you will end up having to sink multiple hours just trying to get back what you lost.

Here's a review from someone that knows more of what I'm trying to communicate: https://youtu.be/_Buwei6ZWqU

[h1] Nearly Seven Years [/h1]

I've been playing Darkest Dungeon for almost seven years and to me it's always been the perfect rogue-like, although I've never had the patience or time to finish it until now.

First let me start off by saying that Darkest Dungeon, at least on its default settings, is still an unforgiving game. At the very beginning, as soon as you boot up the game, it tells you that Darkest Dungeon is all about making the best of a bad situation, and I'm sure anyone who's put any amount of time into the game, can confirm that this is definitely the case.

Effectively, the game plays as thus; A week passes every mission, there are multiple 'Dungeons' you can go to, each with their own trials and tribulations, enemy types and bosses, you take a party of four that will suit that dungeon and complete the given task. After that task is completed (or failed) party members will level up and you'll earn gold and trinkets, which you use to upgrade your Hamlet (Effectively your base of operations) in order to become stronger to make dungeoning easier and get access to harder quests.

There are a multitude of heroes/classes to choose from, each of them bringing their own unique abilities and playstyle to the game. You can also rename all of your heroes to anything you want, making the game ideal for those who want to put their friends in the game (This is what I do for all games that I can, such as XCOM or Phoenix Point or Disgaea) or also ideal for Twitch Streamers as you can make your chat feel more involved by naming them after people in there.

The gameplay loop is very satisfying and I don't ever get bored playing this game, although what I will say is, things -will- go wrong. You will lose that max level hero to something out of your control, yes you can debate that the game is mostly RNG, but think of the game more like D&D as opposed to other turn based RPG's, it's the dice that does decide at the end of the day. However you do have a multitude of ways of mitigating damage and making sure you're getting the most out of your heroes, if you plan ahead well, know when to take a loss as well (tactically) you'll be fine.

The game is long, there's no doubt about that, you're talking anywhere between 30-50 hours for one proper run at the game, beating the final boss and all.

Another great aspect about the game is the Hamlet, randomly you'll get Town Events, these can be positive or negative. Things such as... The Tavern is free for the week, or a free weapon upgrade (This can be particularly helpful in the mid-game when money is an issue.) Or negative ones such as a big bad boss is at your doorstep all of a sudden, with no preparation and you -need- to deal with him. It makes the game feel alive, like not everything is always 100% under your control, and this, for me, is what makes the game so exhilarating. 

In truth, I don't really have anything bad to say about the game, I guess I've been done over by RNG a few times but upon reflection, I guess I could've prepared better, but sometimes I did just get crit 3 times in a row and had a hero die, but I also don't see how blaming RNG for losing someone is a bad thing, especially when that's the nature of the game; you expect this going into it. But that's the reality of the game, I'd say it's a feature and not a flaw, you can do all the preparation in the world and be set up perfectly, but as the narrator so aptly puts it, as you think you're doing well. "How quickly the tide turns."

To me, this is one of the best games ever made, it offers extensive replay-ability and despite its unforgiving nature, it's extremely rewarding, I promise when you pull off something magnificent, or one of your heroes becomes Virtuous, or you beat a boss that was skelping you endlessly, you'll be jumping out of your seat in joy.
