One of my favorites of all time. This game can frustrate me that few others can, because the game can decide to fuck you at even if you make the best decisions because RNGesus decides to, the game says "Well THAT just happened, what are you going to do about it!?" and expects you to overcome what feels like a devastating loss. 

And yet, it remains fun. 

Also, one of the things I love about Darkest Dungeon is that it's turned based but without a time limit on when you have to make your decisions. Also, when the enemy attacks, there's nothing you can do to change the outcomes. Both of these features means that you can leave your computer and come back and deal with the situation when you get back. 

Read the other reviews for the in-depth analysis one what the game is and how it functions, all I can say is that you if think you'll like a game like this, you probably will.

I thought Dark Dungeon (DD) this would be challenging, hard and fun. This is from someone who can stomach MMO RNG. All I found here was endless punishment with little to no progression after so many hours of playtime. I'll try break it down for detail. 

[h1]Story:[/h1]
I've haven't completed the game, but so far it's gives a light background on why the town and the narrator is so gloomy. As you progress, little diary entries can be found for extra flavour. The actual setting is fictional but things like classes that use single shot pistols and crossbows gives a 18th century feel. The game doesn't really need a strong story since most of the features were part of gameplay.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
You work your way through randomly generated rooms which is the game's strongest feature. This is considering the limited graphic assets, DD gives a new feel to each new dungeon the player decides to plunder. There's also the standard RPG heroes progression, classes, renaming, and stat changing items. It's clearly simplistic by design so players can focus on the main mechanic, Stress. The more you push your heroes to do super human things, the faster you'll find a team wipe. In fact, the dev's tried a little too hard on this part and forgot about letting the players know some dungeons shouldn't be attempted. This game has punishment by the truck load.

Like I said before, it's so severe, that even recruiting new heroes is a chore. Let's start there. Heroes are randomised in terms of skill set, and alot of the time you're staring at a roster full of unplayable heroes with conflicting skill sets. You can retrain them which cost a punishing amount of money; coinage that you simply don't have at the start or mid game. In fact you earn so little money that progression slows down as you get further. Add that to the fact they come out of a dungeon with a bad trait 90% of the time means they'll lose value after 2 uses unless your spend more money. What makes this worse is that they can't cure their deseases or lose bad quirks at the same time. So this means yet another punishment since both deseases and quirks will become more severe and cost more to remove each week you put it off. 

So how do you get stress and deseases? Through dungeon combat which has many great features and clever designs. Unfortunately it's eclipsed by the fact the random events are biased towards gaining stress and misses in attacks. I've had a hero miss twice in a row even though it says 90% chance to hit. Granted after playing over 100 hours, players might see rare misfortune like this, but I haven't gotten close to that much gameplay. Positioning is vital and this plays a great deal with strategy and planning before starting out into a dungeon. In fact once you got a good synergy going, most fights end favourably. That's if you can get the right people (see above). Turn order and speed is the second most critical thing in this game since it decides turn order. More speed and means your heroes go first. For what ever reason, the further you progress, there will be a boss that breaks this rule and hits you twice per turn. If the turn ends with an enemy attack, the next turn can start with their attack since they got more speed. But 2 swipes in a single turn was incredibly stupid and great waste of time. The whole 5 mins was just enemy attacking and spamming moves. 5 mins of no keyboard or mouse. 

So a biased towards misses and handing the initiative to the enemy AI will always leave your party worse for wear. But all would be fine if the coin and treasure are good, right? High risk, high reward? Nope. DD doesn't even have risk since you can't tell what random things will happen inside a dungeon. At best, you can walk away with minimum stress but never enough money to remove all the bad quirks your team will stack up. At worst, you'll team wipe and lose all items, exp, and training. I don't even know they why allow renaming if they're forcing players to make 99% of heroes expendable like this. 


[h1]Sound:[/h1]
The ambience and sound effects are absolutely amazing. It goes well with demonic design of the dungeons. Not much to rave about in terms of the music once you hear it play over 100 times. That's the same with any game soundtrack so nothing new here. The voice actor for the narrator is harder to judge. I can imagine some would say he's a broken man, which understandably sound awkward. The other voice lines like gagging and spluttering weren't over the top.

[h1]Graphics:[/h1]
As with most 2D games, Art style is king. It was grotesque when it needs to be, intimadating when you meet a boss. With many mixed themes thrown around like despair and death, the colour pallete was mostly dark colours. Each attack animation had a comic book feel, with it's stylised expression and shading. It needs to be said that movement isn't entirely animated.

It's really hard to expect everyone to like a certain art, and this extends to DD's graphics. For me, I like it. 

[h1]Bugs and Overall:[/h1]
For a game that's selling gameplay as a feature, there was just no mid game substance. It creates the illusion that players have pathways to finishing the game. Plenty of unique concepts and mechanics, great art, and bug free. I only wished they keep the punishments mechanics in check. Whoever balanced the economy should really think about decreasing the 'cost' ingame to even make it playable. Just horrible execution.

[h1]Score:[/h1]
Story: 1/1
Gamplay: 1/6
Sound: 1/1
Graphics: 1/1
Bugs: 1/1

Overall: 5/10

Ever doubt YOUR own bad luck? Do you ask yourself constantly "oh, how much worse can it get"? You wanna prove how much your tiniest actions can change at the roll of a dice? Are you genuinely masochistic?
Try this game if you truly, absolutely hate yourself! 

But seriously speaking, this game is a wild rollercoaster. Its ups are extremely high, and the lows are extremely low. The game will spit in your face, slap you, steal your gold, and then burn your town down. But that's okay because that one hero who died long ago and you spent almost 40k gold on will just come back to life because they felt like it.
Game is extremely hard and unforgiving. There's a lot of randomness, but just enough to the point where you can feel like you're able to do things with the right gear. It will constantly test you, and has a very high chance of giving you an affliction IRL. Sometimes the game will feel like utter and complete bullshit, other times you'll get a dopamine rush when you crit for 68. There is no inbetween.
My only real gripe with a game like this is the grind. You'll need to spend a lot of time running the same missions over and over again, which helps you learn the mechanics via brute force and trial and error, but at the same time you'll inevitably burn out because of how same-y a lot of fights tend to get, at least in the same region. Trinkets are both a blessing and a curse because good trinkets can change the outcome of a mission entirely, but losing them is always worse than losing a maxed-out hero towards the endgame. It becomes easier to replace people and not trinkets, so it's incredibly demoralizing to lose such a powerful artifact.

It's a very painful game which punishes you deeply, but when good things happen, they happen for sure. The grind I feel is its biggest issue.

Darkest Dungeon is one part strategic-base-and-roster-management (think X-COM) and one part tactical-party-combat.  It's also one part it's own deliciously creative dungeon crawler, brought to life with one of the best narrators I've ever experienced, and a crushing atmosphere.  It can be immensely difficult (if, like me, that's what you're into), or you can play on a level that's challenging, but will never have you restarting your whole game.  I really can't recommend this game enough to fans of tactics games.  One of my all-time favorites, and, I think, a gaming masterpiece.

this game is really really really good, 4/5


     BUT


     it's gonna kick your ass. and not in a fun way. you're gonna be 20h into a run you've spent hours and hours and you're gonna get fucked. couple bad crits maybe, and bam, 3/4 max level characters that you've pumped time, money, and super rare loot into are gonna be dead, and all that shit's gonna be gone forever, vanished into thin air. 

     [i] and that's part of the game. [/i]

     people have said this is a game about handling setbacks, and that's possibly the best description of it i could provide. more often than not you're on the back foot. sometimes you can't afford proper provisions for an excursion. sometimes you gotta take a guy who's still afflicted from the stress of the last trip, and rush through before he freaks everyone [i]else[/i] out. the game is tough as nails, and doesn't give you an inch.

     if that doesn't discourage you, i highly recommend giving this game a shot, because you'll find one of the most stylish and inspired rpgs you'll ever play!

     as a closing thought, be careful with the dlcs on your first playthrough! especially the crimson court, juggling the vampire curse is NOT something you wanna be dealing with while you're still learning core game mechanics. there's a toggle for dlcs before you start a save file, think of them like an extension of choosing your difficulty!

Darkest Dungeon (2016) *had* to be one of the best games I have ever played.

The difficulty at the beginning is immense, but as soon as you get familiar with the Heroes, it starts to very slowly become a cake walk. The gameplay can also be very, very grindy, which I can get, although I don't really base the gameplay of Darkest Dungeon off of the Objectives, I base it off of the battles, the balance, the variety of enemies/bosses, and how much fun I'm having. I think that Darkest Dungeon checks all of these off, except maybe for the fun part. If your RNG is really bad, it can piss you off. It took me ~70 hours to finish this game without trying to rush anything.

The atmosphere in Darkest Dungeon is likely one of the best I have ever seen in a game, with it's art, narration, enemy design and variety, and most importantly, this game's soundtrack. I'm genuinely surprised this game's soundtrack didn't instantly blow up at launch, although I didn't play this at launch, I think this game's soundtrack, and soundtrack creator, deserve much more than what they got. If you haven't listened to it, I totally recommend you do.

This game's DLC is actually pretty good, excluding The Butcher's Circus. Both The Color of Madness and Crimson Court DLC offer a lot of original content that is brand new to the game, but still has the same Darkest Dungeon tone to them. Although the difficulty does tend to scale, especially in late game The Color of Madness. The only good thing The Butcher's Circus brought us is it's amazing exclusive soundtrack. Having the Death's Door mechanic in a PvP environment was a terrible idea, you basically just get heroes who have high stress damage dealing, and team wipe within 3 rounds.

Overall, if you never played Darkest Dungeon, or a game like it, you will probably not like Darkest Dungeon. But if you like side scrolling, turn based, RPGs, then it really doesn't get much better.

Unfortunately due to the state of Darkest Dungeon 2, Red Hooks most objectively up to date gameplay is extremely uninspired, and it's actually sad to see who was plausibly my favorite game developer, ruin their reputation like this. I regret every second of development time spent on modifying their game that is already extremely punishing for new players, regardless of difficulty level, it's just the nature of the game. Do not give Red Hook your money in 2023.

I also have no choice but to stop modding this game due to a frame rate bug that is ruining my experience, after nearly half of a year. Yes, half of a fucking year, I could not find a fix for this and it's quite clear Red Hook couldn't care less.

I shall recommend this game to everyone who is reading my review right now. It's basically a turn based card game, but cards are replaced with heroes and monsters as an enemies. You need to develop your heroes in order to proceed further, yea sound easy but if your hero dies he dies forever (unless magically revived by godly forces). There are also trinkets (accessories) for your heroes, and they can be equipped according to your hero's specialty. Also there is narrator with cool voice that says random stuff, I don't really listen to him to be honest.

Yes, yes all the positive stuff. anyways:

-First of, you can not skip. That means you have to sit through every panic attack, reaction and comment the characters make. Like a school play, where one child starts crying on stage. You're just waitin' for them to be done so you can continue and move on. It is infuriating! And NOT fun. Knowing that the team won't survive AND having too sit through their snail-race of a downward spiral, I would rather have my tonsils removed out my rectum without anesthetics. 

-Secondly, the RNG is full on poop-aids. It renders anything, and I mean ANYTHING, you do to 'improve' your success odds completely pointless. The stats loose any and all point, and become merely aesthetics on the screen. It can create a literal stress loops in the adventure group. And you are forced to watch them panic themself to death, BECAUSE YOU CAN'T SKIP!!

-Thirdly; the online/pvp part. It is unbalanced as hell. If you do not win the coin toss, give up. You cannot win. Also the RNG there is bad aswell. But this is not as important. You're not buying the game for the online part anyways.

If you are working towards trying to get a heartattack or an aneurysm, this game is great for that.
10/10 would put my life and sanity in the hands of RNG again.

TLDR: A lovecraftian-themed XCOM strategy game mixed with a turn-based RPG combat dungeon-crawler. Solid game that can be tailored to your liking with mods. A 3/5 game that becomes a 4/5 with mods. Worth the money for fans of the hardcore strategy genre, and worth it for most people on sale if they're willing to put in the time to beat a campaign.

Pros: Cool art and music direction. Team-building for missions is fairly complex with the Quirk & Trinket & Mission systems. Trinket system especially hooks you into running more missions as you hunt for the perfect equipment builds. Nice town-upgrade system. A wonderful modding community that has added many QoL fixes and content add-ons. Solid combat system, and a relatively small learning curve.

Cons: Combat and exploration can become quite repetitive, similar to XCOM. Combat and exploring dungeons is novel at first, but after awhile you start to see the same locations and enemies over and over again as you grind for resources. Then dungeon exploration becomes slow and tedious, with walking and combat animations taking forever to get through. After mastering the learning curve for combat, the biggest challenge you have is inventory/town/character management, all of which require resources. Most of the "difficulty" comes from artificially limiting the amount of resources you can get from each mission, which for some people is fine. For me, it looks a lot like an artificial time-sink. Campaign runs can be 60-100 hours. I've seen enough of this type of difficulty in other games that it ends up being a turn-off. I don't need to grind the same dungeons over and over just to get the 1x resource I need to get the next upgrade because I had to choose not to get it in the last mission because my inventory was full of other important stuff. Thankfully the modding community comes in clutch with mods to fix most issues one might have with the game.

EDIT: After a few restarts and a 145 hour run time, I'm back to say that the game is still worth it. Game is definitely not for the faint of heart. Even with the issue of mercilessly dragging out progression via limited resources and slow animations. The DLC in particular add some fun new game modes and characters, but the core gameplay is solid. I may downgrade the rating to a medium 2.5/5 due to the unnecessary dragging of gameplay and some of the repetitive dungeon-crawling, but mods do correct a lot of issues, which still probably bring it up to a 4/5. Don't expect to grind out everything in a couple days. It will take weeks to months of real time to beat the Darkest Dungeon - go in, expect characters to be expendable, and try not to be disheartened if something goes wrong - play it casual and you'll get there.

I'll probably never do another play-through again due to the sheer length of each campaign, but if I were, it would be with additional modded content (sunward isles community made DLC, abyss, community-made characters, etc) in order to add some more variety to the characters, locations, enemy types and overall game mechanics.  For those thinking of doing a 1-and-done playthrough, try adding those mods to reduce some of the repetitiveness - would probably have made the end-game 30+ hour grind more interesting.

Nobody seems to appreciate how funny this game is?  "Dark Comedy" should be the most popular thing this is tagged with.  None of the other reviews mention it....  First off, there's this overly-dramatic weird dude narrating everything you do.  Sometimes he'll catch himself being too zealous and try to save face, for example, sometimes after opening a chest he'll say, "IMPRESSIVE HAUL!... if you... value... such things....."  Sometimes he's just psychotic - like if an enemy dies of poison he'll sometimes say, "Slowly, gently... this is how a life is taken!"  Sometimes the things he says don't make any logical sense - there's just a lot of alliteration, like, "packs laden with loot are often low on supplies."  Basically really bad dad jokes, but with medieval vocabulary.  It's an incredibly unique sense of humor that I've never seen before.

It's not just the narrator either, it's everything.  The diseases the characters get while adventuring, like "The Runs" for example.  The personality traits they acquire, like "The Witness" - due to something they saw in church, they'll no longer pray for stress relief (it's a reference to child molestation by priests).  When their stress builds up to 100, they get an "affliction" which can have hilarious effects.  They could become "Abusive" for example and when this happens, they'll berate other members of their party which in turn stresses THEM out further, possibly causing a chain reaction with everyone getting afflictions.  They could become "Paranoid" and refuse to let other party members heal them.  They could become "Masochistic" and attack themselves.  You could then, after the dungeon run, put them in the asylum to treat their conditions.    You could pay to have their negative personality traits literally beaten out of them.  If it's not "Dark Comedy" I don't know what is.

It doesn't end there.  Even the characters' skills have funny flavor to them.  For example, The Graverobber has a camping skill called, "Gallows Humor" which when used, lowers her stress by 25 and all party members either get their stress lowered by 15 or get their stress RAISED by 15.  Get it?  She basically tells a sick joke while camping and there's a chance some people don't appreciate it and this stresses them out.  There's a bard-like character who plays a mandolin and his camping skills have names that all allude to real music... but it's all cheesy 80's tunes (Every Rose Has Its Thorns, Eye Of The Tiger, and If I Could Turn Back Time).  He's also got a skill called "Mockery" which raises one character's stress while lowering everyone else's stress (meaning that he makes a joke at someone's expense, which stresses them out and makes everyone else laugh).

You don't usually see such highly emotionally intelligent things coming from RPG devs.  Everything is translated into a number in these sorts of games - everything.  The college level psychology expertise couldn't be quite as funny in another genre of game - the irony of its presence in the nerdiest genre just adds that extra layer of comedy.  No offense to nerds, it's just that usually if you sharpen one corner of your mind, another softens.
